sentence: Thank you for your suggestion of increasing the discussion of the results.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We’ve expanded the discussion of the results as much as possible.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: For now we would prefer to keep the actual bar plot of individual module performance in the appendix in the interest of space, and keep the dataset description in the main part, as this was appreciated by the other two reviewers.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: As you say, the ability to generalize is very important in mathematics.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The paper contains an extrapolation test set to do exactly this - these include generalization tests on larger numbers, longer sequences, more function compositions (which is similar to having more variables), etc (see Appendix B for more details).
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: We haven’t attempted to be exhaustive in types of generalization, but the extrapolation test set can be extended in the future to allow for this.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: None of the modules currently include “unsolvable” as an answer, but this is something that would definitely fit within the framework.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (As an aside: there would be no need to have a special character; we could simply select some consistent word like “Unsolvable”; neural models trained so far seem to have no problem outputting “True” or “False”.) More generally, there are many further types of problems, that could be included in the dataset - but we hope for now that the current range is comprehensive in types of reasoning required for school-level mathematics.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: We always welcome contributions to the dataset that extend the range of questions in a consistent manner.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for your positive review, we address your reasonable concern for the applications of the proposed method in below:
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Q1:  It would be nice to see a better case made for spherical convolutions within the experimental section.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A1
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: : We believe the best case is the non-rigid shape classification and retrieval.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our method achieves a state-of-the-art classification and retrieval performance on Shrec’11.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The good performance on non-rigid shape is mainly contributed by the use of bijective spherical parameterization method, which obtains the input spherical image without topological information losses.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: When using spherical projection method to represent 3D shape, there will be information loss if the object is non-convex.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The lossy input affect the performance of rigid shape analysis to some extent.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q2: The experiments on SHREC17 show all three spherical methods under-performing other approaches.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: It leaves it unclear to the reader when someone should choose to utilize a spherical method or when the proposed method would then be preferred compared to other spherical methods.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Is there a task that this representation significantly outperforms other spherical methods and non-spherical method?
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A2: The experiments on SHREC17 does show all three spherical methods slightly under-perform some other state-of-the art approaches, We believe this is mainly due to the information losses introduced in the spherical projection process which retains only the convex portion geometric information.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Future improvements can be added by using:  (1) less lossy input in spherical projection methods (e.g. on top of SEF, and EDF, we can also add other statistic information such as the minimum distance of intersection, mean distance of intersections or standard deviation of the intersection and so on to reduce the information losses); (2) extend the spherical parameterization method on to the general 3D shapes.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Currently, the spherical parameterization method only works for genus-0 closed object.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The 3D models presented on ModelNet and Shrec’17 are of arbitrary genus which prevents us from using spherical parameterization method.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Generalization of spherical parameterization methods to objects with arbitrary topology will be one of the future work.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Compared to non-spherical method, spherical image is one of the most compact representation for 3D shape analysis, the spherical convolution methods rely on no data augmentation (for Type I and Type II) or reduced data augmentation (for Type III, only SO(2) rotation augmentation is required).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Other non-spherical method (such as volumetric or multi-view based methods)  can only be generalized into unknown orientations using SO(3) rotation augmentations, their representation of 3D shapes are either too sparse (voxel model) or too redundant (multi-view projections).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Compared to SO(3) spherical convolution method (Cohen et al. 2018), our network is computationally efficient (in terms of network model), but we have to admit that this is at the price of required data augmentation
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Another advantage is that our network allows local filters and local-to-global multi-level spherical features extraction.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The other two spherical convolution methods (Cohen et al 2018 and Esteves et al 2018) use a lat-lon grid and conduct convolution in the Fourier space, which has a common disadvantage: the Fourier transform does not support local spherical filters.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Another disadvantage is the use of lat-lon grid which introduces unevenness of the perception field (due to the high resolution near the poles, and low resolution at the equator).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Experimentally, we compared the three spherical convolution methods in Table 3 using Shrec’17 perturbed shape retrieval experiment.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Cohen et al 2018 and ours obtain similar performances because both of the methods used anisotropic filters, the former achieves rotational invariant using SO(3) rotations for filters, while ours achieves rotational invariant using alt-az rotation of filter and SO(2) rotation augmentation of input shapes.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: As expected, anisotropic filter perform  better than the isotropic filter proposed in Esteves et al 2018 which limits the model capacity.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q3:  Is there a specific useful application where spherical methods in general outperform other approaches?
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A3: As mentioned in Cohen et al 2018, perhaps the most exciting future application of the Spherical CNN is in omnidirectional vision.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Although very little omnidirectional image data is currently available in public repositories, the increasing prevalence of omnidirectional sensors in drones, robots, and autonomous cars makes this a very compelling application of our work.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Omnidirectional vision is a better application to show the strength of the spherical convolution method.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We thank reviewer for his insightful comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that sinkhorn iteration is a way to obtain an upper bound on Wasserstein distance.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: However, based on the original paper, they solve the Sinkhorn divergen with T iterations, later when they solve the generator based on the estimated distance, the gradient has to backpropagate through those T iterations, which is expensive and infeasible.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: We also note that there is new work, IPOT (Xie et al., 2018), which can get rid of backpropagating through the T iterations as what we adopted (Bertsekas, 1985) in the paper.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Combining PC-GAN with IPOP or other future works could be an interesting future work.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: 2.  The variance of the sandwiched estimator can be higher, but we are more concerned about bias in this work, which can be treated as a bias-variance trade-off.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: 3. The 20:1 mixture used in practice do not directly correspond to s in theory, because the distances we compute are not scaled.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: For example, if the f_\phi, the discriminator of GAN, is k-Lipschitz, the lower bound estimate should be divided by k.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: However, k is unknown in practice.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Therefore, we just numerically did a coarse grid search and find the best mixture ratio.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Also, we try different ratios as we replied to R2 above.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Ratio                   D2F (Distance to Face)
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Coverage
label: rebuttal_none

sentence: 4. We do not consider W_s to be very close from W_U. As can be seen from Figure 6, for the aeroplane examples, W_U fails to capture aeroplane tires while W_s can.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Similarly for Chair example, W_s recovers better legs than W_U. Quantitatively, we highlight that W_s outperforms W_U consistently as shown in Table 1.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Thus, we consider both W_U and W_L is needed to generate good quality point clouds.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We have simplified the architecture described in the paper by combining the networks $\sigma$ and $\omega$, and included the results from this architecture as well, producing a more robust architecture that performs better for multiple rewrite steps (while keeping the original, more complicated solution as one of the baselines).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: As suggested, we have added further analysis of failure cases.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We also corrected the typos and clarified the definitions of True, Pred (One Step) and Pred (Multi Step) variants.

sentence: We will address the issues you mentioned.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: ARTNet is not very much related to our V4D.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Basically, ARTNet is an alternative for 3D CNNs by replacing 3D convolution layers with SMART blocks.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The SMART blocks are two branch units, with one branch for learning static appearance features and one branch for learning motion features.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: ARTNet is a clip-based method for learning short-term representations while our V4D is a video-level method for learning both short-term and long-term representations.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2.	During training, we uniformly divide the whole video into U sections and randomly select one action unit from each section.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: So there are no overlaps for training.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For testing, there might be overlapping during sampling due to the limit length of video.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, our V4D inference algorithm in section 3.4 guarantees that only the non-overlapping action units will interact with each other during testing.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Sure.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We train all the models with 8 GPUs of GTX 1080 with memory capacity of 11178MB.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For the inference speed, our V4D ResNet18 takes 0.67s per video and V4D ResNet50 takes 1.22s per video.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In addition, we also reported the GFLOPs of V4D and compared it with other typical methods in Table 2(b).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: For training on Mini-Kinetics, V4D ResNet18 takes a bit more than 1 day while V4D ResNet50 takes a bit more than 3 days.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We can only find the results of ARTNet ResNet18 in the published paper.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: After communication with the authors of ARTNet, we confirm that there are no results published for ARTNet ResNet50.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: So instead we implement ARTNet ResNet50 by ourselves and the top1 accuracy on Kinetics-400 is 74.3%.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This is still lower than our V4D ResNet50 whose top1 on Kinetics-400 is 77.4%.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Also, ARTNet ResNet18 reports an average metric of 81.4%, which is the average of top1 and top5 accuracy.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: While our V4D yields an average score of 85.3%.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Thank you for providing this related work and we now cite this paper in the second version.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: This paper utilizes 4D CNN to process videos of point cloud so that their input is 4D data.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Instead, our V4D processes videos of RGB frames so that our input is 3D data.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: This basically makes the methods and tasks quite different.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Actually we was going to cite this paper yet considering the significant difference we finally did not cite it in the original version.

sentence: What would make it stronger imo is to address the issue of how much is gained from a discrete vs. continuous representation.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Discrete representations by themselves are not better than continuous ones (cf. Table 1, wav2vec vs. vq-wav2vec).
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: However, discretization enables the application of existing algorithms from the NLP literature which were designed for discrete inputs.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: We show that the BERT model can be directly applied to discretized speech.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: BERT can better model context than (vq-)wav2vec.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: >> The authors take it as a given that discrete is good because it allows us to leverage work in NLP. That makes sense -- but at what cost?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Chaining vq-wav2vec and BERT requires more computational effort than just wav2vec, however, it does improve accuracy as our results show (cf. Table 1).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Running BERT requires roughly as much computational overhead as just vq-wav2vec.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: >> The state of the art on LibriSpeech is not Mohamed at al. 2019.

sentence: See e.g. Irie et al. Interspeech 2019 for better result.

sentence: A: You are totally right, eq.10 simplifies to $\log p(D) \geq
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: \mathbb{E}_{I \sim
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: q^D}
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: \left[ \sum\limits_{i=1}^{|D|-1} \log p(D_i |D_{<i},I_{<i})  + \sum\limits_{v \not\in U^D} \log p(v \not\in U^D| D_{\leq |D|-1}, I)\right]$. We were aware of this but for simplicity and the conciseness of presentation we chose to not give this final derivation.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Also, this was because $P(D_i,I_i|D_{<i},I_{<i})$ is much easier to compute (and more efficient) than $P(D_i |D_{<i},I_{<i})$, given that the computation of $P(I_i| D_{\leq i},I_{<i})$ is in both case required for sampling ($P(D_i,I_i|D_{<i},I_{<i})$ involves a simple product while $P(D_i|D_{<i},I_{<i})$ involves a sum of products).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: But we agree this was not a good choice, since this simplification appears obvious to the reader.

sentence: We hesitated a lot on this, our decision was taken to present things as closely as possible to our implementation (by the way there was a mistake in the algorithm 2 resulting from this hesitation - the implementation for our experiments was correct however).

sentence: We agree that this may appear confusing.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Particularly since it gives the feeling that parents of infections are not involved anymore in the computation.

sentence: But there are actually, since there remains $P(I_i|D_{<i},I_{<i})$ terms in the expectation.

sentence: The process learns parameters that tend to give high probabilities to the most likely parent vectors regarding infections from the episode.

sentence: In the revision of the paper, we gave the final derivation you suggested, since it is better for comprehension (It also allowed us to discuss more precisely on what is optimized by considering the given gradient update), and we discuss about its implementation in the appendix as an explanation for the algorithm 2 (that only slightly changed to correct the aforementioned mistake).

sentence: In particular, the Tandem approaches utilize the EM algorithm that should be highly influenced by outliers, while our method is specialized to be robust against them.

sentence: We clarified this in Section 2 of the revised draft.

sentence: 3. [1] successfully use PPO with an LSTM policy on a challenging, partially-observable environment.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: It is equally principled to use a Transformer policy, since both would operate on the same sequence of observations.

sentence: The SimPLe algorithm runs PPO on an MDP approximated by a powerful model that handles stochasticity well, which is also a valid approach.

sentence: 4. We updated the paper with a justification of our action discretization scheme.

sentence: Such a discretization has a number of benefits, including multi-modality, which cannot be achieved using a parameterized Gaussian policy.

sentence: [2] show that discretization of the action space improves the average performance, stability and robustness to hyperparameters of reinforcement learning agents on a range of continuous control tasks.

sentence: 5. While we have not included such transfer experiments in our current work, we do believe that a model trained on enough architectures and tasks will generalize to new ones.

sentence: 1- There are two reasons that concept and problem embedding are performed in this work.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Considering concept continuity is an important matter in education.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Having concept embedding, concept continuity can be reached as is discussed in the last paragraph on page 7 and some other examples are given in table 2.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: By just having the most sophisticated concept extractor, the concept continuity cannot be retrieved.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Furthermore, problem embedding is used by the recommender system to project the performance of students on the problems they solved onto other problems that they have not solved.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This way, we have an idea of what problems should be recommended to them and which problems should not by having an evaluation of their ability to solve unseen problems and recommend problems in the boundary of their capacity, not way beyond, and to recommend problems in a way that covers all concepts necessary for students to learn.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We have observed interesting patterns, e.g. similar problems are more likely to be solved correctly at the same time or wrong at the same time.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Note that by just having the concepts of problems that are not in numerical form, performance projection may not be feasible and there is a need for using other methods like embedding.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: 2- The data size being small
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: is just the nature of the application.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Creating new problems is a creative process and is not easy, given that with the insight we have on the application, the data size seems to suffice.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Furthermore, since Prob2Vec is performing well for not a relatively big data set, it would definitely do well for big data sets since the more data we have, the more precise the concept and problem embedding are.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The easy-tough-to-beat method proposed by Arora et al. is the state of the art in unsupervised sentence embedding that we compared our algorithm with.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Please let us know if we missed anything.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Pre-training is a common practice in transfer learning (one-shot learning).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The objective function does not differ from the objective function used for post training.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Training on only negative samples with lower training epochs than the training epochs in post training just adjusts the weights of the neural network to a better starting point.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If the training epochs in pre-training is relatively smaller than the training epochs in post training, due to curse of dimensionality, the warm start for post training results in better performance for NN classifier.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: To make it more clear what it means to train the neural network on a pure set of negative data samples, think about batch training.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: It's not likely, but possible, that a batch only has negative or positive samples.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In the pre-training phase of our method, we intentionally used a pure set of negative samples (with fewer training epochs) to have a warm start for post training.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: As table 3 shows, our proposed method outperforms one-shot learning.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Please look at part 1 of our response to reviewer2 and part 2 of comment titled "Response to Question on Negative Pre-Training" below.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their insightful comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Q1 "all the experiments except the last row of Table 2 concern adaptation between two domains. Given the paper title, the reviewer would have expected more experiments in a multiple domain context."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A1 A main difference between domain adaptation and MDL is the fact that the former aims to minimize the target error, while the latter aims to minimize the average error.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In this sense, our goal (and the validation experiments on Cell) are focused on MDL.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Q2
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: "Although the paper introduces the generalization bound for MDL, it does not give new formulation or algorithm to handle MDL" [...] "There is no connection between the theoretical results on MDL generalization bound and the proposed method MULANN."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A2 This issue is related to the above: the new generalization bound extends that of Ben David et al. in the sense that it considers all pairs of domains involved, thus bounding the *average* risk; and this bound is the one underlying the proposed algorithm and its MDL experiments.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We have clarified this in the manuscript.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Q3 "the reviewer was interested to see how the proposed MDL performs on jointly adapting SVHN, MNIST, MNIST-M, and USPS or jointly adapting DSLR, Amazon, and Webcam for OFFICE dataset. "
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A3: We added 3 domain experiments for Office, which are now displayed in Appendix E.1 table 6.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: As discussed in [3], we also find that the addition of a second source is not necessarily beneficial to target accuracy.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Q4: Comparison with some of the DA baselines (ADDA[1], DSN[2]) is missing."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A4: ADDA, an unsupervised DA method, proceeds by training sequentially a classifier on Source, then learning the Target feature space by making it indistinguishable from the Source one.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: However this is not applicable to the semi-supervised setting: either target labels would not be used in the first training step, or they would be used but without any domain loss to account for the fact that two domains are being used at the same time.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Thus, the classifier would actually learn two sub-classifiers: one for each domain, which would turn counter-productive in the second step where this strong distinction between source and target would have to be un-learned.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We are re-programming DSN and experimental results will be added.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the suggestion.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Q5: "The reviewer is also interested to see how the the generalization bound introduced in this paper is related to the recent theoretical works [3],[4] on MDL."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A5 Zhao et al. [3] consider the multiple source context; they define a weighted scheme where the weight of a source depends on its H-divergence with the target, plus its own classification error.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The feature extractor is trained either from the best source only (in the sense of this weight), or from a weighted sum of the sources.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: When interested in multi-domain learning (thus aiming to minimize the average risk), it seems that there are two possibilities: a single feature extractor; or a feature extractor per domain.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In the former case, the feature extractor might be overly conservative; in both cases, scalability w.r.t. the number of domains might be an issue.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Hoffman et al. [4] also consider the multiple source context, assuming that the target is a unknown mixture of the sources (or not too far thereof in terms of Renyi divergence).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Their experiments follow this assumption (using as target a mixture of sources Amazon, Webcam and DSLR).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In our case this assumption does not hold, e.g. the joint distribution of England(x,y) is *not* a mixture of Texas(x,y) and California(x,y) (as can be seen by eye, and confirmed by experiments).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The adversarial change of representation only enforces the merge of the marginals.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q6 "The authors propose to rank the unlabeled samples of each domain according to the entropy of their classification of the current classifier. Obviously there must be some false ranking (specially at the initial stages of updating the classifier) for the unlabeled samples"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A6
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: As the reviewer suggests, there are indeed misclassifications of samples using their entropy ranking in early training stages.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We mention this section 4.3.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This misclassification is the reason why it is better that hyper-parameter p slightly underestimates p* than is equal to it, as can be seen in Fig. 1, right (except when p*=1 as one could expect).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q7
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: "Since each domain may have different number of classes, it is not clear how the number of classes (L) is set in the classification module (maximum number of classes in all domain?)."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A7 L is the cardinal of the union of classes with labeled examples in at least one domain.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for your thoughtful feedback!
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: As correctly observed by the reviewer, Arora et. al. 2015 suffers from a bias in estimation both in the analysis and in the empirical evaluations.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The source of this bias term is an irreducible error in the coefficient estimate (formed using the hard-thresholding step).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: NOODL overcomes this issue by introducing a iterative hard-thresholding (IHT)-based coefficient update step, which removes the dependence of the error in estimated coefficient on this irreducible error, and ultimately the dictionary estimate.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Intuitively, this approach highlights the symbiotic relationship between the two unknown factors — the dictionary and the coefficients.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In other words, to make progress on one, it is imperative to make progress on the other.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: To this end, in Theorem 1 we first show that the coefficient error only depends on the dictionary error (given an appropriate number of IHT iterations R), i.e. we remove the dependence on x_0 which is the source of bias in Arora et. al. 2015.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have added the intuition corresponding to this in the revised paper after the statement of Theorem 1 in Section 3.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Analysis of Computational Time — We have added the average per iteration time taken by various algorithms considered in our analysis in Table~4 and Appendix E.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: The primary takeaway is that although NOODL takes marginally more time per iteration as compared to other methods when accounting for just one (Lasso-based) sparse recovery for coefficient update, it (a) is in fact faster per iteration since it does not involve any computationally expensive tuning procedure to scan across regularization parameters; owing to its geometric convergence property (b) achieves orders of magnitude superior error at convergence, and as a result, (c) overall takes significantly less time to reach such a solution; see Appendix E for details.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We would like to add that since NOODL involves simple separable update steps, this computation time can be further lowered by distributing the processing of individual samples across cores of a GPU (e.g. via TensorFlow) by utilizing the architecture shown in Fig. 1.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We plan to release all the relevant code as a package in the future.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: In this revision, we have added comparison to Mairal '09, a popular online DL algorithm.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: Further, we have also added a proof map, in addition to the Table 3, for easier navigation of the results.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: We would like to thank the reviewer for providing valuable and detailed feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We have addressed the clarity concerns in the updated paper.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Figure captions, metrics used in the table, etc, as mentioned in the presentation section of the review have been carefully examined and updated in the paper.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We will reorganize the experiment section to better present the comparisons under different experimental settings.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: (1) Factorized Latent Variables:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The factorization of latent space with respect to the modalities provides a way to differentiate observed and unobserved modalities.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Therefore, VSAE is capable of handling partially-observed data where the missing modalities can be arbitrary.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In addition, the embeddings are intuitively more meaningful as input to unimodal encoders is now limited to only observed modalities, eliminating the effect of missing modalities.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: When performing imputation/generation, however, we want to capture the dependencies between modalities.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In other words, unobserved modalities should be imputed based on the information extracted from observed modalities.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: For experiments, we design this by conditioning decoders on all latent variables, essentially accessing information from all observed modalities.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This is not in contradiction to the factorized latent variable assumption.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Instead, the encoders try to embed each modalities individually, while decoders learn the dependencies between different modalities.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: (2) Multimodal Experiments:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We apologize for unclear description of experimental settings.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: In general, we believe multi-modal data is more general than conventional image-text or video-text pairs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: By unifying tabular data also as multi-modal (with each attribute as one modality), we show that VSAE provides us a principled way for imputation, capable of generalizing to more data families.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Specifically, we conducted experiments on two types of data:
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (1) low-dimensional tabular data, and (2) high-dimensional data (pixel or text) as "multimodal" to better define the overall task of learning from partially-observed data.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Upon request, we have included more extensive experiments following [1] on MNIST/FashionMNIST, and [2] on CMU-MOSI/ICT-MMMO.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Results are reported in Table 10 and Table 11 (Appendix C.5).
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: As shown, VSAE consistently outperforms baseline models across the added experiments as well.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (3) Discussions on Comparison with Upper Bound Methods:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Models trained with fully-observed data in theory should have better performance, thus we treat them as upper bound methods.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, it is very interesting to observe that in some cases, VSAE have superior performances.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: One possible explanation is that missing modalities introduces extra noise into the model as regularizer, thereby, increasing the generalization ability.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, detailed experiments and more discussions need to be carried out to back up this explanation.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: [1] Wu et al. Multimodal Generative Models for Scalable Weakly-Supervised Learning, NeurIPS 2018.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [2] Tsai et al. Learning Factorized Multimodal Representation, ICLR 2019.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: Many thanks for the detailed review!
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Main comments:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1/ The DIP approach critically relies on regularization in order to make the method work (both by adding random noise in each optimization step to the input, as well as early stopping).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: As the first reviewer noted ``In fact, the DIP of Ulyanov et al. can hardly be considered "a model" (or a prior, for that matter), and instead should be considered "an algorithm", since it relies on the early stopping of a specific optimization algorithm''.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However we follow the reviewers' suggestion and made clear that the idea to use a deep network without learning as an image model is not new and rewrote the item to ``The network itself acts as a natural data model.  Not only does the network require no training (just as the DIP); it also does not critically rely on regularization, for example by early stopping (in contrast to the DIP).''
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Before that, in the introduction, in the original and revised version, we have a paragraph devoted to the DIP explaining that Ulyanov et al. introduced the idea of using a deep neural network without learning as an image model.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2/ Regarding the theoretical contribution: We fully agree that a limitation of the theorem is that it pertains to a one layered version of the decoder.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We are currently extending this to the multilayer case, but still have to address a technical difficulty in counting the number of different sign pattern matrices.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Regarding the assumptions: The proposition uses the assumption that k^2 log(n_0)  / n <= 1/32.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Here, the constant 1/32 is not optimal.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: k^2 is essentially the number of parameters of the model, and n is the output dimension.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The proposition is only interesting if k^2 log(n_0)  / n <= 1/20 even without this assumption (due to the right hand side of the lower bound) therefore this assumption is not restrictive.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The bound is applicable if the number of parameters, k^2 is smaller than a logarithmic term times the number of output parameters, i.e., it allows the number of parameters to scale almost linearly in the output dimension.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This is the regime in which the deep decoder operates throughout the paper.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We agree that many natural noise patterns have structure, and that those can be better approximated with deep models, and are thus more difficult to remove.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3/ We have added the sentence ``In the default architectures with $d=6$ and $k=64$ or $k=128$, we have that N = 25,536 (for k=64) and N = 100,224 (k=128)
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: out of an RGB image space of dimensionality 512\times512\times3=786,432 parameters.'' to specify the number of parameters.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Thanks for the suggestion to try second order method like LBFGS; we have tried LBFGS as a response to the reviewer's comment.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: It converges in significantly fewer iterations, but each iterations is so much more expensive that overall it optimizes slower than ADAM or gradient descent.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Minor comments:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1/ Figure 4: We have added labels and the sentence ``Early stopping can mildly enhance the performance of DD; to see this note that in panel (a), the minimum is obtained at around 5000 iterations and not at 50,000.'' in the caption to clarify.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Also, we have added the sentence ``Models are fitted independently for the noisy image, the noiseless image, and the noise.'', and rewrote the paragraph
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thanks for pointing this out!
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We agree that here we present only results for one image, but we did carry out simulations for many images, and those plots are qualitatively the same for all the images considered.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thus our conclusions about the model do not only hold for one image.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 2/ Normalization is applied channel wise.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Let z{ij} be the j-th column in the i-th layer.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Then z{ij} is normalized independently of any of the other channels.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3/ We have reworded the corresponding paragraphs to make clear that while we do not use convolutions, and thus this is not strictly speaking a convolutional neural network, it shares many structural similarities with a conventional neural network, as pointed out by the reviewer.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 4/ The equation is correct in that the parameter choices in the paper are such that the deep decoder has much fewer model parameters N than its output dimension. Thus N is much less than n.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: 5/ We agree that it is not optimal to use unintroduced notation at this point, but we made this compromise so that we can illustrate the performance of the deep decoder without introducing its details, but wanted to give a reader the chance to later see exactly what parameters we used.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: 6/ Unfortunately choosing k=6 is too small to have a small representation error, i.e., to represent the image well.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: We have, however not hand-selected the 8 images shown out of the 64, and the other 64-8 images look very similar.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: We have all the images in the jupyter notebook that comes with the paper.

sentence: 7/ Great question, it is faster to optimize the deep decoder since the adam/SGD steps are cheaper, but it indeed seems to require slightly more iterations for best performance than the DIP.

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the comments and suggestions.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: As the reviewer points out, the community currently lacks a strong theoretical understanding of minmax optimization, and we believe our work helps to fill this gap.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We comment on the practical implications of our work below:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1) While the exact form of the sufficiently bilinear condition may be somewhat unwieldy, the result gives concrete evidence that having higher bilinearity can aid convergence for certain algorithms, even for settings that are not purely bilinear.
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: This indicates that one should pay attention to the magnitude and condition number of the off-diagonal of the Jacobian when constructing a min-max problem and choosing an algorithm to solve the problem.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2) In non-convex-concave settings, HGD will converge to all types of stationary points, as the reviewer points out.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We propose some modifications to HGD to allow it to work in non-convex settings in Appendix A, which essentially amount to explicitly determining the local curvature of the problem and running a modified algorithm, such as Hamiltonian Gradient Ascent, near undesirable critical points.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This would allow us to show similar local convergence guarantees to those proven by other works in the area (see Appendix A).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, as the reviewer points out as well, the HGD analysis is also useful because it implies similar convergence results for CO, which is a practical algorithm.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3) Our result for CO shows that as long as $\gamma \ge 4L_g/\alpha$, then CO will converge in sufficiently bilinear settings (currently it’s written as $\gamma = 4L_g/\alpha$ but we will change this in the final version).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This indicates that increasing $\gamma$ may speed up convergence when we are in a sufficiently bilinear region (and in particular, the algorithm may not converge if $\gamma$ is too small and the region has a very large bilinear term).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: If $\gamma$ is too large, CO will converge to stationary points that are not local min-maxes, so these two phenomena must be traded off.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: One could potentially detect which regime one is in by computing a few eigenvalues of the Jacobian (using a logarithmic number of Hessian-vector products) during or after training.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Other comments:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -We thank the reviewer for pointing out Azizian et al. 2019.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: This work was released concurrently to ours on Arxiv and indeed seems to have some similar findings.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We will include a reference to it in our revised version.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: References:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Azizian, Waïss, et al. "A Tight and Unified Analysis of Extragradient for a Whole Spectrum of Differentiable Games." arXiv preprint arXiv:1906.05945 (2019).
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their helpful comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Please could the reviewer clarify why they felt our work muddies the debate regarding large-batch training?
label: rebuttal_followup

sentence: We demonstrate that one can initially increase the batch size with no loss in test accuracy by simultaneously increasing the learning rate.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: However for very large batch sizes the test accuracy degrades under both constant epoch and constant step budgets.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We agree that some of our observations under constant epoch budgets in sections 2 and 3 have been made in previous work.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: However there are also several important differences:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Our paper is the first to relate the two regimes of SGD to the popular analogy between SGD and stochastic differential equations (SDEs).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: As we show in sections 4 and 5, this perspective is crucial to understanding the influence of batch size and learning rate on test accuracy.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: A common criticism of this analogy is that SGD noise is not Gaussian when the batch size is small.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: To our knowledge, we are the first to show that the analogy between SGD and SDEs holds for non-Gaussian short-tailed noise (appendix B).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: 2. Zhang et al. argued that Momentum only helps in the large batch limit.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: However, their analysis is based on the noisy quadratic model, which cannot explain the results we observed on the test set in sections 4 and 5.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: These experiments clearly demonstrate that, unlike the SDE perspective, the noisy quadratic model is not an appropriate model for predicting test set performance in deep learning.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Their work also does not clarify the assumptions under which linear scaling of the learning rate should arise.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: 3. Our empirical results in section 3 are similar to Shallue et al., however their work argues that there is no reliable relationship between learning rate and batch size.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We draw a very different conclusion: the learning rate usually obeys linear scaling, but linear scaling only holds theoretically when the assumptions we specify are satisfied.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Linear scaling may not hold in cases where these assumptions break down (e.g., language modelling).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: 4. The observation that the test accuracy is independent of batch size in the noise dominated regime is a natural consequence of the SDE analogy, since any two training runs which integrate the same SDE should sample final parameters from the same probability distribution.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We will clarify this in the updated text.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Two reviewers complained that it was difficult to tell from the text which contributions are novel and which also appear in previous works.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We apologise for this.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: It was not our intention and we will edit sections 1 and 2 to ensure that this is resolved and that the above points are reflected in the text.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Turning to our generalization experiments in sections 4 and 5.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: It is true that a number of papers in recent years have claimed that SGD noise enhances generalization.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: However Shallue et al. recently argued no previous work had provided convincing empirical evidence for this claim.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Indeed in their abstract, they state ‘We find no evidence that larger batch sizes degrade out-of-sample performance’.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In another recent paper, Zhang et al. argued that optimization in deep learning is well described by a noisy quadratic model which predicts that increasing the batch size should always enhance performance under constant step budgets.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Crucially, to establish that SGD noise enhances generalization, one must show that small batch sizes generalize better than large batch sizes under constant step budgets, with realistic learning rate decay schedules, and one must independently tune the learning rate at each batch size.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In section 4, we are the first authors to perform this experiment and confirm that the final test accuracy of SGD does degrade for very large batch sizes under both constant epoch and constant step budgets, contradicting the claims of both Shallue et al and Zhang et al.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Furthermore, we show in section 5 that the optimal SGD temperature which maximizes the test accuracy is almost independent of the epoch budget.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: These results provide the first convincing empirical evidence that SGD noise does enhance generalization in well-tuned networks with learning rate decay schedules.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We believe this is an important contribution.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We thank reviewer 1 for the detailed feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: In this response, we clarify the accuracy-realism trade-off, revise the accuracy metrics, indicate reruns and new experiments, and address the individual questions.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We updated Section 4.4 to indicate that it is to be expected that, although our SAVP model improves on diversity and realism, it also performs worse in accuracy compared to pure VAE models (both our own ablation and SVG).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: A recent result [1] proves that there is a fundamental tradeoff between accuracy and realism, for all problems with inherent ambiguity.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In fact, a recent challenge held at ECCV 2018 in such a problem [2] evaluates all algorithms on both of these axes, as neither adequately captures performance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Although the SVG generator is simpler than ours, ours is just a simple variation from Ebert et al. (2017).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Since proposing a strong generator architecture is not the goal of this paper,
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: any video generator (including the one from Denton & Fergus (2018)) could be used with our losses.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We added this clarification to Section 3.4.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Instead, we provide a systematic analysis of the effect of the loss function on this task (which could be applied to any generator).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: It's also worth noting that with a simpler feed-forward posterior and a unit Gaussian prior, our VAE ablation and SVG achieve similar performance on various metrics.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We added Section 3.5 to point out the differences between the VAE component of our model and prior work.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We have included a revised plot in Figure 14 (note that this temporary plot will be incorporated into Figure 6), where we use the official implementation of SSIM and replace the VGG metric with the LPIPS metric (Zhang et al., 2018).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: LPIPS linearly calibrates AlexNet feature space to better match human perceptual similarity judgements.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Aside for the first two predicted frames, our VAE ablation and the SVG model both achieve similar SSIM and LPIPS.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: After examining the KTH results further, we realized that our results are likely weaker than they should have been, because we did not use the same preprocessing as prior work.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The experiments from our original submission cropped the videos into a square before resizing, and thus discarded information from the sides of the video.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We are currently rerunning the KTH experiments and we plan to update the results in the paper.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We also didn't choose particular hyperparameters to ensure diversity for our models, and we expect some improvement in diversity in the new sets of experiments.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Although the combination of VAEs and GANs have been explored recently for conditional image generation (Zhang et al. 2018), the video prediction task is substantially different, with unique challenges, due to spatiotemporal relationships and inherent compounding uncertainty of the future.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Furthermore, while the individual components have indeed been known for video prediction, their combination is novel and not present in prior work, and we demonstrate that this produces state-of-the-art results in terms of diversity and realism.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In addition, this work provides a detailed comparison of the effect of the losses on the various metrics.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Furthermore, we are currently running experiments for various weightings of the KL loss and the adversarial loss, and we plan to include additional results that illustrate the trade-offs based on these hyperparameters.

sentence: Although MoCoGAN performs well for videos with a single frame-centered actor, it struggles with multiple simultaneously moving entities.

sentence: The authors of MoCoGAN also mentioned in personal correspondence that the conditional version (i.e. video prediction) was significantly harder to train.

sentence: We noticed the same in earlier iterations of our model.

sentence: In our case, we found that the model would degenerate to static videos or videos with a cyclic flickering artifact, which are issues that aren't a problem in conditional image generation.

sentence: We added details to Section 3.4 describing the importance of a few components, such as spectral normalization and not conditioning the discriminator in the ground-truth context frames.

sentence: The purpose of adding adversarial losses to a pure VAE is to improve on blurry predictions where the latent variables alone cannot capture the uncertainty of the data.

sentence: However, that is typically not the case of synthetic datasets.

sentence: In early experiments, we trained our pure VAE model on the stochastic shape movement dataset from Babaeizadeh et al. (2018), and our pure VAE was able to model the dataset without any blur and with perfect separation of the possible futures.

sentence: We agree that plausibility is indeed important, and that's what our human subject studies try to capture.

sentence: Unlike the VAE models that implausibly erase the small objects that are being pushed in the BAIR dataset, our SAVP model moves those objects in a more plausible way.

sentence: 1) Difference from parameter noise except for memory consumption:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: As stated in Section 3.3, we believe NADPEx is a generalization of parameter noise, with not only flexible memory consumption but also lower variance in gradients.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: This theory is examined in Section 4.2, where NADPEx shows faster convergence and lower variance in performance with different random seeds.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Besides, comparing with [1], our work provides a theoretical modeling for the idea "a hierarchy of stochasticity for exploration".
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We model the NADPEx policy as a joint distribution of dropout random variables and actions, such that it could be combined seamlessly with existing on-policy policy gradient methods.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: One example is the policy space constraint stated in Section 3.2.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We also provide another distribution i.e. Bernoulli distribution for stochasticity at high level, for which we derive gradient alignment and policy space constraint, as well as empirical results.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: As a minor point, in [1], the stochasticity at the high level i.e. the variance of parameter noise, is adjusted in a heuristic manner.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: NADPEx, in contrast, aligns the stochasticity throughout the hierarchy with end-to-end gradient update.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 2) Other good side effects:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The robustness of the NADPEx policy is orthogonal to our current work, but will be an interesting direction for the future.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Currently we only have some preliminary results.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: For example, it is more robust to adversarial neural attacks.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In the future we will investigate how robust NADPEx policies could be when the environment is perturbed, e.g. agents are dragged slightly by humans as in [2, 3].
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: That temporally consistent exploration is fairly important for physical robots is one of our motivations for this whole project.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In the next step we will look for simulator environments with more authentic actuators to see how NADPEx could help solve that.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Our ultimate goal is to find a safer and more efficient way for on-policy exploration on physical robots.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We believe the application of NADPEx to off-policy exploration is straightforward.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, as stated in Section 1, off-policy methods benefit from stronger flexibility for experience sampler.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: This makes the gradient alignment and policy space constraint not as important as in the on-policy methods.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: As off-policy methods have the potential to be much more data-efficient, we will compare in the future how NADPEx performs comparing with auto-correlated noise in [4] and separate sampler in [5].
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: “The paper makes use of a result from the David MacKay textbook which defines the capacity of a single layer network to memorize the labelling of $n$ inputs in $d$-dimensional space. [...] It would be great if the paper also made some attempt to consider these connections. Or at least comment on how these factors could be incorporated into a more sophisticated analysis of the capacity of a network.”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that our analysis of capacity in section 3 does not take into account the magnitude of the weights, nor the dependence on the depth of the network.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Our objective in this section was to provide a empirical lower-bound on the capacity by designing a setup where we can vary the quantity of information contained in a dataset (in our case, N choose n), and evaluate empirically the effect of data augmentation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In relation to section 5, we aim at seeing how much a network can remember if it is explicitly trained to remember a given set of images.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We understand the limitations of MacKay's analysis, which was presented to give a rough theoretical comparison point to our empirical evaluation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We will clarify this in the paper and improve the discussion along the lines discussed by the reviewer.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: “There is a slight oxymoron in the premise of the first set of experiments.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The network is forced to memorize a set of positive examples relative to the negative set it sees during training. What is memorized I presume depends a lot on the negative set used for training (its diversity, closeness to the positive set and how frequently each negative example is seen during training).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: [...] Is there a training task which would allow one to more explicitly memorize the image (some sort of reconstruction task) as opposed to an in/out classification task?”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In these experiments, the set of positive and negatives is fixed (when varying data augmentation and architectures).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: During training, we feed to the network all positives and an equal number of negatives during each epoch.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The performance does indeed depend on the closeness of the positive and the negatives, but this is similar to the membership inference problem presented in section 5, where it is difficult for a network to tell apart a seen image from an unseen, very similar image.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A reconstruction task would suffer the same problems: the reconstruction is only approximate so we would need to evaluate the distance between our reconstruction, positives and negatives, which also depends on the closeness between positives and negatives.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Also, the reconstruction task would need to remember the values of all pixels which requires more capacity.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We agree that this specific deserves a short discussion and will add it to the paper.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: “This paper is a slightly difficult read [...] because there is not one main coherent argument or goal for the paper.[...]. Yes the different sections are related but it is does not feel like they build upon each other to help form a clearer picture of memorization within neural networks.”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The general goal of the paper is to empirically assess memorization in neural networks, and in particular the important question of implicit memorization, which is important for privacy: does a network trained for classification remember an image, or a set of images ?
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This aspect is empirically evaluated in sections 4 and 5, and section 3 is a preliminary study of the memorization capabilities for systems explicitly trained to memorize (this serves as a qualitative upper-bound for implicit memorization).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We acknowledge that Section 3, which is a preliminary analysis, may confuse the reader in the first place.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We decided to move it to an appendix after reading the feedback from the three reviewers.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: “The conclusions focus on the importance of section 3 and the results of the experiments performed. Do the conclusions accurately reflect the opinions of the author?”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We do not consider the conclusions of the experiments from Section 3  to be more important than those of the other sections, in fact quite the opposite.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: As mentioned above, we will move it to appendices.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: “[...]In section 3 is a perturbed positive image considered a positive training image? And in the testing phase are only unperturbed versions of the positive images given to the ConvNet as input?”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: When data augmentation is used, we consider that perturbed positive images are also positive images.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In the testing phase, perturbed versions of the positive images are given to the ConvNet.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: “Last paragraph page 4: "when the accuracy gets over 60\% and at 90\%". Is this training or validation accuracy?”

sentence: We decrease the learning rate when the training accuracy reaches these thresholds.

sentence: Our responses for all your questions are provided below. Our major revisions in the new draft are colored by red.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Q1. Comparison with [1, 2, 3, 4].
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The main difference between our method and [1, 2] is that we do not directly train the Gaussian mixture model, i.e., generative classifier but we post-process it on hidden feature spaces of pre-trained deep models.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In addition, we study a robust inference method to handle noisy labels in training samples, while they did not.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Next, [3,4] also assume clean training labels, and aim for detecting abnormal test samples after ’clean’ training.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Therefore, a comparison with [1, 2, 3, 4] is not straightforward as our goal is different.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We clarified this in Section 2.1 of the revised draft.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Q2. Computational cost.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: As you expect, estimating the parameters of LDA is very cheap compared to training original deep models like ResNet and DenseNet, since it requires only one forward pass to extract the hidden features.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q3. Version of backward/forward losses.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: As mentioned in Appendix B of the previous draft, we use the estimated noise transition matrices for backward/forward losses.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We clarified more details of experimental setups in Appendix B of the revised draft.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Q4. Updated abstract and performance evaluation.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: As AnonReviewer 3 mentioned, our main contribution is developing a new inference method which can be used under any pre-trained deep model.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In other words, our goal is not outperforming the performance of prior training methods and complementary to them, i.e., our inference method can improve the performance of any prior training methods (see our common response to all reviewers).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Nevertheless, we agree with your comments that it is more meaningful to emphasize our improvement over the state-of-the-art training methods.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: In the abstract of the revised draft, we report our improvement over Co-teaching [5] which is the most recent and state-of-the-art training method.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Q5. Evaluation on adversarial attacks.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In the revised draft, we also consider optimization-based adaptive attacks against our method under the black-box setup (see Table 5) and the white-box setup (see Table 10).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: In both setups, our inference method is shown to be more robust compared to the softmax inference.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We further show that our method further improves the robustness of deep models optimized by adversarial training (see Table 6 and 11).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Such experimental results support our claim that the proposed generative classifier can improve the robustness against adversarial attacks as it utilizes multiple hidden features (i.e., harder to attack all of them).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We very much appreciate your valuable comments again.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Following your suggestion, we evaluated the Byzantine settings Multi-Krum (Blanchard et al 2017) and Bulyan (El Mhamdi et al 2018 ICML).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: For both DBA and centralized attack we use the aggregation rule that can tolerate f Byzantine workers among n workers
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (Blanchard et al 2017)
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: For centralized attack there is 1 attacker and n-1 non-Byzantine workers.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: For DBA there are f distributed attackers and n-f non-Byzantine workers.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The total number of poisoned pixel amounts are kept the same.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 1. Multi-Krum
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - To meet the assumption that 2f + 2 < n, we set  (n=10, f=3) for loan and (n=12, f=4) for image datasets.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The Multi-Krum parameter m is set to m=n-f.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: For Tiny-imagenet we decrease the poison ratio to 5/64 for both attacks.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Other parameters are the same as described in the paper.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: - For CIFAR and Tiny-imagenet, we find that DBA is more effective.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: - For LOAN and MNIST, both attacks don’t behave well.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We believe the reason can be explained by the fact that Loan and MNIST are simpler tasks and benign clients quickly agree on the correct gradient direction, so malicious updates are more difficult to succeed.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 2. Bulyan
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - We use Bulyan
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: based on the Byzantine–resilient aggregation rule Krum
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: To meet the assumption that 4f + 3 <= n, we set  (n=15, f=3) for loan and (n=20, f=4) for image datasets.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: - For CIFAR, DBA is more effective.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: - For other datasets, both attacks fail.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: However, we note that our distributed and centralized backdoor attacks are not optimized for Byzantine setting.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We believe it’s worthwhile to explore the distributed version of other new attack algorithms, e.g. A Little Is Enough (Baruch et al 2019) that manipulates its update to mitigate Krum and Bulyan defenses.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In summary, Multi-Krum and Bulyan have stricter assumptions on the proportion of attackers than RFA and FoolsGold.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In addition, while RFA and FoolsGold still assign potential outliers with extreme low weights, Krum (Multi-Krum, Krum-based Bulyan) directly removes them, making it impossible to inject backdoors if the malicious updates are obviously far from the benign updates.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The centralized attack for four datasets totally fails under Multi-Krum and Bulyan while DBA can still succeed in some cases.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We have included these results in Appendix A.6 of the revised version.

sentence: 1- The idea of using concepts to represent a problem is simple, but using it along with neural network based embedding gives us the opportunity to gain concept continuity as discussed on the last paragraph on page 7 and table 2, which is an active field of research in education.
