label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We will make this assumption explicit in the revised manuscript.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: From this perspective (and other reasons mentioned in the discussion section), MAD should be viewed as complementary to, rather than a replacement for, the conventional accuracy comparison for image classification.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: When two classifiers perform at a reasonable level and achieve very close accuracy numbers (e.g., VGG16BN and ResNet34 on ImageNet validation set), MAD provides the most efficient way of differentiating the two models by maximizing their discrepancies over a large-scale image set.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We want to emphasize that MAD is especially useful on image classification tasks where most cutting-edge classifiers achieve very close performance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In these situations, the MAD competition ranking, which is obtained by evaluating on corner examples searched from web-scale unlabeled dataset, is more convincing than something like 1% accuracy advantage on the validation set.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For problem domains where there are few sufficiently accurate models, we may still apply the underlying principle behind MAD to create adaptive test sets such that the strengths and weaknesses of the models are most easily revealed.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In those scenarios, we conjecture that we need increase k to a reasonably larger number, thus at the cost of efficiency.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Regarding comment 2: Thanks for the comment.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: As long as two (or multiple) models differ (even in slightly different ways), MAD provides the highly efficient way of spotting such differences by exploring a large-scale unlabelled dataset.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: However, these differences are less likely to be revealed using a fixed and small test set (i.e., they will probably have the same accuracy numbers as models to be compared are very similar and are biased in similar ways).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: For the extreme case that two models are exactly the same (i.e, they are biased in identical ways and make identical prediction errors), both MAD and traditional accuracy-based methods will draw the same conclusion - the two models have the same performance.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Accuracy-based evaluation methods arrive at this conclusion by comparing model predictions with ground truth labels and outputting the same accuracy numbers.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In contrast, MAD arrives at the same conclusion without any human labeling since the set S for subjective testing is empty.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: So in this extreme case, both MAD and accuracy fail to compare those two models.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In summary, to reliably compare the relative performance of computational models, all evaluation methodologies (including MAD) rely on the assumption that the models to be compared should be diverse to a certain extent, and the proposed MAD makes this assumption more explicit.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In fact, MAD makes the best use of model discrepancies (even if models are biased in very similar but not identical ways) to rank the model performance.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: As a matter of fact, based on our experiments, we find that state-of-the-art ImageNet classifiers do have their own biases. (See figure 8 in the appendix.)
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Regarding comment 3: Thanks for the excellent question.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We believe that the parameter k is task-dependent.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For problem domains where there are reasonably accurate models (e.g., imageNet classification in our example), we may obtain a stable ranking with a relative small k (e.g., k=15 in the imageNet classification example).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For problem domains where there are no good models, we may increase k to the limit of human labeling budget in order to obtain reasonable performance comparison.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Regarding comment 4: Thanks for the comment.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: In our current setting, we restrict the dataset D to the domain of interest that contain natural images of mainly 200 classes.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, as the construction of D is noisy and coarse, D contains plenty of open-set images, which do not belong to any class of interest.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Since we do not perform any manually data screening at this stage, some of the open-set images may even be selected to construct the dataset S.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This means that although the selected open-set image is out of the domain of interest, the associated two classifiers make different, high-confident (with threshold set to 0.8), but incorrect predictions (Case III).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: As a result, we consider it as a strong counterexample of the two classifiers.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Note that this situation rarely happens, at least in our experiments because the competing classifiers tend to give open-set images low-confidence, and therefore are automatically filtered out.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that selecting images that contain only one salient object requires a lot of human effort.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: So we did not eliminate Case I. It turns out that keeping Case I does not seem to affect the comparison and analysis of competing models.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We thank the reviewer for a detailed review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that a uniqueness result based on the axioms is desirable, but we don’t have it.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: While we’re able to show that the paths at the input and at the hidden layer must be coupled (i.e. non-oblivious), we just don’t understand the space of non-oblivious methods that well.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Mathematically, we don’t have a handle on how the path at the hidden layer can vary as the network below the hidden layer is changed.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Partition consistency is the only axiom about the network below the hidden layer, but it is not applicable to all networks.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We probably need another axiom to prove uniqueness.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Another key observation made by the reviewer is the interpretability vs importance of neurons.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: While those are not the same, we demonstrate that conductance can give us some insights about the network (Sections 5.1 and 6.1).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the valuable feedback! We reply to the answers and comments in the order they were raised.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Note, that regarding the methodology there were some misunderstandings (which we try to avoid for future readers in the revised version).
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: (1) The equations are indeed very related.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Note however, that In a standard Bayesian neural network (BNN), one would assume that \theta is a global random variable (i.e. does not depend on input x), whereas in the CDN, we assume that \theta depends on x and is thus a local random variable.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Furthermore, in a Bayesian setting p(theta|...) would play the role of a approximate posterior, which would require variational inference (VI), and thus a different objective,  to estimate it.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (2) In Equation (4) we followed with  p(D | \psi) a standard notation for \sum_n p(y_n | x_n; \psi) (i.e. summation of Equation (3) wrt all data in D) which also can be found e.g. in the work of Graves (2011) [4] and Blundell et al. (2015) [5].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The objective we introduce for CDNs differs from the ELBO-based objective in VI in the way the logarithm is placed in the first term of the objective: in the ELBO we have a logarithm inside the expectation, while the logarithm is outside the expectation in the CDN objective (note however, that the sample-based approximations get equivalent if only one sample is used).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Furthermore, in the ELBO we have a fixed value of \lambda = 1.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We added a new Section 4 in the revised version of the paper discussing these differences.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Moreover, we investigated the impact of the different objectives empirically and found that the CDN-based objective led to significantly better results, as shown in the newly added Section 6.4 in the revised manuscript.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: (3) Indeed we need the probabilistic version of hypernetworks to implement the model we described in Equation (3).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We just wanted to point out that this is in contrast to the vanilla  hypernetworks proposed by Ha et al. (2016) [1] and Jia et al.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: (2016) [2] which would produce a point estimate for \theta.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: (4) We used a matrix-variate normal (MVN) to reduce the parameters of the model.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Using a diagonal MVN for X \in R^{p x q} one needs pq+p+q parameters.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In contrast a fully-factorized diagonal Gaussian needs pq+pq.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: But you are right, we could easily extend our approach to account for more flexible distributions by using a "diagonal plus rank-one" structure diag(a)+uu^T, with vectors a and u, as noted by Louizos and Welling ( 2016) [3] (the increase of parameters is negligible: adding additional vector u).
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We will investigate the benefits of more flexible mixing distributions in future work.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: (5) Thanks for this valuable comment!
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We have revised the toy experiments to include a heteroscedastic regression task (see Section 6.1.).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: It shows that CDNs are able to quantify the heteroscedastic aleatoric uncertainty.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, we kept the OOD experiments on MNIST and notMNIST in the paper as well, since we consider it as very interesting that the CDN, while being designed for modelling aleatoric uncertainty, is very competitive on this task.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Moreover, we investigate the mixing distribution learned in Appendix G.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (6) Of course, you are right! Previously we showed the test accuracy in Appendix F.  To make it more directly accessible, we have now added the test accuracy achieved by the different models into the legends of the plots, showing that CDN achieves similar predictive power as the baselines.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We now present the validation accuracy instead in Appendix F.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: (7) Sorry, for this unfortunate formulation!
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We observed that generally as \lambda increases, the uncertainty is increasing, while the accuracy is decreasing.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Therefore a simple and effective heuristic for choosing \lambda is to look at the validation set of MNIST and choose the highest \lambda that still results in high accuracy (e.g. >. 0.97).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have made this procedure clear in the revised manuscript.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: P and G, the elements of the divergence D(P||G) that appears in the first paragraph of section 3, is defined in the subsequent two sentences in the same paragraph.

sentence: By the notation G_theta(u) \sim p(theta), we mean that we want to train the generator G_theta such that when fed a random variable u \sim p(u), the distribution of G_theta(u) matches that of p(theta).

sentence: 2. The training of G_theta is described in the subsection titled “Hierarchical Sampling”.

sentence: Using (4), we train G_x and Q networks.

sentence: After training G_x and Q, we use trained Q to collect inferred Q(X), for each point cloud X.

sentence: Then we train the generator G_theta using ordinary WGAN formulation to produce samples from same distribution as that of the samples Q(X) for each point cloud X. In addition to such two step training, a joint training also works, but is slower computationally, thus we report only the two step training in the paper.

sentence: 3. Quantitative evaluation of generative modeling performance is unfortunately very hard for real world problems like point clouds, which is the probable cause for it being missing from much of GAN literature.

sentence: We would like to thank Reviewer 1 for their review and constructive suggestions.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Our responses inline:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: >Can you elaborate more on why BatchNorm statistics are computed across all devices as opposed to per-device? Was this crucial for best performance?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -The primary reason is to ensure that training is invariant to the per-device batch size.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: When scaling from resolution 128x128 to 256x256, we increase the number of devices but maintain the same overall batch size, reducing the per-device batch size.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Cross-replica BatchNorm ensures that the smaller per-device batch size does not affect training.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Switching to per-device BatchNorm at 128x128 results in a performance drop, albeit not a crippling one: for a model which would otherwise get an IS of 92 and an FID of 9.5, switching to per-device BatchNorm results in an IS of 78 and FID of 13.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: >It is not clear if provided analysis for large-scale GANs apply for small-medium sized GANs.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Providing such analysis would be also helpful for the community.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -The goal of this work is to explore GANs at large scale; the exploration of small or medium scale models would indeed be interesting for another study.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Having said that, we do evaluate BigGAN on conditional CIFAR-10 (mentioned briefly in Appendix C.2) and obtain an IS of 9.22 and an FID of 14.73 without truncation, which to our knowledge are better than any published results.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: >How do you see the impact of the suggested techniques on tackling harder data-modalities for GANs, e.g. text or sequential data in general?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -Any of the proposed techniques could be applied to standard GANs for text or other sequential data in principle, but we have not experimented with these applications ourselves.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We thank the referee for finding our paper clearly written and in an interesting domain.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: 1. We are not training Restricted Boltzmann Machines (RBMs), but Boltzmann machines where the hidden units can be fully connected.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We have shown in our experiments (see Fig. 3) that using a single RBM as a pre-processor will not result in increased adversarial resistance.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: A comparison of mean field training vs. constrastive divergence for RBMs has been made by [III,IV].
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Nevertheless, we have added a comparison between our method and the exact solution for a small Boltzmann machine of 16 units in the appendix.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: While we don't claim that this explains the performance of the method under all circumstances, it gives an indication of how well it works.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We agree that a more thorough study of the training method would be desirable but in this article we are concentrating on reporting the results on increased adversarial resistance.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We believe that these results should be interesting to the community even if some doubts about the training procedure remain.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Lastly, we want to obtain a differentiable building block that can be used in standard neural nets.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The unrolling of the mean field iterations (see Fig. 1) provides a straightforward to achieve this.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Propagating a gradient through a sampling based building block, while possible, would be considerably harder.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 2. In [III,IV] the authors have succesfully used a mean field approximation beyond the trivial first order to train RBMs.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In [II] a first order approximation is used.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In our approach we use the approximation up to fourth order in the coupling J.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 3. The approach of the authors in [III,IV] and also our approach is based on free energy.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The systematic expansion of the free energy in the coupling constant forms the basis of our approach.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 4. D is calculated as the relative entropy over a batch of 10000 examples.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The reference probabilities are taken to be uniform and the model probabilities are calculated according to the procedure outlined in section 2.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Due to the approximations involved it is possible that the sum of the model probabilities exceeds one.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In this case we rescale the unclamped free energy to limit the total probability to one.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have added a note to that effect to the article.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 5. We have included a comparison to the, to our knowledge, currently most adversarially resistant model on MNIST.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Since our results are derived for MNIST we can only compare to methods in the literature that are evaluated on MNIST.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We acknowledge that other methods perform very well on more sophisticated tasks and have added a reference.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 6. While we have not explicitely labelled white box and black box attacks we are using a strong white box attack (gradient based) and the, to our knowledge, strongest black box attack (boundary method).

sentence: We have added the labels in the text and Table 1 to make this more clear.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 7. We have added some more attacks on the most robust model.

sentence: We completely agree that more experiments on other datasets are needed to show the universality of the method.

sentence: Due to the computational complexity this will need to remain a topic for a follow up article.

sentence: We thank our second reviewer for his comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We first refer to your main comments and then answer each point in part.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The work of Lakshminarayanan et al. indeed showed that deterministic ensembles can improve on the performance of MC-dropout techniques and provides a foundation for ours.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: And as Beluch et al. (2018) showed, this can be valuable in an active learning setting.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, our work differs in two major ways:
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: i) We focus on showing the uncertainty representation in these methods suffer from overconfident predictions and that combining the two methods into a stochastic ensemble can be of great benefit and improve on the quality of the uncertainty.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: ii) We believe the true novelty to be in applying them in an active learning setting, and in particular on a small dataset problem (i.e. the size of the final dataset acquired during AL is only a small fraction of the entire available unlabelled dataset).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: As you mentioned, data is notoriously scarce and deep learning methods rarely work on small dataset problems.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We thank the reviewer for pointing us to the work of Huand et al. Indeed this is an interesting method that would allow us to most likely achieve similar or better results with less computational overhead.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This is definitely something we will consider for future work, but it is somehow out of the main scope of the paper, which was to show the power of combining MC-dropout with ensembles in the active learning setting.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Taking into account more advanced ensemble methods is definitely of interest.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In terms of the Bayesian Optimization literature, this is definitely of interest if we are to focus on hyper-parameter tuning for our models, but we fail to see the connection of the work you mentioned to our active learning examples.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Our focus was not on fine-tuning our models.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: In relation to your specific points, we answer these below:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1) Gal has already showed in his PhD thesis that MC-Dropout almost always performs best in terms of prediction accuracy and uncertainty quality assessment when compared to alternative Bayesian neural network approaches such as Probabilistic Back Prop and other variants of stochastic gradient MCMC methods.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The aim of our paper was to improve upon MC-Dropout in the context of active learning, which would invariably translate into better performance w.r.t. other Bayesian NN approaches.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: 2) Beluch et al. (2018) showed that going beyond 3 networks in their deterministic ensemble method does not add any significant improvements in terms of performance.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Therefore, we used this number when benchmarking against their method.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3) The aim of the paper was to improve upon the state-of-the-art in active learning for the image classification task.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We specifically chose this task due to its relevance to the real world especially in the medical imaging industry.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We agree that a more comprehensive study could be done in order to asses the viability of our method for ML tasks other than image classification.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: As for other neural network architectures, we chose the one used in the benchmarked methods.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 4) Results are averaged over 5 multiple independent runs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We will include both this and confidence scores in a revised version of our paper.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We are grateful to the reviewer for the comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: In this revision, we have corrected the minor typos, added additional comparisons, and added a proof map for easier navigation of the results.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Specific comments are addressed below.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1. Regarding exact recovery guarantees — NOODL converges geometrically to the true factors.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Therefore, the error drops exponentially with iterations t. In other words, as t —> infinity A_i —> A^*_i for i in [1,m] and x_j —> x^*_j for j in [1,m], where x_j is in R^m.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have added this clarification in Section 1.1.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 2. On tuning parameters — There are primarily three tuning parameters, namely eta_x (step-size for the IHT step), tau (threshold for the IHT step), and eta_A (step-size for the dictionary update step.) Our main result prescribes the theoretical values of these as shown in assumptions A.5 and A.6.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Here, eta_x = Omega_tilde(k/sqrt(n)), tau = Omega_tilde(kˆ2/n), and eta_A = Theta(m/k).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have updated A.6. to include the order of these parameters.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: The specific choices of these parameters, like other similar problems, depend on some a priori unknown parameters (e.g. the sparsity k, and the incoherence mu) which makes some level of tuning unavoidable.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This is true for Arora '15 and Mairal '09, as well, where tuning is required for the choice of step-size for dictionary update, and for choice of regularization parameter and the step-size for coefficient estimation via FISTA.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Note that, in our experiments we fix the step-size for FISTA as 1/L, where L is the estimate of the Lipschitz constant (since A is not known exactly).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Alternately, since NOODL involves gradient-based updates for the coefficients and the dictionary, tuning (the step-sizes and the threshold) is relatively straightforward in practice, since it is based on a gradient descent strategy.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In fact, to compile the experiments presented in this paper, we fixed step-size, eta_x, and threshold, tau, and tuned the step-size parameter eta_A only (Theta(m/k)).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The choices of eta_A are 30 for k = 10,20 and eta_A = 15 for k =50,100, as shown in Fig.2.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: , eta_A mostly effects the convergence rate as long as it is chosen in Theta(m/k).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Also, as shown in Table 4 (Appendix E), the tuning process for l1-based algorithms (i.e. FISTA) takes more time, since one needs to scan over the range of the regularization parameter to find one that works.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This (a) adds to the computational time, and (b) since the dictionary is not known exactly, may guarantee recovery of coefficients only in terms of closeness in l2-norm sense, due to the error-in-variables (EIV) model for the dictionary.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In this sense, NOODL is (a) simple to tune, (b) assures guaranteed recovery of both factors, and (c) is fast due to its geometric convergence properties.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: These factors highlight its applicability in practical DL problems.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3. Definition of Hard Thresholding (HT) — As per the recommendation of the reviewer, we have repeated the definition of hard-thresholding (HT) initially presented in the "Notation" sub-section, in Section 2 for clarity.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 4. Comparison to other Online DL algorithms — As correctly observed by the reviewer, the overall structure of NOODL is similar to successful online DL algorithms.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: These successful algorithms (such as Mairal '09) leverage the progress made on both factors for convergence, however, do not guarantee recovery of the factors.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: On the other hand, the state-of-the-art provable DL algorithms focus on the progress made on only one of factors (the dictionary), and do not have good performance in practice, since they incur a non-negligible bias; see Section 5 and Appendix E.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: NOODL bridges the gap between these two.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In addition to our main theoretical result, which establishes conditions for exact recovery of both factors at a geometric rate, NOODL also has superior empirical performance, leading to a neurally-plausible practical online DL algorithm with strong guarantees; see Section 3 and 4.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our work also paves way for the development and analysis of related alternating optimization-based techniques.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: On reviewer's recommendation, we compare the performance of NOODL with one of the most popular alternating minimization-based online DL algorithm used in practice -- Mairal `09 -- in Fig. 2 and Table 4 (Appendix E).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: In this work, the authors show that alternating between a l1-based sparse approximation step and dictionary update based on block co-ordinate descent converges to a stationary point.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The other comparable techniques shown in Table 1, are not ``online’’ and/or require stringent initializations, in terms of closeness to the true dictionary, as compared to NOODL.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our experiments show that due to the geometric convergence to the true factors, NOODL outperforms competing state-of-the-art provable online DL techniques both in terms of overall computational time, and convergence performance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: These additional expositions further showcase the contributions of our work both on theoretical and practical online DL front.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We appreciate your constructive feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Specifically, your comments about our motivation and development of our idea greatly help us to improve the quality of our paper.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: If we correctly understand reviewer 2’s concerns, the concerns can be divided into two folds:
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: 1. Our suggestion to mitigate the catastrophic forgetting looks a naive combination of well-known concepts. Thus, it is more system engineering than science.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 2. Each component described in Figure 1 is not explained enough.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Also, there is no description of the complete task.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: [Response for 1]
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: As we explained at the common response, we started our research from clear open questions.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Our first open question was that why other GR-based algorithms [1, 2] assume unit Gaussian priors even though they integrate classification loss into their VAE formulation.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Since they do not consider the conflict between the unit Gaussian prior and discriminative loss for the latent variable z, their models generate ambiguous samples that negatively affect the performance of incremental learning, which is discussed in section 4.1 in our paper.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: This leads us to a more theoretical formulation for classification-regularized VAE.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: By introducing class conditional priors induced by the mutual information maximization, DiVA yields class-wise discriminative one mode Gaussians for latent variable z.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Naturally, DiVA can conduct both class prediction and class conditional sample generation with one integrated model.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: The second open question was that why GR-based algorithms suffer from serious catastrophic forgetting in natural image datasets, even though generated samples are not completely noisy.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We assumed that this is due to the vulnerability of neural networks [3] triggered by different distributions of pixel values between real and generated images.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Thus, we defined the two domains: real domain and sample domain.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: To narrowing the distribution gap, we needed a solution that satisfies two conditions (also described in section 5):
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: 1. We should translate only the style (a global pattern of a specific domain) as keeping outline patterns of given images.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: 2. We should consider an unpaired domain translation between real and generated images because the generated images are sampled randomly.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Fortunately, we were able to find an existing solution that satisfies the requirements: CycleGAN. Any other domain translators that satisfy the conditions can be used or newly studied.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: With the solution, we could make a breakthrough for GR-based methods.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: To the best of our knowledge, this is the first successful approach for a GR-based algorithm to start to resist the catastrophic forgetting problem with a natural image dataset.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: [Response for 2]
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Figure 1 is a conceptual description of our proposed model, DiVA.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Each component is explained in section 4, below Equation 2, and justified in section 4.1.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Also, for an easy understanding of the whole CL process with DiVA, we added another figure in Appendix E.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Proofs that the space "interpolates smoothly with curvature": we added formal proofs (see theorems 2 and 3) that all the operations are differentiable, i.e. the gradients are equal from both the left and right at 0, w.r.t. curvature, for the chosen models of hyperbolic and spherical geometry.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: k-addition definiteness in the spherical setting: we have added the formal condition that the k-addition be well-defined, and a proof that for two points this condition indeed recovers x != y / (k ||y||^2) - see Theorem 1.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Theorem 5 shows that our proposed left-matrix-multiplication is an intrinsic averaging for Riemannian manifolds of constant curvature, i.e. it does commute with isometries when the matrix A is right-stochastic, which is not the case of right-matrix-multiplication.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: This is a desirable property for Riemannian vector averaging.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Theorem 6 shows that weighted combinations in the tangent space used in the very recent works of [1,2] (appeared after ICLR submission deadline) is also an intrinsic averaging for Riemannian manifolds of constant sectional curvature, i.e. it does commute with isometries.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Dear Reviewer 2, thank you for your constructive feedback and for taking the time to review our work.

sentence: Your specific points are addressed below.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: > “The results are not strong. And, unfortunately, the model contribution currently is too modest.”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Indeed, the model is a minor contribution and, especially in light of a more thorough evaluation of RGCN, the sum attention RGAT results do not improve on those in Schlichtkrull et al. (2017).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, we would like to highlight that despite being a simple modification, the implementation of such a model that is trainable in a reasonable time frame is non-trivial.

sentence: We plan to make our implementation public to aid future research in the area.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: To generalise the model, following the recommendations in one of the comments, we have investigated applying the Transformer-style dot product attention that was presented in GaAN: Gated Attention Networks for Learning on Large and Spatiotemporal Graphs
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: (Zhang et al. 2018)
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We believe that this additional investigation, accompanied by marginally improved results on Tox21 for dot product attention (Mean test AUCs: WIRGAT 0.838 +/- 0.007, ARGAT 0.837 +/- 0.007) enhance model contributions of the paper.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We also consider the poor results on MUTAG to be significant and informative for the rest of the community in developing more powerful models that can be applied to relational graphs.

sentence: > “We should see the performance on other datasets  (e.g., some of the other datasets in Wu et al. (2018)”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We agree that including experiments on the other data sets presented in Wu et al. (2018) would be a valuable addition to the paper.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Unfortunately, we are unable to perform the required thorough hyperparameter exploration required to draw meaningful conclusions within the remaining time of the rebuttal period.

sentence: This is something we will investigate in the future.

sentence: > “My introduction suggestion: do not talk about Convolutional neural networks (CNNs).”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thank you for this stylistic critique.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We see how the approach taken did not provide an intuition about the problem as well as it could have.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We agree with your point regarding the wealth of graph neural network studies.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We feel that the field of geometric deep learning, from which part of the direction of this work originated, is important to keep as part of the development of graph-based machine learning models.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Some recent publications in the area of graph based ML have put less emphasis on geometric deep learning, the generalisations of convolutions from grids to graph, and the modifications of convolutions to achieve non-basis dependent methods.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We felt that it is important to keep these concepts associated with the field of graph based ML.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: This introduction could, however, talk less in detail about CNNs themselves, and deal more with graphs - the main focus of the paper.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We will produce a reworked introduction where graphs play a larger role.

sentence: This should provide a more intuitive introduction to our work, whilst maintaining cornerstone concepts.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Thanks for your careful review! As mentioned in the intro, we are trying to give some principled insight into benefits of BN, which has proved tricky.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Also, it is noted in the paper that BN probably has many desirable properties, of which auto-rate tuning is just one.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: (i) Speed of SGD vs GD:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Note that “time” here refers to number of iterations, not epochs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We are not aware of results establishing SGD is faster in this measure.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (As noted on p2,  we are working within the standard paradigm of convergence rates in optimization.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: The only new part is the automatic rate tuning  behavior shown for most parameters when BN is used.)
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: (ii) “usually training is stopped much before convergence, in the hope of finding solutions close to minimum with high probability.”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We’re assuming training proceeds until gradient is small (stationary point).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We are not aware of any prior analysis of speed of convergence that deviates from this assumption.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Perhaps the reviewer is thinking of early stopping in context of better generalization?
label: rebuttal_followup

sentence: (iii) “clarify difference from Wu et al. (2018)”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Wu et al. 2018 introduces a *new* algorithm inspired by weight normalization (WN) and studies its convergence rate to stationary point.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This algorithm can be seen as an explicit way to tune the learning rate (thus it is conceptually analogous Adagrad).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: They don't have any results about WN or BN itself.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Their analysis could be adapted to GD on one-neuron network with WN or BN without scale-variant parameters (gamma and beta).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Even this adaptation is not immediate because the goal of this work is to find a stationary point on the unit sphere rather than R^d.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Finally, they prove no results for SGD, whereas our paper does.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (iv) “single learning rate doesn’t apply for all parameters”
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Correct.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The algorithm can use a single learning rate for scale-invariant parameters but needs a tuned rate for the scale-variant ones.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In feedforward nets, the number of scale-variant parameters scales as the number of nodes and the number of scale-invariant parameters scales as the number of edges (up to weight sharing).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thus the vast majority of parameters are scale-invariant.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (v) “Relation between original loss and loss using BN.”
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our results hold for the loss of batch-normalized network (“BN-loss”)  which is different from the loss of the original network (“BN-less loss”).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Probably the reshaping of loss function due to BN is very important but currently hard to analyse theoretically because we lack a good mathematical understanding of the loss landscape (even BN-less).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Dear Reviewer:
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Thank you for your valuable comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We have addressed typos in the revision accordingly.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: And please find our response as follows.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -  Can you be more specific about the gains in training versus inference time?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We would like to emphasize that the our goal is to speed up the inference time for softmax, so we do not include any comparisons in terms of training time.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: According to our experiments, most speedup can be achieved in few epochs (given all other layers are pre-trained) so that the training time increase is not significant compared to the original one.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - You motivate some of the work by the fact that the experts have overlapping outputs. Maybe in section 3.7 you can address how often that occurs as well?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thanks for the suggestion.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We demonstrate that ambiguous words are often overlapped between clusters as illustrated in Figure 3(b).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We added one more Figure in Appendix B, Figure (b), to demonstrate the distribution of overlapping.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: - It wasn't clear how the sparsity percentage on page 3 was defined?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Sorry for the possible confusion.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: The sparsity in page 3 means the percentage of pruned words.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have added more clarifications in the revised version.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: - Can you motivate why you are not using perplexity in section 3.2?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We use top-k accuracy, instead of perplexity, because approximating top-k is required for most inference tasks in practice (see [1]).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Perplexity captures the normalized log-likelihood of all possible words, while top-k accuracy is a better measure for inference speedup for top-k retrieval.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For example, in some extreme cases, if a word only has a very small probability which makes it unpredictable at all (i.e. couldn’t be retrieved by top-k for any reasonably small k)
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: , it could still have a huge impact in terms of perplexity, but has a much smaller impact on top-k accuracy, which seems more reasonable given the goal of top-k retrieval.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: [1] Asymmetric LSH (ALSH) for Sublinear Time Maximum Inner Product Search (MIPS), NIPS 2014
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: We appreciate your constructive feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Specifically, your comments about the motivation and problem definitions greatly help us to improve the quality of our paper.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: (Importance and motivation)
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: To step forward to artificial general intelligence, we should further consider making an agent that can learn and remember many tasks incrementally [1].
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: However, this is particularly challenging in real-world settings: the agent may observe different tasks sequentially, and an individual task may not recur for a long time.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In this settings, a learned model might overfit to the most recently seen data, forgetting the rest, a phenomenon referred to as catastrophic forgetting, which is a core issue CL systems aim to address [2].
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Recently, GR-based methods, inspired by the generative nature of the hippocampus as a short-term memory system in the primate brain [3], have been widely studied to address the catastrophic forgetting problem.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In terms of GR, we are trying to address the two open questions mentioned above.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (Use of labels and novelty) In GR-based approaches, the quality of generated samples is crucial to keep the performance of previous tasks.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: If we use labels, we can construct a conditional generative model.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Generally, conditioning on a generative model yields higher quality samples than unconditional one and makes it possible to generate class-balanced samples [4]; the importance of conditional generation is also described in section 6.1 in our paper.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In this paper, we showed that discriminative regularization could make VAE possible to conduct both class conditional generation and classification with one integrated model.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Thus, we do not need to train an additional classifier, e.g., deep CNN, which is necessary for other works, including Narayanaswamy et al. There is also classifier integrated VAE such as [6].
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The difference with [6] is the use of class-conditional priors; more details are explained at the response (Difference with CDVAE) for reviewer 3 and section 4.1 in our paper.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (Domain translation) Even though the conditional generation improves the quality of the generated samples, there is still a big difference between real and generated images.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Because a deep neural network is vulnerable to even single-pixel perturbation [5], the difference can seriously affect the classification performance of GR-based algorithms.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Thus, we suggested applying the domain translation to address this issue.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: By narrowing distribution discrepancy between real and generated images using the domain translation technique, we were able to alleviate the catastrophic forgetting problem successfully (Table 2).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (Modeling) Good point.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Since we consider finite discrete conditions, we can directly optimize $\mathrm{\mu_c}$ and $\mathrm{\sigma_c}$ for each c as parameters without the prior network.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, introducing a prior network makes our model become a more general framework that can address continuous-valued conditions.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Also, in our paper, we set the prior network as a single fully-connected layer for easy handling of conditions and simple implementation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Otherwise, we should keep an additional mapping table between class conditions and its $\mathrm{\mu_c}$ and $\mathrm{\sigma_c}$.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (Experimental settings)
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Generally, CL systems assume that each task comes sequentially, and an agent can not directly access previous experience [2].
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We exactly follow the assumption.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Also, we train DiVA sequentially for each task with one same model.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: To clarify our training process, we provide a brief summarization.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Firstly, we train DiVA with task 1 that consists of real images and labels.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Then, when new task 2 is coming, DiVA generates images and its labels of task 1 and learns both task 2 and the generated task 1 simultaneously.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We added an additional figure in Figure 6 in Appendix E, for helping conceptual understanding.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: (Domains of CIFAR dataset) Since current generative models are not perfect for generating complex natural images, there is always a discrepancy between generated images and real images.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Thus, we can define two domains: real image domain (realistic) and generated image domain (blurry).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We used the domain translation for narrowing the gap.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: [1] Legg, Shane, and Marcus Hutter. "Universal intelligence: A definition of machine intelligence." Minds and machines 17.4 (2007): 391-444.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [2] https://sites.google.com/view/continual2018
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [3] Shin, Hanul, et al. "Continual learning with deep generative replay." Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems. 2017.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [4] Lesort, Timothée, et al. "Marginal Replay vs Conditional Replay for Continual Learning." International Conference on Artificial Neural Networks. Springer, Cham, 2019.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [5] Su, Jiawei, Danilo Vasconcellos Vargas, and Kouichi Sakurai. "One pixel attack for fooling deep neural networks." IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation (2019).
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [6] Mundt, Martin, et al. "Unified Probabilistic Deep Continual Learning through Generative Replay and Open Set Recognition." arXiv preprint arXiv:1905.12019 (2019).
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: We thank you for the constructive feedback and discuss some of your comments below.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: R3: "it would be valuable to compare the performance of curiosity-based learning versus learning based on well-defined extrinsic rewards"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: => We would like to highlight that evaluating success of pure curiosity-driven exploration (no extrinsic rewards for training) by measuring the extrinsic score of game is just a proxy to evaluate exploration.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our results show that exploration via curiosity has striking correlation with game scores.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: But we expect that when environments have a well-defined (and well-shaped!) extrinsic reward, a policy trained using that extrinsic reward should outperform the policy trained with only curiosity especially when the performance is measured by the extrinsic return.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: There are, however, examples, such as the Bowling Atari game, where a policy trained with only curiosity does *better* than a policy trained with extrinsic rewards.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The purely curious agent learns to play the game better than agents trained to maximize the (clipped) extrinsic reward directly.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We think this is because the agent gets attracted to the difficult-to-predict flashing of the scoreboard occurring after the strikes.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We expect such examples to come from environments with misleading or poorly-shaped extrinsic rewards.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: R3: "...it would be beneficial for the authors to explore reasons that random features perform well in reinforcement learning."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: => In the paper, Section 2.1, we discuss that random features have advantages that they are they are stable, compact, and tend to include most relevant information about the observation.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: However, in our opinion, a more interesting question is not why random features perform so well, but rather why the feature learning methods perform so poorly (relative to this baseline).
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Learning the features introduces non-stationarity that confounds the effects of learning the dynamics.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We believe that if methods are developed to address this non-stationarity, or environments that are more visually complex are used, then the benefits of the learning the features will become more noticeable.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thanks for your comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: To our knowledge, close to 2% improvement of accuracy is not small in CIFAR100. Because we only change pooling layers while keeping others exactly the same.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Now, we respond to your questions one by one:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The results of AA-pooling and F-pooling are not the same.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In Fig. 1, we show the results of average-pooling and F-pooling.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If you carefully look at the corner of curves, you can find the differences.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Without convolution, AA-pooling is similar to average-pooling (both of them are low-pass filters but with sightly different kernels.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: So AA-pooling gives different results for sine waves.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2. We believe F-pooling plays a more important rule in applications where shift-equivalent is serious, such as object detection and object tracking.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Because we need to predict the location or shifts of an image object.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Moreover, F-pooling may be better for complex-valued CNNs, such as [1].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3. The limitation of imaginary part is easy to overcome: set the resolution of F-pooling’s output to an odd number or padding it to an odd number when the resolution is an even number.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In this way, the imaginary part is zero.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Moreover, the word shift in this paper means circular shift.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: So it is better to use circular padding in convolutional layers.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, we find circular padding slower the training speed in PyTorch.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If we use zero paddings as in most situations, the beneficial of F-pooling is reduced.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our current experiments use zero paddings.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: See our general response for what happens when we replace zero paddings with circular padding.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 4. In all experiments of our current paper, the imaginary part is already ignored.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We can’t directly measure how the imaginary part affects the performance unless we use complex-valued CNNs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Ignoring this part will destroy the reconstruction optimality, but the effect is small.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Suppose the output size of F-pooling is 2N+1.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We first transform a signal into frequency domain and keep 2N+1 components with the lowest frequencies: f(-N), … , f(0), … ,f(N).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Then we transform it back into time domain.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In this case, the imaginary part in time domain is zero because of symmetry.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Now, suppose the output size is 2N+2: f(-N), … , f(0),
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In this case, the imaginary part is not zero.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, if we set f(N+1) to 0, it imaginary part becomes zero again.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thus, the error of ignoring imaginary part is not larger than ||f(N+1)||.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Fig.4 shows an example of odd and even output size of F-pooling.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: [1] Deep complex networks, ICLR2018
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: Thank you very much for the constructive comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We tried to strengthen our claims by adding more experimental data which the Reviewer requested.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1. The proposed "Multi-bit-quantization + Viterbi-based binary code encoding" requires slightly larger memory footprint than "Multi-bit quantization only ([4])" because some of the Viterbi encoded bits have different indices from their corresponding quantization bits.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Hence, the "Multi-bit quantization only" requires 10 % to 20 % smaller memory footprint than "Multi-bit-quantization + Viterbi-based binary code encoding" case.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, the main reason why we apply the Viterbi weight encoding is that parallel sparse-to-dense matrix conversion can be done by applying same Viterbi encoding process to the non-zero values and indices of the non-zero values in parallel.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This parallel sparse-to-dense conversion makes the speed of feeding parameters to PEs 10 % to 40 % faster compared to [1] (Figure 6c).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2. Per Reviewer’s suggestion, the experimental results for the effectiveness of "Don’t Care" term have been moved to Section 4.1.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 3. Per Reviewer's suggestion, we measured accuracy differences before and after Viterbi encoding for several quantization methods such as linear quantization ([2]), logarithmic quantization ([3]), and alternating quantization ([4]) methods with the same quantization bits (3-bit).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The result shows that combination with alternating quantization and Viterbi weight encoding had only 2 % validation accuracy degradation after the Viterbi encoding was applied first right after the quantization and the accuracy was easily recovered with retraining.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: On the other hand, the combination with the other quantization methods and Viterbi weight encoding showed accuracy degradation as much as 71 %, which was too large to recover the accuracy with retraining.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The accuracy difference mainly results from the uneven weight distribution.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Because weights of neural networks usually are normally distributed, the composition ratio of '0' and '1' is not equal when the linear or logarithmic quantization is applied to the weights of neural networks.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: As we stated in the manuscript, Viterbi encoder tends to produce similar number of '0' and '1'.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Therefore, we can conclude that under the same bit condition, alternating quantization method shows best accuracy and compatibility with our bit-by-bit Viterbi encoding scheme regardless of the type of neural networks.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 4. We conducted additional simulations to compare sparse matrix reconstruction speed of [1] and the proposed method.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We used a random 512-by-512 size matrix with various pruning rate ranging from 75 % to 95 %.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We conducted the simulations under the assumptions described in Figure 6c.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The simulation results are shown in Figure 6c in updated manuscript.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We could observe that the proposed method could feed 10 % to 40 % more nonzero weights and input activations to PEs in same 10000 cycles compared to [1].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Proposed method could also feed parameters to PEs 20 % to 106 % faster compared to baseline method, which reads dense weight and activation matrices directly from DRAM.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The improvement in the proposed scheme mainly comes from the parallelized process of assigning non-zero values to their corresponding indices in the weight matrix.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: While preparing addition data for the rebuttal, we realized that our simulation model did not fully exploit the parallelized weight and index decoding process of the proposed method.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: After further optimization, we could observe that the parameter feeding rate of the proposed method increased compared to the reported data in original manuscript.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Therefore, we updated Figure 7 in original manuscript to Figure 6c in updated manuscript according to the new data.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 5. We added the change of the exact weight representation at each process in Figure 1 to clarify the flowchart.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Reference
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: [1] Dongsoo Lee, Daehyun Ahn, Taesu Kim, Pierce I. Chuang, and Jae-Joon Kim. Viterbi-based pruning for sparse matrix with fixed and high index compression ratio. International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR), 2018.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [2] Darryl D. Lin, Sachin S. Talathi, and V. Sreekanth Annapureddy. Fixed point quantization of deep convolutional networks.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: In Proceedings of the 33rd International Conference on International Conference on Machine Learning - Volume 48, ICML’16, pp. 2849–2858. 2016.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [3] Daisuke Miyashita, Edward H. Lee, and Boris Murmann. Convolutional Neural Networks using Logarithmic Data Representation. CoRR, abs/1603.01025, 2016. URL https://arxiv.org/abs/1603.01025.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [4] Chen Xu, Jianqiang Yao, Zouchen Lin, Wenwu Qu, Yuanbin Cao, Zhirong Wang, and Hongbin Zha. Alternating multi-bit quantization for recurrent neural networks. International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR), 2018.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: We really appreciate your constructive comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We respond to each comment as follows.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1. Meta dropout does not regularize the variational framework because there is no variational inference framework.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - Thank you for your comment.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We agree with you that the current lower bound is not a variational form due to the assumption of q=p. In Section 3.2, we toned down the original expression “Learning to regularize variational inference“ into “Connection to variational inference”, and corrected the corresponding sentences.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Still, there exists a clear connection between standard variational inference and our learning framework.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Thus we believe that discussion in Section 3.2 will be helpful to readers who want to understand the meaning of learning objective Eq.(2) in depth.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: 2. Improving adversarial robustness experiment.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - Thank you for the helpful suggestion.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: During the rebuttal period, we conducted additional experiments on adversarial robustness as you suggested:
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: a) We replaced the previous FGSM attack with stronger PGD attack (200 iter.), with $L_1$, $L_2$, and $L_\infty$ norm constraints.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: b) We included more baselines (e.g. Mixup, VIB, and information dropout), and show that our meta-dropout largely and consistently outperforms all of them.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: c) We added more detailed descriptions of the adversarial meta-learning baseline and in-depth analysis on the results.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: d) We further show that the learned perturbation from our Meta-dropout also generalize across different types of adversarial attacks with $L_1$, $L_2$, and $L_\infty$ attacks.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: The generalization to different types of attacks is an important problem in adversarial learning, and most existing models fail to achieve this goal.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Please see the corresponding section in the revision.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We believe that the adversarial robustness part of our paper has become much stronger than before, thanks to your suggestion.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We address the different remarks below.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: “It is unclear whether the data augmentation techniques is applied only at training time or also at test time. In other words: at test time, do you present the original images only or transformed images too?”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We apply the data augmentation both at training and test time.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: “In section 4, it is unclear why only the maximal activation of the softmax layer is used to characterize a sample? Why not considering the full distribution that should contain richer information? Why just focusing on the output layer and why not using the info available at intermediate layers?”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We agree that the full distribution of the softmax layer provides more information, but there is no straightforward way to extend the Kolmogorov-Smirnov distance to multi-dimensional distributions, beyond the two- and three-dimensional cases.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We focus on confidence as a proxy to the loss, and we assume that the loss is the quantity that should be the most different between training and testing, as the optimization phase explicitly minimizes the loss on the training set.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Moreover, early experiments showed that using the outputs of intermediate layers provide no improvement for membership inference (on preliminary CIFAR-10 experiments, we obtained respectively 67.7 accuracy with the output layer and 66.5 when using all layers).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: “Section 5 is somewhat less clear than the previous sections. The authors should more clearly define what the private, public and evaluation sets are, right from the beginning. The purpose of the public set is explained only in section 5.2.”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We will update this section to make it clearer.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: “The experimental results of section 5.2 are somewhat disappointing. Even with no data augmentation, and even with the original networks, membership can only be assessed with a 90% accuracy.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Results are much lower in less favorable cases, sometimes close to random (see last line of Table 3).
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: This seems to be too low to be of practical use.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: This might be because the Bayes and MAT attacks are too simplistic.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Again, why not using the distribution of the outputs of all layers? Why focusing only on the output of the last layer?”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We agree that better performance could be obtained by running the initial model for more epochs, but our goal is to stay close to the standard training of Imagenet models, i.e. 90 epochs with an initial learning rate of 0.1, divided by 10 every 30 epochs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We emphasize that the last line of Table 3 corresponds to the most difficult setup, where the network has been trained with a strong data-augmentation, and we only use the intermediate layers of the network (which amounts to less than 62% of the parameters for e.g. Resnet101), this is why the performance is significantly impacted.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We experimented with more sophisticated models, and it did not bring any improvement (see shadow models in appendix E, e.g. the performance before the softmax layer is 58.2 for Resnet101 and 60.8 for our method).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their evaluation.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Please see our response at https://openreview.net/forum?id=Hkx-ii05FQ&noteId=HygFbNmL6X, where we also discuss our experimental framework.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Even though we present results on two tasks, it appears the paper structure doesn’t convey this clearly, and we suggest two possible ways how to update the paper in this regard.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We note in this context that even though we would also like to see Cakewalk evaluated on the domains mentioned by the reviewer, these are not part of our own research agenda, and accordingly our suggestions refer to other problems in combinatorial optimization.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Next, we address other issues raised by the reviewer.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: First, we’d like to emphasize that the clique problem studied in the paper is far from being a toy problem.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: All the algorithms are evaluated on the DIMACS clique dataset which was published as part of the second DIMACS challenge which specifically focused on combinatorial optimization.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Over the years, this dataset has become a standard benchmark for clique finding algorithms, and results on it are regularly published.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In this respect, this dataset is an important benchmark for clique algorithms very much like CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 are for image classification methods.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Notably, Cakewalk approaches the performance of the best clique finding algorithms that directly search a graph, and which are tailored to this specific task.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Note that none of the tested methods were given enough samples even to recover the graph itself, as most graphs have more than 100 nodes, and we’ve allowed only for 100 |V| samples in each execution.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: To us this seems as a rather challenging setup, not just for the algorithms we’ve tested in this paper, but for any clique finding algorithm.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Next, we wonder how would the reviewer correct the confounds mentioned with regard to the clique experiment.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Providing a controlled experiment is always challenging, though the elements mentioned by the reviewer were specifically selected as to reduce various confounds.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The main research question we try to address is whether algorithms that only rely on function evaluations can recover locally optimal solutions.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Since the objective is the only source of information for such algorithms, an all-or-none kind of objective would not be very useful.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Instead, the objective is designed in a manner that provides information even for partial solutions, thus allowing the tested algorithms to gradually improve the objective.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In terms of the sampling distribution, as our focus is on the update step, we decided to use the simplest possible sampling distribution we can think of.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In such a regime, we can attribute any performance gains to the algorithms themselves, and not to any prior knowledge that is reflected by the structure of some complex sampling distribution.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Next, we agree that local optimality is a mean rather than a goal (the objective itself).
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Nonetheless, as in the problems we seek to address the global optimum cannot be found in polynomial time
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: , the second best approach is first to design a method that can recover locally optimal solutions.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Once such a method is available, repeated applications of that method can allow one to select a good solution, very much like the standard practice of repeated applications of k-means which the reviewer mentions.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This reasoning however is dependent on a method’s capability of recovering locally optimal solutions, and therefore studying this ability makes for a worthwhile effort.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Answers to the last comments:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - Table 3 is indeed confusing, this is a good point. We will correct it.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: - Methods that apply a surrogate objective work best with AdaGrad.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In this case, our data is a classical use which is explored in the AdaGrad paper uses as a motivating example.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Not surprisingly, both Cakewalk and OCE work best with it.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: REINFORCE however is sensitive to the objective values, and it appears that Adam somewhat mitigates this problem.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, this is not as effective as applying a surrogate objective, and REINF_Z with Adam is outperformed by OCE_0.1 with AdaGrad in all measures.

sentence: - Our frame of reference were algorithms that could be applied to any combinatorial problem, and which only rely on function evaluations.

sentence: Control variates and reward shaping methods are mostly useful when tied to the particularities of a given objective, and thus do not fall into this category.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: In neural combinatorial optimization the study is focused on designing a sampling distribution that reflects some prior knowledge about a problem, and thus, we consider this line of work as orthogonal to ours.

sentence: Having said that, we see how these areas might seem related, and we will revise the related work section to better emphasize the aforementioned differences.

sentence: 1. “The numbers reported in Figure 5 do not match with the performance of adversarial training in previous paper… I wonder why the numbers are so different.”

sentence: Table 1 of "Obfuscated Gradients Give a False Sense of Security" reports an accuracy of 47% under 0.031 norm-inf perturbation for the CIFAR10 dataset (55% is reported for the MNIST dataset), approximately the same as the 44% accuracy in our Figure 5.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The difference in performance stems from how we preprocessed the CIFAR10 images: exactly in the manner described by (Zhang et al., 2017)’s ICLR paper “Understanding deep learning requires rethinking generalization” (we whiten and crop each image).

sentence: 2. “What's the training time of the proposed method compared with vanilla adversarial training?”

sentence: For 39 of the cases, our TensorFlow implementation of the proposed method results in longer training times (from 1.02 to 1.84 times longer).

sentence: In the 3 cases of iterative adversarial attacks with the Inception architecture, the proposed method actually results in faster training time.

sentence: This is likely due to how TensorFlow handles training in the backend.

sentence: We provide the code for full transparency.

sentence: Here we respond to your specific comments.

sentence: "Some technical details are missing.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In Section 3.2.2, the authors only explain how they learn example-based \sigma, but details on how to make graph construction end-to-end trainable are missing.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Constructing the full weight matrix requires the whole dataset as input and selecting k-nearest neighbor is a non-differentiable operation. Can you give more explanations?"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: >>> Thanks for pointing out the details.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We want to clarify the few-shot setting.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We follow the widely-used episodic paradigm proposed by Matching Networks [1].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In each episode (training batch), our algorithm solves a small classification problem which contains N classes each having K support and Q query examples (e.g., N=5, K=1, Q=15, totally 80 examples).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The weight matrix is constructed on the support and query examples in each episode rather than the whole dataset.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This is very fast and efficient.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In deep neural networks, there is a common trick in computing the gradient of operations non-differentiable at some points, but differentiable elsewhere, such as Max-Pooling (top-1) and top-k.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In forward computation pass, the index position of the max (or top-k) values are stored.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: While in the back propagation pass, the gradient is computed only with respect to these saved positions.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This trick is implemented in modern deep learning frameworks such as tensorflow and pytorch.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In our paper, we use the tensorflow function tf.nn.top_k() to compute k-nearest neighbor operation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: "Does episode training help label propagation? How about the results of label propagation without the episode training? "
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: >>> In our paper, the length scale parameter \sigma is trained in an example-wise and episodic-wise way, as described in section 3.2.2 and Figure 4 of Appendix A. In order to investigate the benefit of episodic training, we combine the heuristic-based label propagation methods [2] with meta-learning to serve as a transductive baseline.
