sentence: Our main contributions include:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: (i) For single-layer random variables (RVs), we propose a unified gradient named GO by exploiting the integration-by-parts idea, which is applicable to continuous/discrete RVs.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In the special case of single-layer continuous RVs where GO recovers Implicit Rep or pathwise gradients, we consider it’s our contribution to provide a principled explanation (via integration-by-parts) why Implicit Rep and pathwise gradients have low Monte Carlo variance; or in other words, we prove that their implicit differentiation originates from integration-by-parts.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (ii) For multi-layer RVs, our main contribution is the discovery that with GO (or in other words, the introduced variable-nabla), one can back-propagate gradient information through a nested combination of nonlinear functions and general RVs (including non-reparameterizable continuous RVs, back-propagating through which is challenging).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Another interpretation of this contribution is that GO enables generalizing the deterministic chain rule to a statistical version.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Here, we refer to deterministic chain rule as back-propagating gradient through deterministic functions (like neural networks) or reparameterizable RVs (like Gaussian).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: By contrast, statistical chain rule is referred to as back-propagating gradient through more general RVs (including non-reparameterizable ones).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Of course, statistical chain rule recovers deterministic chain rule for deterministic functions and reparameterizable RVs, because GO recovers the standard Rep.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (iii) Another 2 minor contributions include Lemma 1 and Corollary 1.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In Lemma 1, we explicitly prove that our deep GO gradient contains the standard Rep as a special case, in general beyond Gaussian.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Note neither Implicit Rep nor pathwise gradients can recover Rep in general, because a neural-network-parameterized reparameterization usually leads to a nontrivial CDF.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In Corollary 1, we reveal the fact that the proposed method degrades into the classical back-propagation algorithm under specific settings.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Finally, we believe it is interesting to create a consistent architecture, which unifies (a) a GO gradient which contains many popular gradients as special cases, and (b) a more general statistical chain rule developed based on GO which recovers the well-known deterministic chain rule under specific cases.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: For your comments not addressed above, please see our additional response below.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: (1) We have made clearer the relationships among the standard Rep, Implicit Rep/pathwise, and our GO in the revised manuscript.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: In the revised paper we have explicitly pointed out that the experiments from (Figurnov et al. 2018, Jankowiack & Obermeyer,2018) additionally support our GO in the special case of single-layer continuous RVs.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (2) Please refer to our main contributions summarized above, where other contributions, beyond GO for discrete RVs, are clarified.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (3) Please refer to our main contributions (ii)-(iii).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: As stated in our paper, many works tried to solve the problem of stochastic/statistical back-propagation.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We consider our contributions in Secs. 4 and 5 as one step toward that final goal.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Please note that what’s done in Secs. 4 and 5 is not straight-forward and has not been reported before.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Since stochastic back-propagation (Rezende et al., 2014; Fan et al., 2015) focuses mainly on reparameterizable RVs, deterministic chain rule as mentioned in main contribution (ii) can be readily applied.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: By contrast, we target towards more general situations in Secs. 4 and 5 where deterministic chain rule might not be applicable, such as for non-parameterizable (continuous) RVs.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We prove that one can utilize our GO to sequentially back-propagate gradient though non-parameterizable continuous RVs, namely the statistical chain rule mentioned in main contribution (ii).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We have revised the last paragraph of the Introduction to make a more explicit summation of our main contributions, as mentioned above.

sentence: THEORY:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Section 2 now formalizes our contribution of unifying Riemannian geometry and gyrovector spaces for all stereographic spaces of constant curvature of any sign, formally proving that the interpolation is smooth at 0.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Please note that gyrovector spaces and their properties were stated only for negative curvature spaces prior to our work.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Theorem 1 formally states when k-addition is defined for spherical spaces.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Theorem 2 formally derives formulas of exponential map, logarithmic map, geodesics and distance w.r.t. Gyro-operations in the setting of positive curvature, by making use of the Egregium theorem.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Theorem 3 proves smoothness of the main quantities appearing in Theorem 2 w.r.t. curvature, i.e. that they are differentiable at 0, by showing that left and right derivatives from both models actually match.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: It also gives the derivative of the distance function w.r.t. curvature around 0.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Theorem 4 describes two simple properties of our proposed left-matrix-multiplication, in particular that it is Mobius-scalar-associative.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Theorem 5 shows that our proposed left-matrix-multiplication is an intrinsic averaging for Riemannian manifolds of constant curvature, i.e. it does commute with isometries when the matrix A is right-stochastic, which is not the case of right-matrix-multiplication.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: This is a desirable property for Riemannian averaging.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Theorem 6 shows that weighted combinations in the tangent space used in the very recent works of [1,2] (appeared after ICLR submission deadline) is also an intrinsic averaging for Riemannian manifolds of constant sectional curvature, i.e. it does commute with isometries.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Yeh et al. (2017) use the discriminator loss of a trained GAN as an indicator of how realistic their restoration is.

sentence: Ideally the generator will have all the information of the data distribution while the discriminator will have none.

label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: These images are damaged so badly that TV cannot recover any meaningful thing.
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: As a handcrafted prior, TV performs much worse than our data-driven baseline method in these tasks.
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: Q3: Does the proposed method learn the image inpainting mask as well?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: What are the parameters of the degradation in the applications?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A3: The image inpainting mask is known and fixed.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We use four different kinds of degradation to test the generality of our method.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The first three kinds of degradation are 7× downsampling, making a 14×14 square hole in the center of the image, and adding Gaussian white noise with a standard deviation of 1.0, respectively.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The last kind of degradation is a composition of a series of degradation in order, which are (a) adding linear motion blur by at most 14 pixels in any direction, (b) 4× downsampling, (c) adding uniform noise between -0.05 and 0.05, (d) randomly removing 10% of the pixels.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q: "...I find these assumptions too strong for the task of learning disentangled representation."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: We wish to emphasize that:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: (1) we only require access to meta-labels on the source set
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: (2) our goal is not to find disentangled representations; Our goal is transferability so that we can learn on real data with minimal supervision.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Q: "you can simply train a network to predict the canonicalizations by simple supervised learning"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: Finding the canonicaliers is not our goal.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: These are used as auxiliary constraints which guide representation learning and allow for latent data augmentation on our limited target data.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Specifically, predicting the factor values will not help us in manipulating the target samples (note the significant improvement we get by using the majority vote).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Q: method needs to be compared with other representation learning methods such as jigsaw[1], colorization[2] and rotation[3].
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: The suggested methods [1-3] are self-supervised methods using less information than the baselines we have included (for example, the AE+classifier baseline is trained on the same synthetic data with the same access to digit labels).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We therefore expect that these methods will perform worse than our baselines.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have included  a comparison with method [3] (see general comment to all reviewers).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the comments and suggestions.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We address points individually below:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1) The Higher-order Lipschitz condition is necessary for us to use the PL convergence guarantee.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This condition is similar to assumptions made in convex optimization, especially where higher-order updates are involved (see eg. Agarwal et al. 2017 and Bubeck et al. 2019).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If the iterates of the algorithm always have bounded norm (eg. due to constraints or regularization), then three-times differentiable functions will satisfy the Higher-order Lipschitz condition for our purposes.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This is because it suffices for the condition to hold for only the iterates of the algorithm ($x^{(1)},x^{(2)},...$), rather than for all of $\mathbb{R}^d$.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2) We thank the reviewer for this remark.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We wanted $L_H$ to be defined for our theorem statements, but we can see how it is confusing as is. We will make it clear that $L_H$ is the smoothness parameter of $H$.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: 3) Theorem 3.4 holds in the broadest setting out of all of these results.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Theorems 3.2 and 3.3 have slightly tighter bounds for their respective settings.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We will clarify this in the surrounding text.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: 4) It is true that these results rely on the PL condition, and this is unavoidable for our current results.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: The novel perspective in this paper is that we consider the PL condition on a different objective, namely the squared gradient norm, rather than on the game objective $g$. This perspective allows us to prove our new bounds, although we still require some nontrivial linear algebra.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The PL condition also allows us to easily prove our stochastic HGD results.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 5) The 1/sqrt(2) should cancel out on both sides of the guarantee in Theorem 5.2 (and eg. in equation 68).
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: Minor suggestions:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -We appreciate the suggestion for page 5 and will make this change in the final version.

sentence: We would be happy to include some further experiments in the final version comparing HGD with other algorithms such as extragradient.

sentence: Q: "I had hard time to understand latent canonicalization..."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: "latent canonicalization" is a procedure by which the representation is being modified such that a factor of variation assumes a certain prescribed value. While the values of the factors are pre-specified, the canonicalizers are learned linear operators.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q: The learning of the proposed model relies on meta-data description such that the learning is supervised. Can the method be applicable to situations where no meta-data and no class labels are available?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: as we discuss in the general comments, the method is best suited for problems of interest where a synthetic simulator is available.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In those cases full access to factors of variation is available as this is used to generate the data.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: , The question we focus on is how to best utilize the knowledge of factors of variation to improve the transferability of the learned representation to real data with limited labels.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We are not focusing on a setting where the source domain has no labels.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: That said, our method does not assume access to all factors for all samples (in fact we only use two factors per sample).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q: How can the proposed method be generalized to non-image data?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The experiments were only done on simple image datasets.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: I am wondering this method can be applied to other complex datasets whose latent factors are unknown.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: Our method is not specific to the image domain and there is no reason it could not be applied to other input types.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In order to use our method, we only require a corpus of data with partially (at least two) labeled factors of variation and a corpus of data which is sparsely labeled for a downstream task.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Critically, these two sources of data need not be identical!
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This means that an easy way to acquire a corpus with labeled factors of variation is to use a simulator to generate this data,  as we do in this study.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Q: I do not understand this: "to fit well the method overfitting rate" in Section 3.3.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thank you for pointing this sentence out!
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: It is indeed unclear.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: All we were trying to say is that each baseline’s training duration was chosen independently to prevent overfitting.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We have updated the draft to be more clear.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: The following link is a figure that explains the difference between zero-confidence attack and fix-perturbation attack.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/anon181018/iclr2019_rebuttal/master/figure1.pdf
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: As can be seen, the zero-confidence attack finds the closest point on the decision boundary; while fix perturbation-attack finds adversarial samples within a fix perturbation.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Both attacks are equivalent if we only want to compute the attack success rate under a given perturbation level.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: However, we will be better off with zero-confidence attacks if we want to
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 1) Compute the margin of each individual example; and
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 2) Probe and study the decision boundary of a classifier
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Of course, we can also measure the margin of each example using a fix-perturbation attack, for example PGD, by binary searching over the perturbation levels.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: However, the computation cost will significantly increase.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Consider, for example, the CIFAR-10 dataset.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Since for our model, most margins fall within 10, so let’s assume the binary search range is 10 (for adversarially trained models this number will be much higher).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: If we want to achieve a accuracy of 0.1, then we need at least 7 binary search steps.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In other words, the computation complexity increases by 7 times.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In fact, CW applies a similar binary search idea to achieve zero-confidence attack, and that is why its computation cost is high.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The above discussion is not saying that it is impossible to convert PGD to a zero-confidence attack efficiently, but it at least provides a perspective on why zero-confidence attack is challenging, and why the complexity reduction as well as accuracy improvement of MarginAttack is valuable.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Although this is not the major focus of your comment, we would like to revisit the theorem assumptions.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: While there are nine assumptions, these assumptions are in fact more realistic than expected.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Take the convexity assumption, which you mentioned in your review, as an example.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This assumption does not say that the constraint has to be convex.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: It only says that the constraint should not be ‘too concave’.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In particular, the curvature of the of the decision should not exceed that of the L2 or L-infinity ball.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: For better illustration, we plotted some decision boundaries that are allowed by the assumption, and some that are not.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Please check the following link:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/anon181018/iclr2019_rebuttal/master/figure2.pdf
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: As can be seen, the convexity assumption permits a wide variety of decision boundaries.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Among the few cases that it does not permit is the case where the decision boundary bends more than the L2 ball does.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In this case, the critical point becomes a local maximum rather than a local minimum.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The other assumptions are also more realistic than their names sound.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The differentiability assumption does not stipulate that the constraint has to be differentiable.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: It actually permits countably infinite jump discontinuities.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The Lipchitz continuous assumption does not assume Lipchitz continuity everywhere, but only at x*. We are not saying that the assumptions are very loose, but they are realistic enough to shed some light on the actual convergence property of MarginAttack.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Nevertheless, we are considering adding a 2D toy example as you suggested.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We will post further responses if there are further updates.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Q: Did you try applying the classification loss to both the encoded representation and the canonicalized representation at the same time?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: Yes we did and interestingly, it didn't show improvement.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The results are reported in Appendix A, Table A1 in the row titled: "Ours + classifier after" and discussed in Section 4.2.4.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Note that because the bypassed latent, z, is included along with the canonicalized latents, z_canon, the classifier is trained on both the original representation and the canonicalized representations together.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q: For Figure 2, Did you try applying canonicalizations in different orders? Do they give the same results?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: For our experiments, each training example was bypassed and canonicalized by four different transformations: C_1, C_2, C_1C_2, and C_2C_1.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: So latents are canonicalized in both possible orderings.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We discuss this point at the bottom of page 4 after equation 6 and will further clarify.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q: Instead of trying to learn idempotency by gradient descent, you could try to parametrize the canonicalizations with a matrix X, such that C =  X (X^T X)^{-1} X^T. C will be idempotent (although restricted to be symmetric).
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: There might be other constructions that are more efficient and less restrictive.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: Structuring the matrix to enforce properties like idempotency is definitely an interesting direction to explore in future work.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: While not equivalent, as a first step towards this, we did try to examine different levels of idempotency enforcement.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: First, at the reconstruction loss, since pairs of canonicalizers are applied in different order we enforce the the decoded results are similar.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, adding a stricter enforcement of similar values before decoding only hurt performance, hinting that the suggested idea of enforcing idempotency at the strictest level may hurt performance further.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q: I'm not sure I understand the PCA figures. Can you please explain how the first principal component was used to generate them?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: Treating a canonicalizer as a standard linear projection, we explore z - P*z which should contain only the factor of interest (intuitively it is the difference between a representation and a version of it stripped off of the specific factor so that the factor is isolated).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Creating a set of such latent samples (here we took all examples to be of the same digit for visualization purposes) we ran PCA to get a dimension with the most significant variance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If the above mentioned assumption indeed holds, the font should be the only change in the set.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We order the samples according to that axis and plot them in a row from left to right.

sentence: We see that indeed the font (bottom row) and angle (top row) present a good correlation with the value along the axis.

sentence: 1- We briefly mentioned the way problem embedding with similarity metric is used in the recommendation system in this work, but here is more explanation on that.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The most similar problem is not necessarily recommended to a student.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: On a high level, if a student performs well on problems, we assume he/she performs well on similar problems as well, so we recommend a dissimilar problem and vice versa.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: More specifically, we project the performance of students on problems they solved onto the problems that they have not solved.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This way, we have an evaluation of the performance of students on unseen problems.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: A problem is recommended that is within the capacity of students close to their boundary to help them learn, and at the same time recommendation is done so that all the concepts necessary for students are practiced by them.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: An evaluation on real students is presented in part 2 of the comment titled “Response to questions about Prob2Vec” on this page, and we observed that similar problems are more likely to be solved correctly at the same time or wrong at the same time.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The math expressions are not ignored in our proposed Prob2Vec method.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In the example given in the last paragraph on page 3 for example, math expressions are used to extract the concept n-choose-k.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We both use math expressions and text to label problems with appropriate concepts.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: 2- Prob2Vec only uses expert knowledge for rule-based concept extractor, but does not use selected informative words.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The effort put for rule-based concept extractor is negligible compared to effort needed for annotation of all problems with their corresponding concepts.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We both annotated all problems manually and used rule-based concept extractor for annotation.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In the former method, we observed 100% accuracy in the similarity detection test and observed 96.88% accuracy in the latter method.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: However, the rule-based concept extractor needs much less manual effort than manual problem annotation and is capable to provide us with relatively high level of accuracy we need in our application.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Note that our method is scalable as long as problems are in the same domain as the rule-based concept extractor is automated for a single domain, but for the case that problems span many different domains, it is the natural complexity of the data set that requires a more sophisticated rule-based concept extractor.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Furthermore, in most realistic cases for education purposes, problems span a single domain not multiple ones.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: 1. Comment:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Missing comparison with parameter counting bounds [1, 2].
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1. Response:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: [1, 2] are early works on RNNs and their analysis is based on very simple network architectures, which is not directly comparable to our results.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Specifically, [1] only consider RNNs taking the first entry of the hidden state as output and restrict their discussion to polynomial or sigmoid activation functions.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Moreover, their analysis is based on unwinding RNNs as feedforward neural networks and adopt a layer-wise analysis, which fails to incorporate the parameter sharing in RNNs, and the established bounds are far from satisfactory (O(d^8 t^2) for sigmoid activation).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: [2] simply focus on linear RNNs for binary classification problems, its extension to general settings are quite unclear.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: 2. Comment:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Vacuous bounds in the regime \beta >1.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 2. Response:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We have clearly indicated that our bound is always polynomial in d and t in the introduction on page 3, which is not vacuous.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Moreover, both bounds of Theorem 3 are obtained under the same assumptions as in Theorem 2 with additional norm constraints on weight matrices.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The exponential term stems from the layer wise covering argument rather than the range of the output.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The bound in Theorem 2 is still polynomial in d and t, since we exploit the parametric form of RNNs and construct the covering by weight matrix coverings.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Existing literature has shown that keeping the spectral norm of weight matrix U close to 1 stabilizes the training of RNNs.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This can be achieved by orthogonal initialization and imposing extra constraints or regularization [3-5].
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We further discuss the trade-off between representation and generalization beneath Theorem 2 on page 4: \beta \approx 1 helps balance the generalization and representation of RNNs.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: 3. Comment:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Technical contribution: marginal.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 3. Response:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We provide new understandings of RNNs by connecting their generalization properties to their empirical success.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We establish generalization bounds using the PAC-learning framework by instilling our simple but new complexity analysis for RNNs.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In particular, we characterize the Lipschitz property of the output of RNNs with respect to weight matrices (Lemma 2).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: This key step allows us to construct a covering on RNNs from simple coverings of weight matrices, which results in a complexity bound of RNNs polynomial in d and t.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We further extend our analysis to establish the first generalization bounds for MGU and LSTM RNNs.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The proposed analysis is quite different from [6], which adopts a layer-wise evaluation for neural networks and constructs the overall covering via a complicated matrix covering argument.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Moreover, as compared in Section 4 Table 1, our generalization bound is much tighter when \beta > 1.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: To sum up, the main contributions are listed as follows (see paragraphs 2 - 5 on page 3):
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 1) We develop new techniques for effectively characterizing the model class of RNNs, which allows us to establish tight generalization bounds.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 2) We establish generalization bounds for both MGU and LSTM RNNs, and demonstrate their advantages over vanilla RNNs in generalization (under Theorems 4 and 5).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Given very limited literature on RNNs and their variants (not even mentioning that most of existing theoretical results are negative, e.g., exponential complexities), we believe this paper has its novel contributions.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 4. Comment:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Missing experiments to validate nature of bounds.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 4. Response:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Please refer to the revised version for numerical evaluations in Section 6.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: In particular, we illustrate that our obtained generalization bound (Theorem 2) is much smaller than existing bounds even for \beta > 1.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Thank you for your review of our work.

sentence: The following are your concerns of our work:

sentence: a. Limited contribution to the qualitative understanding of the optimizers

sentence: a.i. Informativeness of the proposed w-tunability metric
label: rebuttal_structuring

label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We address these concerns one-by-one.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: a. Limited contribution to the qualitative understanding of the optimizers:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We consider the three main contributions of our work to be 1) a systematic evaluation protocol of optimizers, with off-the-shelf HPO to account for the cost of tuning of hyperparameters.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: This is missing in existing papers, which consider best attained performance alone.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The importance of a proper hyperparameter search protocol is emphasized by Choi et al., 2019 (published after our submission and under review at ICLR).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: 2) a “w-tunability” measure of the cost of hyperparameter optimization, and 3) under the experiments considered we find that Adam (with default beta and epsilon values) is the most tunable.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: a.i. Informativeness of the tunability metric:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We propose w-tunability as a metric to incorporate the HPO tuning too in reporting the performance of an optimizer, and compute it as a linear combination of the incumbents of the HPO algorithm, though one can use an arbitrarily complex function trading off interpretability.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: It is true that Figures 4-7 essentially contain all the information needed to judge about the optimizer’s tunability.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: However, a metric that is easy to compute, interpret and compare optimizers across tasks is crucial, for which we propose w-tunability.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: This is analogous to computing specific quantities like accuracy, FPR, TPR from the confusion matrix, even though a confusion matrix contains all the information (and is quite cumbersome to compare).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The summary metric in Figure 2 provides a different interpretation: It reports a normalized performance i.e., the  normalized incumbent performance at iteration $k$. This doesn’t explicitly include information about the previous $k-1$ iterations (which is our central argument).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Thus our proposed tunability metric provides more information than the summary statistics plot (figure 2).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Due to this novelty, we argue that our setup does contribute to the qualitative understanding of the optimizers.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In fact, it yields to a drastically different valuation of adaptive gradient methods than popular previous work (Wilson et al, Shah et al).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We have modified parts of our paper to reflect these arguments better.

sentence: b. Using wall-clock time instead of HPO oracle calls:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Our reason for using a number of configuration trials instead of a time budget is that measuring number of hyperparameter configuration searches required is more relevant to understand the optimizers’ dependence on the hyperparameters.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, we completely agree with you that computational budget is a relevant factor from the practitioner’s point of view, and added a discussion of this in Appendix E of the paper.

sentence: As you rightfully point out, the adaptive optimizers tend to converge in fewer number of epochs, amplifying the results that favor Adam over the variants of SGD.

sentence: 1. Comment:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: However, it seems a little unexplainable to apply a technique developed from classification to analyze RNNs, since the main task of RNNs never should be classification.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1. Response:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We study seq2seq classification tasks since they have been widely used in real world applications for RNNs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: To name a few, in speech recognition, [1] hybridizes hidden Markov model with RNNs to label unsegmented sequence data; In computer vision, [2, 3] demonstrate scene labeling with LSTM and RNNs, achieving higher accuracy than baseline methods; In healthcare, [4] proposes a model, Doctor AI, to perform multiple label prediction (one for each disease or medication category).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In addition, [5, 6] both apply RNNs to real-world healthcare datasets (MIMIC-III, PhysioNet, and ICU data) for mortality prediction and other multiple classifications tasks.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We establish bounds for classification because it is typical in learning theory and is easy to compare among existing literature.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: On the other hand, our analysis applies in other tasks as long as a suitable Lipschitz loss function is chosen.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Specifically, Lemma 4 establishes an upper bound for empirical Rademacher complexity of general Lipschitz loss functions (the last line in Appendix A.4).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: By replacing the loss function in Lemma 1, we can derive generalization bounds for various tasks other than classification.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our goal is to develop a quantitative understanding of AlphaGo Zero (AGZ), moving beyond the intuitive justification for the algorithms in the original work.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We believe that a rigorous mathematical analysis is crucial to provide a solid foundation for understanding AGZ and similar algorithms.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This requires developing (i) a precise mathematical model, (ii) a quantitative performance bound within the model.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Our work takes an important step in this direction by modeling AGZ’s self-play and its supervised learning algorithm accurately.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In particular, we use the turn-based game model to capture the self-play aspect.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We develop a quantitative bound in terms of cross-entropy loss in supervised learning, which is the “metric” of choice in AGZ.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: While the cross-entropy loss seems intuitive, using it as a quantitative performance measure requires careful thought.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: For example, in Appendix F (page 19, 2nd paragraph), we discussed a scenario where this intuition is incorrect under a careless measure.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: That is, seemingly “obvious” algorithms can fail in the absence of a rigorous mathematical proof.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We agree that there is a gap between AGZ and our model.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: As mentioned in our paper, MCTS converges to the optimal policy for both classical MDPs and stochastic games.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Hence in this paper, we model the AGZ’s MCTS policy by the optimal policy, and mainly focus on the other two key ingredients of AGZ, self-play and supervised learning.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: It will be interesting to study how the error between MCTS and the optimal policy affects the iterative algorithm.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: This is a research direction we think is worth pursuing in the future.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: We also agree with the reviewer that some of our statements might be too strong.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We will revise accordingly. Instead of ``immediate justification``, we believe this work does provide a first-step, formal framework towards a better theoretical understanding.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We will also revise the title, perhaps to ``applying AGZ`` so as to make the connection to MDP more clear in our paper.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We would like to thank the reviewer for their feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We address each comment below individually with appropriate headings.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - Summary
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We would like to point out that the reviewer in the summary incorrectly described that our approach uses the "triplet loss as a convex relaxation of the ordinal embedding problem".
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Using the triplet loss as a proxy does not make the problem convex.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: - The relation between data distribution and hardness of ordinal embedding
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Ordinal embedding is NP-hard independent of the data distribution.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The paper “Landscape of non-convex quadratic feasibility” (Bower et al. 2018) can shed more light on this.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The equation (1) in this paper rephrases the ordinal embedding problem as a homogeneous quadratic feasibility problem.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The constraint matrices of the problem (P_i in the paper), which correspond to the triplet inequalities, are all indefinite which makes the whole optimization NP-hard.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Moreover, many of our experiments in this paper feature the uniform distribution, which does not satisfy any nice structural assumptions.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - Using a convex solver
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: As we pointed out earlier, using the triplet loss does not make the optimization problem convex and hence using a convex solver would not be possible here.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - “Equations (3) and (4):  isn't this the same as using the hinge loss to bound the zero-one loss?”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Yes, that is true.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: To reply to your other specific comments,
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1) The intuition for batchnorm can be put in a more general setting.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If a function f: X -> Y tends to spread out small clusters in the input space almost evenly in the output space, then one can expect that its gradients will be large typically.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In our case, a batchnorm network can be understood as a function that sends a batch of inputs to a batch of outputs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In the appendix, we showed that the correlation between two different batches tend to a constant value independent of the input batches.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: No matter how close two input batches are, the output batches will have the same “distance” from each other -- small movements in the input space leads to large movements in the output space.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thus we can expect the gradients to be large as well.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have added a new figure to the Appendix to further support this intuition.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In it, we pass through a linear batchnorm network 2 minibatches.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Both minibatches contain points on the same circle and 1 point off the circle that is unique to each minibatch.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: While the circle in each minibatch will remain an ellipse as they are propagated through the network, the angle between the planes spanned by them increasingly becomes chaotic with depth.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3) As observed in [1] and [2], depthwise convergence to covariance fixed points is bad for training, and the best networks are either moderately deep or initialized such that the depthwise convergence rate to the fixed point is as slow as possible.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We observe that deep networks whose activation statistics resemble a non-BSB1 fixed point typically feature worse gradient explosion than BSB1 networks.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This seems to be because the nonlinearities that induce these fixed points increase rapidly (for example, polynomials with high degrees), so that the corresponding derivatives are also large, causing gradient explosion.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (The reason that rapidly increasing nonlinearities don’t converge to BSB1 fixed points is that, after a spontaneous symmetry-breaking, begins a “winner-take-all” covariance dynamics, in which the activations of a few examples in the batch suddenly dominates those of the others in the batch, and this dominance persists across each layer.)
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 4) We were a bit confused by what was meant by “practice” here.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We have thoroughly verified that for realistic input distributions (MNIST and CIFAR10) and common initialization strategies (weights that are randomly distributed) our theory makes accurate prediction.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: Moreover, we have shown that these predictions can be connected to practice in the sense that they predict whether or not the network can be trained.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: Having said this, if by practice you meant that the neural network is accurately described by our theory during training then we do not expect this to be true. We are happy to emphasize this in the camera ready.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: If this did not properly address your question, please feel free to let us to know and we will improve this response!

sentence: The purpose of the counterexample is only to show that there exists some spurious solutions to GANs with general DeepSets-style discriminator for point clouds.

sentence: We found empirically that GAN with simple DeepSet-like discriminator most of the times fails to learn to generate point clouds even after converging, however, it does sometimes results in reasonable generations (although worse than proposed PC-GAN).

sentence: So, we do not consider the argument to be unrealistic as we often observe the degeneracy.

sentence: So the message here is that we need additional constraints for GANs with simple DeepSet-like discriminator to exclude such bad solutions and lead to a more stable training.

sentence: Thank you for your insightful feedback and suggestions! To address your comments:
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: - Following your suggestion, we have added one experiment on a synthetic regression task in Appendix C. Here, we show that our method can learn meaningful models for target domains, and also learn the source domain weights in a way that selects only relevant source domains for training.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: More importantly, we can learn the model and the domain weights simultaneously, unlike many existing works that use two-stage learning (learn the weights then the model).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: - We also followed your suggestion and show the domain weights of MDMN on the Amazon dataset for comparison (see the new Section 5.4).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: As you mentioned, our weights are theoretically justified while theirs are only heuristically computed.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We see that the weights provided by MDMN are not very stable, changing from one source domain to another drastically during training.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: This instability makes their weights difficult to interpret.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: - W.r.t. the naive method of using (fixed) coefficients.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Note that whichever domain discrepancy is used, it has to depend on the data representation.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: For complicated models like deep neural networks, the feature representations (hidden layers) are changing constantly during training and arguably there is no "right" way to compute *fixed* coefficients/weights
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: based on ever-changing representations
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Computing the coefficients directly from the images is extremely difficult, if not impossible, because calculating the domain discrepancy using such high-dimensional data is not feasible.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Note that MDMN DOES use W1-distance to compute domain weights, and our comparison in Section 5.4 shows that it is not very stable, as mentioned above.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: To summarize, there is no easy way to compute meaningful fixed coefficients and our method is indeed suitable for dynamic representations during neural network training.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We hope our explanation and additional results address and resolve your concerns. If you have any other comments, we are happy to have further discussions.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: The prior work by Hsu et al. showed that the oracle trained by deep learning has high accuracy (see Section 5.3 in their paper): for Internet traffic data, the AUC score is 0.9, and for search query data, the AUC score is 0.8.

sentence: Summary: our response includes: (1) Clarification on language translation baselines; (2) Discussion on image translation evaluation; (3) Reference and clarification.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: ** Language Translation Baselines **
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1. For the baseline models reported:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1.1) We use the transformer model with "transformer_big" setting [1], which is a strong baseline that outperforms almost all previously popular NMT models based on CNN [2] and LSTM [3].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Transformer is the state-of-the-art NMT architecture.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our numbers of the baseline transformer model match the results reported in [1].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 1.2) In addition to the standard baseline models, we also compare our method against all the relevant algorithms including knowledge distillation (KD) and back translation (BT).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 1.3) As can be seen in many well-known and recent NMT works ([4], [5])
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: , it is a common practice to use transformer as the robust baseline model.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Furthermore, it is also shown from these works that it is hard to improve over the transformer baseline, and 0.5-1 BLEU score improvement is already considered substantial.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2. We further add newly obtained results on the WMT18 challenge.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We compare our method with both the champion translation system MS-Marian (WMT18 En->De challenge champion).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our method achieves the state-of-the-art result on this task.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: WMT En->De
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: MS-Marian (ensemble)
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Ours (single)
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Ours (ensemble)
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Please refer to Section 3.4 "Study on generality of the algorithm" for more details and Table 4 for full results in our updated paper.

sentence: ** Image Translation Evaluation **
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: For image-to-image translation tasks, we further add two quantitative measures: (1) We use the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) [6], which measures the distance between generated images and real images to evaluate the painting to photos translation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (2) We use "FCN-score" evaluation on the cityscape dataset following [7].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The results are reported in Table 6 and Table 7 respectively.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Multi-agent dual learning framework can achieve better quantitative results than the baselines.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We are not sure what you meant by “How does their ensemble method compare to just their single-agent dual method?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The standard CycleGAN model (baseline) already leverages both primal and dual mappings, which is equivalent to our “Dual-1” model in NMT experiments, i.e., the dual method with only one pair of agents f_0 and g_0.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: Our model involves two additional pairs of agents (f_1 and g_1, f_2 and g_2) during training.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: Unlike ensemble learning, only one agent (f_0 for forward direction, or g_0 for backward direction) is used during inference.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: ** Reference **
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thanks for pointing a reference paper "Multi-Column Deep Neural Networks for Image Classification" (briefly, MCDNN) and we have added reference to it (Section 4).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Although MCDNN also uses multiple agents (i.e., several columns of deep neural networks), it differs from our model in two aspects: (1) Our work leverages the duality of a pair of dual tasks while this paper does not; (2) In an MCDNN framework, during the training phase, all the columns are updated by winner-take-all rule; and during inference, all columns work like an ensemble model through weighted average.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In comparison, we only update one primal and one dual agent during training, and use one agent for inference.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our paper revision includes reorganization of the introduction to our framework (Section 3.1), the additional experiments on WMT18 English->German translation challenge (Section 3.4), the additional study on diversity of agents (Appendix A), and quantitative evaluation on image-to-image translations (Section 4.3 and 4.4) following your suggestions.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In particular, we would like to highlight that:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: (1) The calibration of BLEU score: We would like to point out that our improvement over the previous state-of-the-art baselines is substantial.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: For example, on the WMT2014 En->De translation task, the performance of the transformer baseline is 28.4 BLEU score [1] (our baseline matches this performance).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The improvement over this baseline is 0.61 in [2], 0.8 in [3] (1.3 BLEU improvement over the re-implemented 27.9 baseline in [3]) and 0.9 in [4], while ours is 1.65 BLEU score.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (2) The baselines: As we explained in the previous response, we are using the state-of-the-art transformer as our backbone model, and comparing against all the relevant algorithms including KD, BT and the traditional 2-agent dual learning (Dual-1).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Moreover, we also show on WMT18 En->De challenge that our method can further improve the state-of-the-art model trained with extensive resources (Section 3.4 of our updated paper).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We hope our rebuttal and paper revision could address your concerns.

sentence: We welcome further discussion and are willing to answer any further questions.

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the thoughtful review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: The reviewer points out that CNE works well for link prediction and visualization.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We wish to point out that our experiments indicate CNE consistently outperforms the state-of-the-art not only for these tasks but also for multi-label classification.
label: rebuttal_accept-praise

sentence: Our responses:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: a) Variational inference is useful in particular when the partition function is hard to compute, which is not the case here.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: So we believe it would be overkill in this case.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In any case, it is not needed to achieve the performances CNE achieves at a very modest computational complexity and fast practical runtimes.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: b) No hand-engineering is needed to use CNE even when using more informative priors modeling node degrees and block structure.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The degree of each node can simply be computed on the training set, so no hand-engineering is needed (just the choice to include it or not -- and it always better to include it).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The block structure, on the other hand, will often be part of the data specification or meta-data of the nodes.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For example, the network may be a multi-partite network representing a relational database, or it may be a company social network where the nodes are employees, and generic job titles are known for each of the employees (as attributes of the nodes).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The entity types in the first example, and the job titles in the second example, would then define the blocks, and the density of the parts of the adjacency matrix between any two such blocks can again easily be computed on the network.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our method imposes no constraints on such blocks (e.g. they may even be partially overlapping).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Again, all that is needed is choosing whether to use a block prior for any specified attribute (in the two examples: entity type, and node attribute).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Again, empirically, including it always appears to be better, so one could even avoid having to make the choice.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Inferring structural properties of the graph to be used in the prior (e.g. using GraphRNN), as we understand the reviewer suggests, certainly sounds potentially interesting.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, while it may improve accuracy, we do not believe that it adds value in reducing the amount of hand-engineering needed, as the amount of hand-engineering needed is very minimal already.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The fact that CNE could be combined with such inferred structural properties increases its potential impact though, and this remark of the reviewer further underscores the need for methods such as CNE that can take such structural information into account.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The boost in accuracy achieved by CNE, using a model that is arguably also a lot simpler than the state-of-the-art network embedding approaches, is thus achieved without any increased need for hand-engineering.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for the insightful review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We updated the paper with better results and more tasks.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We show that our method outperforms the human baseline in terms of training speed and either matches or outperforms the human in terms of final accuracy on all tasks.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: While it is true that the human baseline does not require any additional computational resources for training, it does require domain expertise acquired through years of learning, which is arguably even more costly.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Notably, in all 4 problems where we compare to the human baseline, we believe that human researchers used a similar or higher number of runs as our tuner to design the baseline schedules that we compare against.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We also updated the paper with more details regarding Transformer and Proximal Policy Optimization.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Thank you for mentioning the existing learning curve modeling methods.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We added an explanation of differences of our method with those works.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: [1] learn a probabilistic model of one training curve using a handcrafted basis of nonlinear functions of shapes similar to the training curves being modelled.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Our method does not make any assumptions about the shape of the modelled curves and is able to jointly model many training curves - in our experiments, training and validation loss and accuracy.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: [2] learn a deterministic model of a learning curve, while our method also models stochasticity, hence providing diverse experience for training a reinforcement learning agent.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Also in contrast to [1] and [2], our method allows the hyperparameters to change over the course of training and models the influence of those changes on the training metrics.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: [1] Baker, Bowen, et al. "Accelerating neural architecture search using performance prediction." arXiv preprint arXiv:1705.10823 (2017).
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [2] Domhan, Tobias, Jost Tobias Springenberg, and Frank Hutter. "Speeding up automatic hyperparameter optimization of deep neural networks by extrapolation of learning curves." Twenty-Fourth International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence. 2015.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: Thank you for your constructive comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We are glad that you found our experiments extensive and that our approach provides significant improvements.
label: rebuttal_accept-praise

sentence: In response to your comment that "similar ideas have been undertaken (e.g., Mescheder et al 2018), but in different contexts" we would like to take this opportunity to clarify the novelty of our approach.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: First, with regards to (Mescheder et al 2018), our method is not simply the application of existing gradient penalties (GPs) in the context of semi-supervised learning.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Our approach is conceptually different since the regularizer proposed by (Mescheder et al 2018) is an (isotropic) ambient regularizer in the input space, whereas the regularizer we used performs (anisotropic) smoothing on the manifold parametrized by the latent generative model.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We believe we are the first to show the benefits of anisotropic Jacobian regularizers in the context of semi-supervised learning.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Moreover, an important contribution of our work is the efficient computation of such gradient penalties in the context of semi-supervised learning.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Current application of such penalties uses the exact Jacobian which is especially computationally expensive in the case of semi-supervised learning as it is now a tensor (one matrix per class in the case of Improved GAN), which quickly becomes intractable with large numbers of classes.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We proposed and demonstrated the effectiveness of an efficient (non-obvious) approximation of the Jacobian-based regularizer which significantly accelerates training.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We provide responses to further questions/comments below:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Q: "A comparison with Graph Convolutional Network based techniques seems appropriate (e.g. Kipf and Welling 2017)."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: Methods such as (Kipf and Welling 2017) are designed for semi-supervised learning on graphs; here a key challenge is in defining the structure (edges and edge weights) of the graph.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Defining the graph structure is not trivial for the image datasets commonly used as benchmarks.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: In this light, one of the advantages of our approach is that the manifold (graph structure) is implicitly learned by the GAN, thus avoiding the need to explicitly define it.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: That said, it is an interesting direction for future work and we thank the reviewer for the suggestion.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Q: "How do the FID/Inception improvements compare to (Mescheder et al 2018)?"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: We cannot directly compare our image generation scores with those reported in (Merscheder et al 2018) as we used different GAN architectures; for reference, they reported an Inception score of 6.2.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: We have updated the paper with Inception/FID scores from the ambient regularizer on CIFAR-10 (Table 4), which is an approximation of the proposed regularizer in (Merscheder et al. 2018) using stochastic finite differences.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: As mentioned earlier, it is not practical to compare the non-approximated regularizer due to the substantial increase in computational complexity in the semi-supervised GAN setting.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: We observe that ambient regularization gives better image generation scores; however it does not perform as well on semi-supervised learning.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This tradeoff between image generation and semi-supervised learning performance was previously reported in (Salimans et al., 2016) "Improved Methods for Training GANs".
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q: "It would be interesting to discuss why the FID score for SVHN gets worse in presence of 1000 labels."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: We re-checked our FID computation for this case and fixed a bug.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We have updated the paper with updated FID scores; we note there is a high variance in the FID so while there is an improvement on average, it occasionally may not be better.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Q: "Although there is a clear improvement in FID scores for Cifar10. It would be informative to show the generated images w/ and w/o manifold regularization."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: We have included generated images with and without manifold regularization in the Appendix (Figure A5 for CIFAR-10, Figure A6 for SVHN) - these show clear improvements as well.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Q: "More analysis should be provided on why (Kumar et al 2017) perform so well on SVHN."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: We note that although on average the method of (Kumar et al 2017) performs better on SVHN, the standard deviation is also much higher than many other methods (including ours) on both SVHN and CIFAR-10 indicating that it is not as robust.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q: "It should be stated that bold values in tables do not represent best results (as it is usually the case) but rather results for the proposed approach."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A: We have revised the tables such that bold values represent the best results for clarity.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Thank you for your comments and suggestions.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We will address the issues you mentioned.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1.	Thank you for the insightful suggestion.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We now have added related work about video compositional methods in section 2.3 in the second version of the paper.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: In the original version of the paper, all experiments are conducted on trimmed video classification datasets.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Although most papers in this field only report results on the trimmed video datasets, we do agree that more complicate cases should be tested.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Additionally, we evaluated our V4D for untrimmed video classification on ActivityNet v1.3, which contains videos of 5 to 10 minutes and typically large time lapses of the videos are not related with any activity of interest.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: The very competitive result is reported in the appendix of the second version of paper, which demonstrated the generalization and robustness of our V4D.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: In fact, unlike previous video compositional methods, even when local events are not well aligned or misclassified, long-term modelling with 4D convolution and video-level aggregation with global average pooling are very likely to correct the partial error.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3.About complexity, in the original version of the paper, we have reported parameters and FLOPs of V4D and compared it with other baseline methods in Table 2.

sentence: 4. We have already corrected the typo in title in the second version of the paper. Yet it seems that we are not able to modify the title on OpenReview. Thank you for pointing it out.

sentence: Hopefully our rebuttal could stress your concerns. If there are still any possible issues, please don’t hesitate to tell us and we will response as soon as possible.
