sentence: Thank you for your fruitful comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: One observation from the submission is that the token set may need to be very large (from tens of thousands to millions) for the system to work well, making the BERT training computationally expensive [...] I think some more motivation or exploration (what kind of information did BERT learn) is needed to understand why that is the case.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Our BERT vocabulary sizes (13.5k for the gumbel version and 23k for the k-means version) compare favorably to the setups commonly used in NLP where vocabularies are double or triple of our sizes.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We agree that it would be interesting to perform an in-depth analysis on the embeddings learned by BERT and we will investigate this in future work.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Here we focus on a new quantization method evaluated via downstream performance in phone and speech recognition settings by employing models that worked well (and were extensively tuned) in NLP contexts.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A more economical approach is to use BERT-trained model as initialization for acoustic model training, which is the classical way how RBMs pre-training were used in ASR.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Yes, this is an interesting avenue for future work!
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: We did not follow this direction due to two motivations: first, our aim is to contribute a new quantization scheme for audio data that is trained to predict the context in a self-supervised way.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Second, we wanted to show that good performance can be achieved with discretized audio on actual speech tasks.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: >> 3. One concern I have with discrete representation is how robust they are wrt different dataset.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We agree that an ablation study on robustness of the embeddings across different datasets would be very interesting.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Here we are mostly focusing on relatively clean data (WSJ, TIMIT, Librispeech) following the original wav2vec paper but we would be interested in exploring robustness in the future.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: However we note that representations transfer at least well across datasets from the “clean speech” domain: vq-wav2vec and BERT is only trained on Librispeech and never tuned on TIMIT/WSJ.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Another curious question is whether the features would still provide as much improvement when a stronger ASR system than AutoSeg (e.g., Lattice-free MMI) is used.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The original wav2vec paper (Schneider et al., 2019) reports better results than LF-MMI on the WSJ benchmark, however, the two setups are not strictly comparable.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In some sense, the LF-MMI result has an edge because it is based on a phoneme-based ASR system which is typically stronger than the character-based ASR system used with wav2vec.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We agree that evaluation on stronger baselines is an important future direction though.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: We would like to thank the reviewer for the time and useful feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Our response is given below.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - The paper is mainly empirical, although the authors compute two diagnostic statistics to show the effect of the self-modulation method.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: It is still not clear why self-modulation stabilizes the generator towards small conditioning values.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We consider self-modulation as an architectural change in the line of changes such as residual connections or gating: simple, yet widely applicable and robust.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: As a first step, we provide a careful empirical evaluation of its benefits.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: While we have provided some diagnostics statistics, understanding deeply why this method helps will fuel interesting future research.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Similar to residual connections, gating, dropout, and many other recent advances, more fundamental understanding will happen asynchronously and should not gate its adoption and usefulness for the community.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: - It should be pointed out that the D in the hinge loss represents a neural network output without range restriction, while the D in the non-saturating loss represents sigmoid output, limiting to take in [0,1].
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: It seems that the authors are not aware of this difference.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We are aware of this key difference and we apply the sigmoid function to scale the output of the discriminator to the [0,1] range for the non-saturating loss.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thanks for carefully reading our manuscript and noticing this typo which we will correct.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: - In addition to report the median scores, standard deviations should be reported.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We omitted standard errors simply to reduce clutter.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The standard error of the median is within 3% in the majority of the settings and is presented in both Tables 5 and Table 6.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for the detailed review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We appreciate your extremely useful pointers to existing dependency testing techniques, many of which are new to us. Before delving into them, here's our initial thoughts.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: First and foremost, we would like to know more details on the reasoning behind the rejection rating.
label: rebuttal_followup

sentence: It seems that the criticisms are on citations to other dependency testing approaches and time-dependency of fMRI data.
label: rebuttal_followup

sentence: The suggestions are invaluable and we'll gladly include them (work in progress).
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: But comparison with them is not apples to apples , so we are not sure to what extent that adds value to our work, where we already compared to the KSG estimator for MI estimation and Pearson's correlation for dependency testing.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Comparing to other dependency testing approaches, our technique allows the use of arbitrary neural networks and directly tests MI>0, the necessary and sufficient condition of dependency, is more general and is complementary to other techniques that make stronger assumptions about the data.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We want to point out that a simple and most widely used dependency testing technique is Pearson's correlation through test of linear correlation (sufficient condition of dependency), which we compared to and show that our technique provides complementary value on sine wave and the fMRI dataset.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We are aware that low sample complexity dependency tests exist and can be achieved by making additional assumptions on data, and we discussed that in the conclusion section, but our technique makes less assumptions and is applicable to general datasets which may not satisfy stricter assumptions.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We are very interested in the HSIC-based techniques which seem to be popular and we could show complementarity. But at the same time the conclusion will be the same, so we have question on what value does it add for the audience over Pearson's correlation.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Regarding other methods for dependency testing through mutual information, after following the line of work by Barrett et al. 2017, we reached this concise summary http://ims-vilnius2018.com/content/pdf/ivc293.pdf, which explains the smoothness assumptions made to data, as well as the fact that they used an asymptotic variance which holds when a large number of samples is given (page 2 top).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: It implies that the resulting confidence intervals as well as the test results are asymptotic and not guaranteed, which puts the resulting statistical tests into question.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have to admit that we did not thoroughly understand this line of work because of our background, so please comment if we are wrong about that.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Instead, our dependency test does not make assumptions about data.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our lower bound and its confidence interval are not asymptotic.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Theorem 1 provides a guaranteed confidence interval for arbitrary number of samples (so do our baselines, MINE and Pearson's r).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We compared with the KSG estimator, which also only has asymptotic confidence intervals in literature.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In addition, the proof provided in our work is concise and is easy for readers to understand and verify.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Regarding time dependence and test threshold, it's important and thanks for pointing it out! We think that there are two ways time affects dependency listed below.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 1) First, we assume non-overlapping windows of TRs as the basis for computing number of i.i.d fMRI samples, but did not mention that in our current draft. We'll update and make it clear.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2) Second, we can see an argument on whether or not segments of fMRI signals qualify as i.i.d, although not sure if this is a problem for our MI estimation approach.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If things change very little from one second to the next, the signals could be very similar and may not really be, intuitively, independent samples and may bias result of the study.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, which independence assumptions to use is not in scope for our paper, because our fMRI study is trying to show that dependency testing works and is complementary to Pearson's correlation, not so much on drawing neuroscience conclusions.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: On a side note, it may turn out that which independence assumptions to make is a deeper question that doesn't yet have a clear answer.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Regarding the level of the test, our theorem 1 already provides a proof based on Hoeffding inequality.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This proof could be experimentally verified through computing MI on 300 test set samples and see how the estimate changes if there were >1million test set samples, repeat say 1000 times using different random seeds.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their comments and for noting correctly that our modification is quite effective, particularly regarding the large improvements on human evaluations.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Our method is simpler in both conception and implementation than coverage, while requiring less parameters and being twice as likely to be chosen as better by human judges.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We agree with the reviewer on the simplicity of our method, which we believe to be an asset.
label: rebuttal_accept-praise

sentence: In addition to that, we believe the Scratchpad Encoder is fundamentally interesting as a mirror to the ‘attentive read’ common in seq2seq models.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We also appreciate the reviewer taking their time to draw our attention to how to better emphasize the novelty and simplicity of our work.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We would like to thank the reviewer for the comments and for raising some subtle yet important questions.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We address and clarify specific comments below.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We have also made corresponding changes in the revised paper, and have added a proof map, in addition to the Table 3, for easier navigation of the results.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: We have also added comparisons with Mairal `09, and experimental evaluation of computational time.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: 1. Noise Tolerance — NOODL also has similar tolerance to noise as Arora et. al. 2015 and can be used in noisy settings as well.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We focus on the noiseless case here to convey the main idea, since the analysis is already very involved.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Nevertheless, the proposed algorithm can tolerate i.i.d. sub-Gaussian noise, including Gaussian noise and bounded noise, as long as the ``noise’’ is dominated by the ``signal’’.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Under the noisy case, the recovered dictionary and coefficients will converge to a neighborhood of the true factors, where the neighborhood is defined by the properties of the additive noise.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In other words, the noise terms will lead to additional terms which will need to be controlled for the convergence analysis.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Specifically, the noise will add a term to the coefficient update in Lemma 2, and will effect the threshold, tau.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For the dictionary, the noise will result in additional terms in Lemma 9 (which ensures that the updated dictionary maintains the closeness property).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A precise characterization of the relationship between the level of noise the size of convergence neighborhood requires careful analysis, which we defer to future effort.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: 2. On eps_t and A.4. —  Indeed, we don’t need to assume that eps_t is bounded.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Specifically, using the result of Lemma 7, we have that eps_0 undergoes a contraction at every step, therefore, eps_t <= eps_0.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: For our analysis we fix eps_t = O^*(1/log(n)), which follows from the assumption on eps_0= O^*(1/log(n)) and Lemma 7.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: On reviewer’s comments, we have updated A.4., and moved the note about eps_t = O^*(1/log(n)) to the Appendix A.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 3. Exact recovery of factors — Also, we would like to point that NOODL recovers both the dictionary and coefficients exactly at a geometric rate.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This means that as t—> infinity both the dictionary and coefficients estimates converge to the true factors without incurring any bias.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We have added a clarification corresponding to this in the revised paper in Section 1.1 and after the statement of Theorem 1 in Section 3.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Thank you for your thoughtful review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We appreciate that you think our problem and approach are interesting! We have made some substantial revisions to clarify the presentation, we hope that these will help address your concerns.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We respond to some specific comments below:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: > No comparisons were provided to any baselines/alternative methods.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We do compare to a number of lesions in the supplement, and to an alternative method (performing tasks from a description alone).
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: We have moved this latter comparison to the main text at the suggestion of Reviewer 1.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: > in Sections 4 and 5 I was hoping to see comparisons to methods like MAML.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Also, I felt that the proposed approach in Section 5 is very similar to MAML intuitively.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: This makes a comparison with MAML even more desirable. Without any comparisons it’s hard to tell how difficult the tasks under consideration are and what would amount to good performance on the held-out tasks.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Our main contribution is to propose a meta-mapping framework for zero-shot task performance, and parsimonious method for performing these meta-mappings.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: MAML as such is not a method of zero-shot task performance, it requires examples to learn
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: from
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: We could therefore compare to MAML for our basic-meta-learning results, but those are simply a sanity check.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: We also compare to a variety of baselines, including chance and optimal performance, untransformed representations, and the most correlated task experienced (in the cards domain).
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: However, if our paper is accepted, and you feel that the comparison to MAML for basic meta-learning is useful, we will run MAML on our tasks before the camera-ready submission.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: One might take inspiration from our framework try to use MAML for zero-shot task performance by transforming task representations would require adopting our meta-mapping framework, as well as a number of ideas of our architecture (where do the task representations come from, and how are they used?), and so its not clear to us that this is an appropriate baseline, rather than simply another implementation of our technique.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Instead, we feel the more appropriate baseline is performing tasks from a natural language description, as many prior zero-shot works have, and so we have moved this result to the main text, as noted above.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: > The experimental results presented were all done on small synthetic datasets and it’s hard to evaluate whether the method is practically useful.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We already have more material than fits in this paper, especially now that we have added clarifications that all reviewers requested.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We remained with synthetic tasks for two reasons: 1) to illustrate the method in settings we thought would be clearer, 2) because as we highlight in the future directions, there is a lack of meta-learning datasets that contain as structured of relationships between tasks as we consider.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: (Taskonomy, for example, has at best a notion of "similarity" in terms of transfer.) We are working on creating several such datasets, but we think that this paper as it stands is a useful contribution that illustrates the concept and ideas -- the datasets themselves will also require further description, and including them in a paper of this length would likely result in even more material being cut, and so a less clear presentation.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We do think this is an important direction, but we think this paper makes a useful contribution by highlighting this new perspective. We hope that you agree.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: > Also, the work by Platanios, et al. on contextual parameter generation is very relevant to this work as it tackles multi-task learning using HyperNetworks.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: It may be worth adding a short discussion/comparison to that work as it also considers zero-shot learning.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thanks, we weren't familiar with this very interesting work! We have added a reference and a brief discussion of the relationship.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: - Capitalize: “section” -> “Section”, “appendix” -> “Appendix”, “fig.” -> “Figure”.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Sometimes these are capitalized, but the use is inconsistent throughout the paper.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thanks for pointing this out, fixed.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: - “Hold-out” vs “held-out”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Be consistent and use “held-out” throughout.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We are making a grammatical distinction here -- "held-out" is an adjective and "hold-out" is a noun. That is, one might refer to a "held-out task" or to a "a hold-out." Hopefully this clarifies things.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: We hope that this clarifies things, and will help to address your concerns. Please let us know if further changes would be useful.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Many thanks for the detailed review!
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: 1/ We agree that there are many elements of our architecture that are similar to that of a convolutional network, however the network does not perform convolutions.
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: To reflect both points, we have revised the text to:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: ``The network does not use convolutions.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Instead, the network does have pixelwise linear combinations of channels, and just like in a convolutional neural network the weights are
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: are shared among spatial positions.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Nonetheless, they are not convolutions because they provide no spatial coupling between pixels, despite how pixelwise linear combinations are sometimes called `1x1 convolutions.' '',
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: and we have also added a subsection comparing the compression performance of our architecture to that of a decoder with convolution layers.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In a sense, what the deep decoder is doing is separating multiple roles that proper convolutional layers fill:  the DD breaks apart the spatial coupling inherent to convolutions from their channel dependence and equivariance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Further, it says that the spatial coupling need not be learned or fit to data, and can be directly imposed by upsampling.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2/ Yes, the upsampling analysis in Figure 5 also extends to two-dimensional images.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We agree that natural images are only approximately piece-wise smooth after all, and the deep decoder only provides an approximation of natural images (albeit a very good one).
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: 3/ We agree and have changed `batch normalization' to `channel normalization' throughout.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: 4/ Great point; we have added the sentence ``The optimal $k$ trades off those two errors; larger noise levels require smaller values of $k$ (or some other form of regularization).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: If the noise is significantly larger, then the method requires either choosing $k$ smaller, or it requires another means of regularization, for example early stopping of the optimization.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For example $k=64$ or $128$ performs best out of $\{32,64,128\}$, for a PSNR of around 20dB, while for a PSNR of about 14dB, $k=32$ performs best.''
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 5/ We do not mention the standard deviation, but do specify the SNR throughout (e.g., in table 1 in column identity).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have clarified this in the caption of the table.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 6/ It essentially produces smooth noise then.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The weights learned by the deep decoder pertain to the source noise tensor.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have added a corresponding figure to the jupyter notebook for reproducing Figure 6.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the insightful comments.

sentence: - "I don't see a discussion about the downsides of the method"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: One of the drawbacks is that our method needs GPUs, while the more traditional algorithms run on CPUs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This can be of disadvantage if non-machine learning experts want to use our method.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, this is the case for most recent ML methods based on neural nets.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The number of required triplets is theoretically lower bounded by nd log n, and this is also being confirmed by our experiments (our algorithm, as well as our competitors, break down when they get fewer triplets).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Therefore, in a setting with passive triplet answers, and without extra information, it is impossible to overcome this problem.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - "in section 4.4
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: when comparing the proposed approach with another method why not use more complex datasets (like those used in section 4.3)"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Independent of the dataset complexity, provided with enough triplet answers, all methods can yield less than 5% triplet error.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, the computation time is significantly lower for our proposed method.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Due to the iterative nature of all algorithms, the computation time does not depend on the data distribution, but on the number of input points.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thus, a simple uniform dataset could serve to show our intention in this section.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - "in section 4.3, there is no guarantee that the intersection between the training set and the test set is empty."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Yes, in theory that is true, but in practice this is negligible: the total number of possible triplets is about 10^9. So the likelihood that two sets of size 1000 intersect is close to 0.

sentence: - "in section 4.3
label: rebuttal_structuring

label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The colors are the initial labels of the input items.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: There are two or three labels assigned to demonstrate the quality of reconstruction.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Note that the ordinal embedding output is unique only up to isometric transforms.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q4: “From figure 2 it's not clear why all non-zero connections in (b) are then equally weighted in (c). Would keeping the non-zero weightings be at all helpful?”

sentence: A4: In the search stage, the scaling factors are only used to indicate which operators should be pruned.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The value of scaling factors do not represent the importances of kept operators since they can be merged into the weights of convolution.

sentence: We also add experiments in CIFAR-10 to compare the performance between keeping the non-zero weightings and equal weightings.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: The result shows that both of them yield similar performances.

sentence: 1. We aimed to provide a broad variety of example applications (playing tennis, walking, fencing, dancing), while mainly focusing on the most complicated (tennis) application, for a thorough analysis of our method.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Unfortunately, we cannot release the dataset, since we do not own the videos, but we will share our code.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: 2. The Pose2Pose and Pose2Frame networks are trained separately.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Specifically, the P2F network is trained on the original data, and not on the output frames of the P2P network.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: You are correct that some artifacts are added to the final P2F output at test time, yet they are minor due to the structural stability of the poses generated by the P2P network.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Furthermore, training the P2F network with the P2P outputs is problematic, since we do not have the ground-truth for the new pose generated by the P2P network.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: 3. The mask loss proposed in the review is similar to our implementation, except that we make a distinction between an inner-mask control and an outer-mask control.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our mask regression losses consist of a first loss penalizing the mask from being active outside the densepose mask, and a second loss penalizing the mask from being inactive inside the densepose mask.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Combining them both results in the suggested loss.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Responses:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - We clarified the unclear parts, and will upload the revised version asap. (Also see below for specific responses.)
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: - It is unclear to us if the reviewer thinks the computational complexity is high, or the mathematical complexity.
label: rebuttal_followup

label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Thus, we assume computational complexity is meant.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Computational complexity is discussed in detail in the manuscript though, and is certainly not higher than competing methods (in part thanks to the low mathematical complexity of the model).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: See also next point.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: To demonstrate CNE's superior scalability, we included another network with around 200.000 nodes and around 1.000.000 edges (http://snap.stanford.edu/data/loc-Gowalla.html), run on a basic single CPU laptop.

sentence: Detailed comments:
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: - "In the introduction, "it is in general impossible to find an embedding in R^d such that ...", [...]?"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We apologize for having been a bit brief here, we will clarify this in the revision (uploaded asap).
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We meant to say that in network embedding methods that aim to model first-order proximity (where proximity in the embedding space implies a higher probability of being linked), this is a requirement (otherwise, proximity of v and v' would imply they are likely to be linked).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thus our argument only applies to such first-order proximity methods.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Methods that aim to model second-order proximities (where proximity in the embedding space implies a greater overlap between the sets of adjacent nodes), however, are similarly vulnerable.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For example, there can be a 50% overlap (which is highly significant in sparse networks) between the neighborhoods of nodes A and B, as well as between the neighborhoods of nodes B and C, but zero overlap between the neighborhoods of nodes A and C.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This would mean that nodes A and B need to be embedded close to each other, nodes B and C as well, but nodes A and C distant from each other.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The triangle inequality makes this hard.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Finally, these are but examples of how a Euclidean embedding on its own lacks representational power.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We believe that our empirical results also demonstrate this without having to refer to easy-to-identify problematic situations for pure embedding-based methods.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - "In Equation (2), How is P_ij defined exactly [...]?"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: They are not parameters: they are numbers between 0 and 1 representing the prior probability of a link between nodes i and j (i.e. prior to seeing the embedding).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: These numbers are such that the prior knowledge of the types described are satisfied in expectation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In other words, they are implied and can be computed automatically and highly efficiently based on prior work, after one has decided on which prior knowledge to use.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For details about how P_ij are fitted given such prior knowledge constraints, and how they can be represented efficiently, we have to refer to Adriaens et al. (2017) and van Leeuwen et al. (2016).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have however summarized the relevant aspects: the fact that all probabilities P_ij, although there are n^2 of them, can be represented using much fewer parameters, and the fact that they can be fitted highly efficiently (in our experiments, even on the largest networks, this always took only a tiny proportion of the total computation time).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In the new version to be uploaded soon, this will be further clarified.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: - "In Equation (6), the posterior distribution should be P(X|G) [...]?"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: No, the equation is correct as stated.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Footnote 2 warned the reader about this, as we know it is unusual.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: The posterior is a distribution for the network, such that finding the best embedding is indeed a maximum likelihood problem (not a maximum a posteriori problem), even though the likelihood function is computed as a posterior given a prior for the network and a conditional for the embedding given the network.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We suspect that it is this unusual aspect of the CNE formulation that makes it original with respect to the state-of-the-art.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: - "In Table 2 and 3, how are [...]?"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Equation (6) defines the posterior of the network given the embedding, which we maximize w.r.t. the embedding.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: It explicitly depends on the prior probabilities P_ij, which are computed based on the prior knowledge about the degrees or about the block density structure of the adjacency matrix.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thus, this information is brought into the model by considering the posterior distribution for the network, where the prior models the degrees of the nodes, or the block structure.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We would like to thank Reviewer 3 for the review and constructive suggestions.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Our responses inline:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: >it would be nice to also propose unconditioned experiments.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -We agree; this was simply not within the scope of the work we conducted.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: >I understand that no data augmentation was used during training?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -This is correct, and consistent with previous works (Spectral Normalization and WGAN-GP).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We briefly experimented with data augmentation (random crops and horizontal flips) but did not notice any measurable performance difference.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: >clarification of the truncation trick: if the elements of z are re-sampled and are still above the threshold, are they re-sampled again and again until they are all below the given threshold?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -Yes, this can effectively be seen as modifying the PDF of z to have no mass outside of the truncation threshold.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: TensorFlow offers a built-in implementation with tf.random.truncated_normal.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: >A sentence could be added to explain the truncation trick in the abstract directly since it is simple to understand and is key to the quality of the results.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -We have revised the abstract to explain the truncation trick as controlling the tradeoff between fidelity and diversity by reducing the variance of the Generator’s input.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: >A reference to Appendix C could be given at the beginning of the Experiments section to help the reader find these details more easily.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -Thanks for the pointer! We have added this reference.

sentence: Thank you very much for your supportive remark! We are happy that the writing is clear to you. Below we provide additional comments regarding your questions.
label: rebuttal_accept-praise

sentence: 1). Low-rank assumption:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: This work was primarily motivated by the observation that many systems exhibit strong relationship among states and actions, governed by potentially simple dynamics.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This might eventually lead to structures within the optimal solution.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We hope that this empirical study would motivate further theoretical analysis on structures within the community.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Below are some thoughts on the potential theoretical motivation for this assumption:
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: a) It is possible that the states and actions in consideration have some latent variable representations.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If the optimal Q function is a piecewise analytic function on the latent variables, then there are works arguing the approximately low-rank property of the resulting matrix [1].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: b) There are theoretical works in RL and Markov process that assume that the transition kernel can be decomposed to a low-dimensional feature representation [2,3].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: These assumptions on the transition kernel may lead to low-rank optimal Q matrices.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: c) For continuous problems, theoretical analysis often needs to assume some sort of smoothness in the Q function [4,5].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: It is possible that such smoothness in the Q function will result in a low-rank Q matrix when evaluated at finite but fine enough discretized grid.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: [1] Udell, Madeleine, and Alex Townsend. "Why Are Big Data Matrices Approximately Low Rank?." SIAM Journal on Mathematics of Data Science 1.1 (2019): 144-160.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: [2] Yang, Lin, and Mengdi Wang. "Sample-Optimal Parametric Q-Learning Using Linearly Additive Features." International Conference on Machine Learning. 2019.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: [3] Sun, Yifan, et al. "Learning low-dimensional state embeddings and metastable clusters from time series data." Neural Information Processing Systems 2019.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: [4] Yang, Zhuora, Yuchen Xie, and Zhaoran Wang. "A theoretical analysis of deep Q-learning." arXiv preprint arXiv:1901.00137(2019).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: [5] Shah, Devavrat, and Qiaomin Xie. "Q-learning with nearest neighbors." Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems. 2018.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2). Dynamical manner for the number of incomplete observations and whether the strategy can be adapted to the nature of the problem:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: This is a great point and definitely an interesting future direction.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: In the current work, it is not immediately that one could easily detect the rank and adapt the algorithm in a principled manner.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: As one practical solution, it may be possible to dynamically adjust the regularization in a manner similar to cross validation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: At each step, for the submatrix, one could randomly sample a portion of the entries for ME, while keeping another fraction of the remaining entries as a validation set.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If the recovered matrix via ME has a low reconstruction error on the validation set, it is likely that a suitable low-rank approximation is sufficient and has been found by the ME oracle.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In contrast, if the reconstruction error is large, the algorithm might have been too aggressive on finding a low-rank solution while a higher rank solution is indeed necessary.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: As such, one could then adjust the algorithm to increase the number of observations for ME or try to reduce the level of low-rank regularization.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The above cross validation scheme might be an interesting complement to our current approach.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Overall, we believe that principally solving those questions you posted are meaningful and important directions that worth further investigations.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3). Beyond the low-rank assumption and use a more elaborate type of prior:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thank you for your inspiring advice.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Without any elaborate prior information, rank is a natural point to study the global property of a matrix.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In principle, understanding structures in MDP could also be potentially explored, and we believe that it is possible to extend to other types of scenarios with prior information about the MDPs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, at the current stage, we do not have a particularly systematic approach to explore more elaborate type of structures in MDPs.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: While this paper is focusing on low-rank structures, as the reviewer noted, there can be other structures to be explored.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: We hope that our paper could serve as an example, and further motivates future studies for exploiting structures in MDP.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: 4). Notation in Section 4.2:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thank you for the suggestion.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We will expand the definition of the notation to make them clearer.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Thank you for the comments!
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: To review’s questions:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - As the experimental results shows, with position information alone, the agent is able to learn to push or pick up the object, therefore we consider position information alone (without velocity information) is sufficient in our case.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - For MISC, the method needs to know what are the states of interests and what are the context state.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: While, the states of interest can be any states that users are interested in, such as a part of the robot states or the object states.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The context states are some other states, which are different from the states of interest.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In robotic tasks, the states of the robot and the object states are normally available [Andrychowicz et al 2018, Plappert et al 2018].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: To automatically detect the state of interests and the context states, we can train the agent with random state splits and then chose the combination, which is suitable for the tasks at hand.
label: rebuttal_answer

label: rebuttal_structuring

Multi-goal reinforce- ment learning: Challenging robotics environments and request for research. arXiv preprint arXiv:1802.09464, 2018.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - Yes, MISC can deal with the case, when there are multiple objects of interest.

sentence: We added new experiments showing the agent can learn to manipulate two balls.
label: rebuttal_answer

label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The experimental results are shown in the new video at https://youtu.be/l5KaYJWWu70?t=148, where we show that a robot car can learn to manipulate two balls in the same episode.

sentence: - Equation (4) is not the mutual information between two trajectories of states.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: It is an estimation of mutual information between two sets of states. And the states are sampled from the same trajectory.

sentence: Therefore, we do not need to decompose Equation (4) to evaluate Equation (3).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - We add the experimental details in the Appendix.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: - The discriminator is trained along with the policy.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For example, in the case that we update the agent 200 times in each epoch, then we also update the MISC 200 times per epoch.

sentence: For more detailed information, please refer to our code at https://github.com/misc-project/misc
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - Compared to the dense reward, with the negative L2 distance between the robot and the object, the robot can only learn to reach the object but will not learn to push or pick up the object because when the robot reaches the object, the negative L2 distance is already zero.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, MISC has the advantage that it not only enables the agent to learn to reach but also learn to push and pick & place.

sentence: - If we train the MISC and DIAYN at the same time, the DIAYN reward might be dominant. Subsequently, The agent might not learn to control the states of interests with MISC.

label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The main difference is that MISC-p uses the estimated mutual information quantity as a priority, while PER uses the TD-error as a priority for replay.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Reference:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Tom Schaul, John Quan, Ioannis Antonoglou, and David Silver. Prioritized experience replay. In International Conference on Learning Representations, 2016.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - We first scale the intrinsic and the extrinsic reward between 0 and 1 and then use equal weights for these two rewards.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - For the opposite situation, we can use negative mutual information rewards to encourage the agent to learn to “avoid” some objects.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - The discriminator uses the same amount of (s,a,s') experience as VIME consumes because the discriminator is fixed after pre-training.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: VIME can only be trained along with the policy.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: VIME cannot be pre-trained, otherwise, it won’t detect novel states.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - Transfer the learned discriminator from Push to the Pick&Place should still help the agent to learn the pick & place task because the transferred discriminator will help the agent to learn to reach the object at least. As long as the state inputs for the discriminator are the same, then MI discriminator can be transferred among different tasks.

sentence: We thank the reviewer for his comments and observations.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Following are the answers to each question you have raised.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: R1Q1(a): “The classification of base class into super classes seems questionable to me.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In the meta-learning language, the author attempts to learn a good representation of graphs
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: based on different graph classification tasks generated by a task distribution
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In terms of graph classification, the task distribution is supported on the joint distributions (G, Y).”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: R1A1(a): Our model has two major components, $C^{sup}$ (for super-class prediction) and $C^{GAT}$ (for graph label prediction).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: During the training phase of our classification, $C^{sup}$, which is a MLP layer, learns the super-class labels of the samples based on GIN’s extracted feature vectors (which represent base class labeled graphs).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: While, $C^{GAT}$ takes as input the “graph of graphs” (supergraph) which models the latent inter-class as well as intra-class information and is constructed in every training batch, along with base-class labels, to learn the associated class distribution.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Then, during the fine-tuning phase on graphs with novel class labels, the feature extractor’s (GIN) parameters are fixed and $C^{sup}$ is used to infer the super-class label of the novel class labeled graphs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Then, the parameters learned by $C^{GAT}$ get updated and further “fine-tuned” for better performance on the novel samples.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In addition to our brief overview, you could also find a very neatly detailed summarization of our method in reviewer 2’s comments (paragraphs 1-4).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The meta-learning framework, where batches are sampled as “episodes” with N-way K-shot setting, does not perform as well in our few-shot setting on graphs for the following reasons:
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 1) We have very limited total number of training classes (in order of 10s), when compared to the image domain (order of 100s and 1000s).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This limitation hampers learning across tasks and generalization to new unseen tasks.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2) In each of our batches, we randomly sample a fixed-size of training samples belonging to the set of N labels chosen.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Therefore, when building our supergraph, we end up with k-NN graphs of “variable size” per super-class, compared to fixed size (K nodes) k-NN graphs that we would have got using episodic learning.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We suspect this further allows our GAT to learn and generalize better to unseen graphs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Furthermore, in [1], the authors use a similar strategy in their “baseline++” method and produce good results.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Their findings are also in sync with our empirical finding.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: [1] Chen et~al. “A closer look at Few-Shot Classification”, ICLR 2019
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: R1Q1(b): Hence, to characterize different tasks, as far as I am concerned, the classification should take both the graph G and the label Y into consideration, instead of solely the graph.”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: R1A1(b): In every batch of graphs during both training and fine-tuning phase, each graph is associated with its corresponding graph label.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: In case of training, its a base-class and in the case of fine-tuning its a novel class
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: In the case of $C^{GAT}$, the graph is accompanied by a regular class label and in case of $C^{sup}$, the graph is accompanied by a superclass label.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: R1Q2: “Though seemingly very important to the architecture, the purpose of constructing the super-graph $g^{sup}$ in the training of $C^{CAT}$ seems to be unclear to me.”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: R1A2: What makes few-shot learning particularly difficult compared to common machine learning settings is the dearth of training examples, which results in a bad empirical risk approximation for the expected risk and therefore gives rise to an empirical risk minimizer that is sub-optimal.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Reducing the required sample complexity can result in a better empirical risk minimizer.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Therefore, given a very large space of hypotheses H, our goal is to further restrict and constrain H using some prior knowledge because a reduced H has reduced sample complexity and thus requires fewer training samples to be trained.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We provide this “prior knowledge” in the form of a “graph of graphs”, namely our super-graph $g^{sup}$, which captures both the latent inter-class and intra-class relationships between classes.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Observe that in $g^{sup}$, we build a k-NN graph PER super-class, restricting any flow of information between super-classes, thus further restricting H. We force our model to jointly learn both the superclass and graph class labels.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This way similar classes (grouped under a superclass) together contribute to learning a general prior representing the superclasses and each superclass also provides “guidance” to better train with the few samples assigned to that superclass.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The introduction of this prior knowledge in the form of a supergraph in $C^{GAT}$ during training also helps generalize better to the novel samples that are presented to our model in the fine-tuning stage.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Additionally, we would also like to draw attention to the supergraph usage summary provided by reviewer 2 in paragraph 3 of their comments.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their time and welcome feedback, which we are incorporating into the revised version.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: R: - "important features for the new task should be in similar locations ..."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - "the locations for important features should be comparatively stable ..."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -- Continual learning typically assumes a degree of similarity among the tasks.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: If tasks are completely different from each other, then most continual learning frameworks will somehow struggle.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: For example, the standard Split MNIST benchmark is in line with this “locations of important features” assumption.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Having said that, we acknowledge that more agility to, at least, discover that early on would be beneficial.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: More importantly, a normalization strategy on top of our attention map would help enhance its invariance properties, potentially leading to a more robust treatment of the locations of important features.

sentence: R: - FSM vs. Classification performance

label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: -- It is true that evaluating the FSM is not necessarily the same as the classification results, which is precisely the reason why we show both in our results.

sentence: As specified in page 2, “Here we propose a new measure ...” - our point in this regard is to propose another (different) manner via which catastrophic forgetting can be estimated, which is not the same as the classification accuracy.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The goal is that (as we know and agree they are two different measures that might agree or disagree in their judgments on catastrophic forgetting) both can be used to inspect the degree of catastrophic forgetting.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We have further clarified that in Section 6.2 in the experiments by stressing that the obtained FSM results “along with the classification results” denote the significance of the whole framework in addressing catastrophic forgetting.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: It is definitely a good idea to analyse the correlation between changes in classification accuracy and in FSM values, thank you. We will rigorously investigate this in future work.

sentence: We thank our third reviewer for his comment.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We do understand your concern about the significant increase in computational time.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: However, we believe that in the context of active learning, the main problem is not related to computational power, rather to the scarcity of data.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Therefore, a better way of making the most out of little data is critical.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Thank you for your thorough assessment and helpful comments! To answer your two questions:
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: 1) Upper bound
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: You are right that it would be ideal to optimize the target loss L_T(h, f_T) directly.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: However, this is not possible because we do not have labelled target data (i.e., f_T is unknown).
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Minimizing an upper bound is arguably the only viable option *with theoretical generalization guarantee*. It is a common practice in the domain adaptation community (Mansour et al., 2009a, 2009b; Ben-David et al. 2007, 2010; Cortes and Mohri, 2011), and it is essentially the key idea of PAC learning and generalization analysis (Györfi et al., 2006; Schölkopf et al., 2002; Vapnik, 2013).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Besides, our method *directly* optimizes the upper bound without resorting to heuristics, unlike prior methods.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: A : We apologize to the reviewer for the lack of clarity in the manuscript.

sentence: Regarding the details on hyper-parameters:
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - We set parameters as follows.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The number of training iteration and thresholding epsilon are very important parameters in our algorithm and have a considerable correlation with each other.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In the first experiment, the iteration number remains fixed and the growth rate of epsilon is adjusted so that the validation accuracy saturates near the settled iteration number.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: While the validation accuracy is evaluated using the cross-validation, we set the number of training iteration to be 100 so that the model is trained enough until it saturates.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Epsilon is increased in log-scale and begins at a very small value (10^(−5)) where no data is added.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The growth rate of epsilon is determined according to when the validation accuracy saturates.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The stopping criterion is that the accuracy of the current iteration reaches the average accuracy of the previous 20 steps.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If the stopping iteration is much less than 100 times, the epsilon growth rate should be reduced so that the data is added more slowly.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If the stopping iteration significantly exceeds 100 iterations, the epsilon growth rate should be increased so that the data is added more easily.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We allow 5 iterations as a deviation from 100 iterations and the growth rate of epsilon is left unchanged in this interval.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (In previous versions, the growth ratio of epsilon for CIFAR-10 was applied to SVHN and CIFAR-100.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: "The purpose of generative models is not to interpolate per se; the interpolation is really a sanity check that the model is capturing the underlying distribution rather than just memorizing training examples.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The function composition doesn't capture that.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: I think the authors should just acknowledge that you can't soundly *sample* from their generative model the way e.g. VAE or GAN allows (their function composition is not a sampling method).
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: But I think there are lots of useful things you can do without that capability, e.g. do 3D point cloud completion, go image -> structure, etc. I think this function composition angle should be deemphasized in the title/abstract, but I think the paper stands  reasonably on its own without that."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We agree that the current formulation of composition is not equivalent to a generative model.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: In our work, function composition primarily serves the purpose of demonstrating that the model learns a meaningful subspace of objects (rather than memorizing the training set, as you mentioned).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We have revised the abstract to clarify this point.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: "In Figure 2 it's pretty hard to see the differences between the methods. What exactly is being visualized here? DeepSDF shold be visualizing surface normals vs. HOF which is point clouds, right?"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We have clarified in the manuscript that our comparisons are between architectures, rather than training objectives/output representations.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Thus our DeepSDF, FoldingNet, and HOF architectures all output point clouds, which can be compared directly.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: "For predicting a deformation R^3 -> R^3 function composition sort of makes sense, but how generalizable is this approach e.g. to directly predicting a function R^3 -> R (a la DeepSDF)? I think there are ways this function composition approach could generalize, e.g. using skip connections and layer dropout (which encourages layers to be composable)."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Additional techniques for promoting learning of composable representations such as skip connections and layer dropout are an exciting direction for future research.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: One way function composition might allow for R^3 -> R mappings by composing a mapping from R^3 -> R^3 and taking the only first dimension of each element in the final output.

sentence: We also do think that the problem setting we have proposed is an important problem that deserves attention, and has not been studied in the meta-learning paradigm.

sentence: We have identified a novel problem setting, which is closer to the real world setting, than what has been studied so far under the meta-learning paradigm.

sentence: Existing solutions are not effective in this setting, restricting their use in the real world.

label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Specifically, we identify that the principle of image-to-image translation is very suitable for this setting, and apply those concepts to boost the performance of few-shot learning under domain shift.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: As a combination of problem setting and proposed solution, we do believe we have addressed an important problem, and made a novel contribution.

sentence: See for example some of the recent domain adaptation papers [1, 2, 3].
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: While a feature extractor backbone network may have some influence, we would like to highlight three points.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: First, when networks are trained in one domain, and evaluated in another, regardless of the backbone network, it is the domain-shift that dominates the performance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For example, no matter how large the network is, if it is trained to recognize black and white digits, it will still struggle to recognize colored digits.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Second, any benefit of a larger backbone network will likely also enhance the performance of our model.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Third, we just wanted to clarify (if there was a misunderstanding), unlike domain adaptation papers, we do not use a pretrained network – we train the full network from scratch (following traditional meta-training settings).
