label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Actually, for training A-CNN (Augmented CNN), we did not train it on every variation of out-distribution cases, rather, we recognize a single representative out-distribution set among the available ones according to our measurement.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Then using it for training A-CNN with the aim of effectively controlling over-generalization.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The reviewer mentioned: “ Also, one simple way to stop these adversarial cases would be to explore using Sigmoid as opposed to softmax”:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We would be appreciated if the reviewer could provide us with the references that showing using only sigmoid could control such a challenging problem of adversaries.
label: rebuttal_followup

sentence: Please note we did not aim to devise a method that is able to reject all adversaries.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Rather, we attempted to show that a CNN with less over-generalization is able to reject some of the adversaries while correctly classifies many of the remainder, particularly non-transferable attacks.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Thank you very much for your encouraging review and helpful comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We will make revisions to address the several points you have raised in your review.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Below we first address the main concerns.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Q1: “Alt-az” rotation is not a group.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A1: Thank you for pointing this out.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: You are correct.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: The Alt-az rotation, according to our definition, is not a group.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: SO(3)  is a group which can be parametrized by a 3-sphere .
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: But when we reduce one parameter from it, it is not a group anymore mathematically; the composition of two alt-az rotations becomes a general rotation in SO(3).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In the new revision, we will use the term alt-az rotation in “quotient SO(3)/SO(2)”  instead of alt-az rotation group.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Moreover, the quotient SO(3)/SO(2) is isomorphic to $S^2$ and to avoid the ill-definition on the two poles (the two degenerate points), we will add a constraint to the alt-az rotation, i.e. $\phi=0, if \theta=0 or \theta=\pi$. This is because, when the altitude rotation is zero or PI, the azimuth rotation is meaningless in a alt-az rotation and is therefore fixed as zero.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: If $\theta=0 or \theta=pi, and “\phi \neq 0$, this rotation belongs to the azimuthal rotation in SO(2) group.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: (Q2) Equivariance property of the Alt-az convolution
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We think we can still have the equivariance property but only for single alt-az rotation.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Notice the definition of alt-az convolution do not use any composite rotation.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Here is our tentative proof:
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: Under the definition of alt-azimuth anisotropic convolution and using the unitary property (5) of rotation operators, we have (assume the number of channels K=1 for simplicity, assume Q and R be both alt-az rotations):
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: \begin{equation}
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: \begin{aligned}
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: & (h \star D_{Q} f) (R)
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: = \int_{S^2}(D_Rh)(\hat{u})f(Q^{-1}\hat{u})ds(\hat{u}) \\
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: =\int_{S^2}h(R^{-1}Q\hat{u})f(\hat{u})ds(\hat{u}) \\
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: =(h \star f)(Q^{-1}R) = D_{Q}( h \star f)(R)
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: \end{aligned}
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: \end{equation}
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: This means that for a single alt-az rotation of input spherical image; the output of a convolution layer will rotate in the same way.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Although the property doesn’t hold if one performs multiple alt-az rotations to the input spherical image, it is still valuable because we assume the different SO(3) orientation of an input 3D shape is from a composite of an azimuthal rotation and an alt-az rotation, the azimuthal rotation is treated by data augmentation and the single alt-az rotation is treated by the network equivariance and invariance.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Q3: alt-az convolution is not well defined on the south pole
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A3: Yes, we agree that our original definition of alt-az convolution is not well defined on both north and south poles.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Therefore, in the new revision, we will add the constraints to the definition of alt-az rotation and make it one-to-one corresponds to the set points on $S^2$. See A1.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Q4: The paragraph motivating the alt-az convolution on page 4 is not very clear.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A4: Thanks for the comments, as you suggested, we will rewrite this paragraph in the new version, and acknowledge the importance and effectiveness of the recent work on the group equivariance and rotation invariant networks.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Q5: It would be nice to see a more direct comparison between the three definitions of spherical convolution (general SO3, isotropic S2, and anisotropic S2)
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A5: The two related papers (Cohen et al 2018 for general SO3 and Esteves, and Esteves et al 2018 for isotropic S2) both use lat-lon grid and Fourier domain convolution, while ours uses a icosahedron-sphere grid and direct spherical domain convolution.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The use of different sampling in the input spherical image, and the use of filters are totally different.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We think a direct comparison should be done in one of the following ways : (a) perform the three types of spherical convolution all using icosahedron-sphere grid and then convolve in the spherical domain.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (b) perform the three types of spherical convolution all using lat-lon grid and convolve in the Fourier domain.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For the first type of direct comparison, to implement isotropic spherical convolution (Type II), we should make the geodesic disc filter share an identical weight along the angular direction.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: To implement a general SO(3) spherical convolution, we should add a rotation degree of freedom into our disc filter.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We are conducting this experiment and if the time and paper page limit are allowed, we will report the comparison result in the revised version.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Otherwise, we will put it into our future work.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: For the second type of direct comparison, we need to conduct alt-az spherical convolution in the Fourier domain, this is possible by determining the spherical harmonic coefficient, $<g_0, Y_l^m> $ for the alt-az convolution in terms of the spherical harmonic coefficient of input spherical signal $f$ and the filter $h$. This comparison needs re-designing of our network and we can not finish it within the rebuttal period, we’ll leave it for future work.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q6: Initially, I was a bit puzzled about why SO(3) augmentation seems to reduce accuracy in table 1.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: I think this is because SO(3) augmentation actually makes the classification problem harder if the input is initially aligned.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Some more explanation / discussion would be good.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A6: Theoretically, our method will be rotation invariant with only AZ rotation, it will be full rotation invariant with SO(2) rotation augmentation about an arbitrary axis .
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In table I, we believe the reason alt-az augmentation performs better because it contains more training data.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: SO(3) augmentation underperforms the AZ augmentation because several random SO(3) rotation augmentation might not be able to cover all the relative rotation wrt the filter's orientation (see appendix).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q7: It would be nice to explain the spherical parameterization in more detail.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Is this operation itself rotation equivariant?
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A7: Due to the page limit of the conference paper, we could not explain the spherical parameterization method in detail.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: This operation is theoretically rotation equivariant.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Spherical parameterization establishes a map that transforms the points of a closed surface into the points on the unit sphere.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A good spherical mapping for a closed surface should satisfy the following properties:bijective mapping and least distortion.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Bijective mapping is the most important but most difficult in this process which implies that the resulting map is one-to-one, fold-free, and therefore feature preserving (information lossless).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Least distortion seeks a good sampling rate such that interesting features of the model receive enough real estate on the sphere in order to be accurately sampled.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We achieved the bijective mapping by adapting a coarse-to-fine strategy with minor modifications (See http://hhoppe.com/proj/sphereparam/).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The minimizing of the map distortion is obtained using the authalic parameterization proposed in Sinha et al 2016.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This process is rotation equivariant because the initial bijective mapping is depends on the object orientation and the authalic remeshing does not change the orientation of the spherical embeddings.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Spherical parameterization is a good way to retain geometric and topological information of original shapes (compared to the spherical projection method), but currently it works only for genus-0 closed object, extending it to 3d shapes with arbitrary topology is still an unsolved problem, that is why we could not adapt this method for dataset such as ModelNET and Shrec’17, they contain 3D objects with arbitrary topology.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (Q8) Other typos and minor issues
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We will correct all the typos and other minor issues in the revised paper, thank you again for the detailed review. WE really appreciate your help.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for pointing out the other datasets in algebraic word reasoning.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We’ve included these in an expanded discussion of related work with discussion on how they relate to the current dataset.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Please let us know if we have missed other papers.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Your proposal of combining multiple extant problem sets is a good idea.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We’d want to ensure the combined datasets have a common format (e.g., the same unambiguous freeform text format for reasons of transferability, etc as argued in the paper), and there are interesting problem types occurring in other datasets (such as logical entailment or boolean satisfiability) that we haven’t yet included.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We may in the future extend the dataset to include these other problem types if the current ones become solved, and of course we solicit contributions (in the form of generation code) to the dataset.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: We likely could not use workbooks etc as a source for problems without significant investment, since obtaining legal permission to redistribute copyrighted problems found in these books would probably be hard and/or expensive.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Having said that, it is definitely important to ensure the problems remain grounded in real-life problems (thus our small list of real-life exam questions).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This was the motivation for testing trained models against “real life” questions occurring in school-level examinations; these questions are not intended to be a primary benchmark (with more questions and detailed grades), but rather simply a rough indication of whether training models to answer school-level questions could be achievable.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: On the distribution of the sampled answer (and the related question of how difficulty levels are determined), these are great questions.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: For some modules with two output choices (e.g., True, False), we can simply split the answers 50-50.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: But in general, the answer distribution depends on the module, with hand-tuning to ensure the (question, answer) pair is of a reasonable difficulty level as judged by humans.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In more detail: as mentioned in the paper, we want to achieve upper bounds on the maximum probability that any single (question, answer) is sampled; thus if we sample the answer from a set of N possible answers, then to achieve a maximum probability p of a given question, the remaining choices made in generating the question must
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: be from a set of size p/N. We roughly aim to pick N (depending on p) so that conditioned on this, the question is as easy as possible; there is typically a hand-tuned sweet spot.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: On evaluating general-purpose models only, we may have phrased this badly in the paper, and have updated it.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We are definitely interested in any models that learns to do mathematics and symbolic reasoning, which would include more sophisticated models tailored towards doing mathematics (one could imagine models with working memory, etc).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, we discount models that already have their mathematics knowledge inbuilt rather than learnt (for example, this includes many of the models that occur in algebraic reasoning tasks, where the model learns to map the input text to an existing equation template, that is then solved by a fixed calculator).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We test DNC (differentiable neural computers) and RMC (relational memory core) models, which arguably are more specialized for doing mathematics, since they have a slot-based memory that may be appropriate for storing intermediate results.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However these models obtained worse performance than the more general architectures, and we are not yet aware of models that are more tailored for doing mathematics that do not simply have their mathematics knowledge built-in and unlearnable; we hope the dataset will spur the development of new models along these lines.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: On the number of thinking steps, in our earlier analysis we trained up to 150k steps (compared with 500k for final performance reported in paper), and observed the following interpolation test performances by number of steps: 39% (0 steps), 46% (1 step), 48% (2), 49% (4), 50% (8), 51% (16).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We are re-running experiments now to confirm the final performances, which we can include in the final paper.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Thanks for your valuable comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: It helps us to prepare the revision.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We address all your concerns in the revision as below.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Q1: Was the auxiliary tower used during the training of the shared weights W?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A1: Auxiliary tower is used only in the retraining stage.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q2: “Did the experiments on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet use the cosine learning rate schedule?”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: CIFAR: In the pretrain stage and search stage, the learning rate is fixed to 0.1 with batch size 128; In the retraining stage, we use cosine learning rate schedule.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: ImageNet: In the pretrain stage and search stage, the learning rate is fixed to 0.1 with batch 224; In the retraining stage, we use linear decay learning rate schedule.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q3: “Figure 4 does not illustrate M=4 and N=4, e.g. which operation belongs to which layer?”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A3: In the revision, we replace the Figure 4 with a new version which has more details.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: As show in Figure 4, all the operators in level 4 are pruned.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Q4: “The sparse regularization of \lambda induces great difficulties in optimization”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A4: The non-smooth regularization introduced by l1 regularization makes traditional stochastic SGD failed to yield sparse results.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If we need exact zero, we have to use heuristic thresholding on the \lambda learned, which has already been demonstrated in SSS [1] that is inferior.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Besides, traditional APG method is not friendly for deep learning as extra forward-backward computation is required, also as shown by SSS.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q5: “Missed citation: MnasNet also incorporates the cost of architectures in their search process. On ImageNet, your performance is similar to theirs. I think this will be a good comparison.”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A5: We have added the result of MnasNet [2] in Table 2.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Indeed, MnasNet achieves similar results with us with less FLOPs.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: However, it is also need to note that MnasNet evaluates more than 8K models, which introduces much higher search cost than our method.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Moreover, the design space of MnasNet is significant different from other existing NAS methods including ours.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: It is interesting to explore the combination of MnasNet with ours in the future work.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Q6: “The paper has some grammatical errors.”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A6: We have fixed the typos and grammatical errors in the revision.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Q7: About “first NAS algorithm to perform direct search on ImageNet”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A7: We check this claim again and find methods like MnasNet [2] and one-shot architecture search [3] also have the ability to perform direct search on ImageNet, we have delete this claim in the paper.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: However, to the best of our knowledge, our method is the first method to perform directly search without block structure sharing.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We also report preliminary results that directly search on task beyond classification (semantic segmentation).
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Please refer to Q1 of Reviewer3 for details.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: [1] Data-Driven Sparse Structure Selection for Deep Neural Networks. ECCV 2018.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [2] MnasNet: Platform-Aware Neural Architecture Search for Mobile. https://arxiv.org/pdf/1807.11626.pdf
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [3] Understanding and simplifying one-shot architecture search. ICML 2018.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: We thank the reviewer for acknowledging the novelty of our work and for noting that our experiments are thorough.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Thank you for pointing out a related preprint by Z. Hu et al. [arXiv:1905.13728].
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We note the work by Z. Hu et al. was developed independently and concurrently to our work here, and we were not aware of it at the time of writing our paper.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We shall cite the preprint and include a discussion in our paper.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Briefly, the key difference between our work and that of Hu et al. is that Hu et al. consider a more restrictive setting where graphs are completely unlabeled (i.e., graphs have no node features).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Hu et al. then focus on extracting generic graph properties of unlabeled graphs by pre-training on randomly-generated graphs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: While the approach is interesting, the limitation of such an approach is that it improves performance only marginally over ordinary supervised classification of the original attributed graphs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This is because it is hard for random unlabeled graphs to capture domain-specific knowledge that is useful for a specific application.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Moreover, in practice, graphs tend to have labels together with rich node and edge attributes, but Hu et al.’s approach cannot naturally leverage such attribute information, which then results in limited gains.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In principle, we could compare our approach against Hu et al., however, right now, this would be extremely challenging because of the following reasons.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (1) We cannot find a public implementation of Hu et al.’s approach for reliable comparison.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (2) Reimplementing their method requires knowledge of many specific implementational details and design choices (feature extraction, graph generation, etc.), which are not discussed in their preprint.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: (3) Finally, their pre-trained GNN operates on unlabeled graphs, and so it cannot be directly applied to our datasets of labeled graphs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Lastly, in contrast to Hu et al., our work focuses on important real-world domains, where one wants to pre-train GNNs by utilizing the abundant graph, node, and edge attributes.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Importantly, our approach is able to learn a domain-specific data distribution that is useful for downstream prediction.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We demonstrate on two application domains that such practical settings (i.e., labeled graphs with naturally-given node and edge attributes) are very important to consider and that our pre-training can substantially improve model performance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We thank Reviewer 3 (R3) for their review and for clearly articulating their concerns regarding the paper.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: In our response below, we will clarify the design and results of our experiments as well as argue why we believe that these results should be of interest and are not, indeed, that predictable.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: R3 asked why training performance of many models is 100% when they do not generalize and suggested us to perform a large number of training runs to see if occasionally the right solution is found.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: First, we agree that from the point of view of training there are many equally good solutions, and in fact, this is the main and the only challenge of SQOOP.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We designed the task with the goal of testing which models are more likely to converge to the right solution, with which they can handle all possible combinations of objects, despite being trained only on a small subset of objects.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We argued extensively in the introduction that such an ability to find the systematic solution despite other alternatives being available is highly desirable for language understanding approaches.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We fully agree with R3 that in investigations of whether or not a particular model converges to the right solution repeating every experiment several times is absolutely necessary, and we would like to emphasize that we did repeat each experiment 3, 5, or 10 times (see “details” in Table 1 and the paragraph “Parametrization Induction” on page 8).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: In most cases we saw a consistent success or consistent failure, one exception being the parametrization induction results, where 4 out of 10 runs were successful (see Table 4, row 1 for the mean and the confidence interval).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We hope that 3 takes this fact into account, and we will furthermore improve on the current level of rigor in the upcoming revision by repeating each experiment at least 5 times.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We are not sure if we fully understand the question “Could you somehow test for if a given trained model will show systematic generalization?” that R3 asked.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We test the systematic generalization of a model by evaluating it on all SQOOP questions that were not present in the training set.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We hope that this answers the question of R3 and we would be happy to engage in a further discussion regarding this and make edits to the paper if necessary.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We thank R3 for the suggestion to investigate the influence of model size and regularization on systematic generalization.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: It is indeed a very appropriate question in the  context of our study, however, we note that there exists a wide variety of regularization methods and trying them all (and all their combinations) would be infeasible.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: In the upcoming update of the paper we will report results of an on-going ablation study for the MAC model, in which we vary the module size, the number of modules and experiment with weight decay.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We would welcome any other specific experiment requests R3 may have.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Finally, we would like to discuss the significance of our investigation and its results.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: While we agree that the results that we report may not shock the reader (although perhaps hindsight bias plays a role in what people find surprising or not after reading an article) we find them highly interesting and not at all easily predictable.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Reading prior work on visual reasoning may lead a researcher to conclude, roughly speaking, that NMNs are a lost cause, since a variety of generic models perform comparably or better.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In contrast, our rigorous investigation highlights their strong generalization capabilities and relates them to the specific design of NMNs.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Notably, chain-structured NMNs were used in the literature prior to this work (e.g. in the model of Jonshon et al multiple filter_...[...] modules are often chained), so the fact that tree-structured NMNs show much stronger generalization was not obvious prior to this investigation and should be of a high interest to the research community.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Last but not least, an important part of our investigation (which the review does not discuss) is the systematic generalization analysis of popular end-to-end NMN versions, that shows how making NMNs more end-to-end makes them more susceptible to finding spurious solutions.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: As we argued in our conclusion, these findings should be of a highest importance to researchers working on end-to-end NMNs, which is a very popular research direction nowadays.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We conclude our response by announcing that an updated version of the paper, that among others incorporates valuable suggestions by R3, will soon be uploaded to OpenReview.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We are currently performing a lot of additional experiments, the results of which will make our investigation even more rigorous and complete.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We sincerely hope that R3 takes into account the arguments we have made here and the new results that we will publish soon and reevaluates our paper more positively.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Dear Reviewer 3,
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We thank you again for your informative review that you wrote before the revision period.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: In our response and the revised version of the paper we tried our best to address your concerns.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We would highly appreciate to get some feedback from you regarding the changes that we have made and the arguments that we have presented.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: In particular, we report that NMN-Chains (with a lot of inductive bias built-in and also used in prior work such as Johnson et al. 2017) generalize poorly compared to even generic modules, and that layout/parameterization induction often fails to converge to the correct solution.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We believe both these findings are quite surprising.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We also report new experiments with the MAC model, including a hyperparameter search, a comparison against end-to-end NMNs, and a qualitative exploration of the failure modes of this model.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: All these experiments are repeated at least 5 times each, like you suggested in your review, although it’s worth noting that results the original version of the paper also reported results after  multiple runs.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We would highly appreciate a response on our newest revision and suggestions on how it could be improved. If you still think that paper is uninteresting or not well executed, could you then suggest what specifically it is lacking?
label: rebuttal_followup

sentence: We are sincerely hoping to hear from you.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We thank you for the  detailed and thoughtful review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We are glad that you found the paper well-contextualized and the presentation high-quality. Here we discuss some of your comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: R2: "this 'finishes' [Pathak et al., ICML17] to its logical conclusion for game-based environments and should spur interesting conversations and further research. In terms of actual technical contributions, I believe much less significant."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: => In the light of the comments on originality and significance, we would like to highlight our finding that random features perform quite well and at times as well as learned features across many environments.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This is a novel contribution since prior works have relied on learned features as a crucial requirement for good performance [Pathak et. al. ICML17].
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We believe this investigation would allow random features to be seen as an easily reproducible and strong baseline for future investigations of feature learning in exploration.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Indeed, since the release of our paper, there has been some follow-ups on using random features for exploration in achieving state of the art results on hard exploration games when combined with extrinsic reward (in the interest of preserving anonymity, we don't include the references here).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: R2: "However, it isn't entirely clear if the primary contribution is showing that 'curiosity reward' is a potentially promising approach or if game environments aren't particularly good testbeds for practical RL algorithms"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: => We believe that both are valuable insofar as generating discussion within the community and leading to follow-up experimentation.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In particular, we hope our paper stimulates both, an interest in trying out more realistic/stochastic environments, *and* further research on curiosity as a potential useful reward.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In addition to that, we have shown that curiosity could be a very strong baseline to compare against in future papers.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: All these, we argue, are valuable to the progress and health of the field.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: R2: "Dealing with highly stochastic environments seems a potential fatal flaw of the assumptions of this method. However, as I said previously, this is probably a discussion worth having given the popularity and visibility of game-based testbeds"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: => We agree that significant amounts of stochasticity would break the method we used in the paper, and it is an important issue to be addressed by future work.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Our vivid demonstration of this issue in the maze environment has already inspired some recent papers to look into, in particular, by incentivizing episodic reachability (in the interest of preserving anonymity, we don't include references to these, but we will include them in the final version of the paper).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: R2: "I think that more casual ML/RL researchers will find these results controversial and surprising while more experienced researchers will see curiosity-driven learning to be explainable primarily by the intuition..."
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: R2: "Even the 'focused experiments' can be explained with the intuitive narrative that in the state/action space"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: => Indeed in our experience, although a few people were not surprised, most of them were very surprised at the agents being able to make progress without any any extrinsic rewards.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This suggests that the game designers (similar to architects, urban planners, gardeners, etc.) are purposefully setting up curricula to guide agents through the task by curiosity alone [Lazzaro, 2004].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: R2: "consider [Mirowski et al., ICLR17] with respect to auxiliary loss + RL extrinsic rewards to improve performance"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: R2: "RL + auxiliary loss isn't evaluated in detail"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: => We will add a discussion of recent works that deal with navigation tasks in maze environments [Mirowski et. al. ICLR 2017, Jaderberg et. al. ICLR 2017] in the related works section.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: In contrast to these works, we don't assume privileged access to the maze environment in the form of depth estimation or loop closure supervision.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Auxiliary tasks are an important component of RL and exploration methods, however, in this work we chose to focus on the most generic setting with minimal assumptions about the environment: providing raw observations in response to actions.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In environments with privileged access we expect auxiliary tasks to benefit both curiosity-driven and extrinsic-reward-driven RL methods.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Thank you for your review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We agree that further investigation is needed for mutual information, and we are currently working on it.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: As for the layer to investigate, we have presented the higher layer results because the representation regularizers showed the most improvements when applied to the higher (or even output) layer.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We believe the representations in the lower layers are inherently less structured and therefore representation shaping can be harmful.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The layer dependency is further explained in the following article.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Daeyoung Choi and Wonjong Rhee, Utilizing class information for deep network representation shaping, AAAI 2019   (https://arxiv.org/abs/1809.09307)
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: >> The reviewer feels that for CIFAR-10 and 100, some regularizers do consistently give best or close to best networks. Could the authors comment on this?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Response: In general, representation regularizers showed better performance than the others.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Among the representation regularizers, cw-VR and L1R frequently achieved the best performance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Nonetheless, we were not able to identify any specific task condition that makes a specific regularizer consistently best performing regularizer.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 1. Thank you for your suggestion, we have addressed this in the revision as you suggested. This is indeed a good motivation.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 2. Thank you for your suggestion.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We have further added experiments using even stronger query limit (previously 500000, now 50000) for the additional experiments on ResNet V2 model in the supplemental material. (We did not choose to use smaller epsilon because first, we already used a quite standard choice of epsilon, second, as you said, going for extremely small distortion does not really mean anything in adversarial context.) As you can see, in this even harder setting our proposed algorithm still maintain a performance lead over other baselines.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Also, we have revised the statement in the abstract as you suggested.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 3. You are right, it is a quite weak attack and we have removed it from the table (just mention it in the text).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 4. Yes, we could just remove the distortion column in our result.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We choose to include it because we do not want others to think that we actually trade a lot of distortions (to make problem easy) for speedup in runtime.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 5. We have added further empirical evidence to show that in the revision.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: From an intuitive perspective, using lambda>1 is essentially a “relax and tighten” step by first relax the constraint to make the problem easier, and then tighten it back to the real constraint.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The “relax and tighten” idea has been widely used in constrained optimization, and we adapted this idea to Frank-Wolfe algorithm to make it even faster.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 6. As mentioned in an anonymous comment, there is one paper which proposed a similar but different zeroth-order non-convex FW algorithm as well as convergence rate analysis ahead of us.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We were not aware of this paper when we prepared our ICLR submission, since it was posted only ten days before the ICLR deadline.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have cited this paper and modify our claim correspondingly in the revision.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Nevertheless, it does not affect the main contribution of our paper: a novel Frank-Wolfe based adversarial attack framework for both white-box and black-box attacks, which is much more efficient than existing white-box/black-box adversarial attacks in both query complexity and runtime.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 7. Thank you for your suggestion and we have explicitly written down the update for a better comparison in the supplemental materials (Section A) in the revision.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 8. It means it is invariant to an affine transformation of the constraint set, i.e., if we choose to re-parameterize of the constraint with some linear or affine transformation M, the original and the new optimization problem will looks the same to the Frank-Wolfe algorithm.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Please refer to [Jaggi (2013)], [Lacoste-Julien (2016)] for more details.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 9. In white-box setting, we perform grid search / binary search for parameter epsilon (or c for CW) for all algorithms.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This will lead to better/ closer distortions for all methods.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In black-box setting, we care more about query complexity and thus did not perform the grid search/binary search steps to avoid extra queries in finding the best epsilon/lambda.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 10. Thank you for pointing these typos out, we have addressed it in the revision.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Thank you for the review, and we really appreciate your suggestions!
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: In the revision, we have added analysis in section 4.2 and section 5 on how the learned causal matrix can be used downstream, for example in RL/IL and interpretability of neural nets.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: In the discussion in section 5, we also analyze how the error may affect the tasks downstream.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We are excited that various tasks may utilize or incorporate our algorithm, and benefit from the causal inference ability it enables.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We have also added comparison with sparse learning/feature selection methods in the “related works” section.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: In particular, we note that L1 and group L1 regularization is dependent on the model structure change and rescaling of input variables, while our learnable noise risk is invariant to both, making it suitable for causal discovery where the scale of data may span orders of magnitude and the model structure may vary.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: (1) Reconstruction from prior during training:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The crux of the proposed model is the selective proposal distribution.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: "Pseudo" sampling for unobserved modalities during training provides a way to facilitate model training process.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We evaluated the model under two training settings: (I) optimize the final ELBO without conditional log-likelihood for unobserved modalities x_u; and (II) optimize the final ELBO with  conditional log-likelihood of unobserved modalities.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This is realized by utilizing the "pseudo" sampling described before (and in the paper).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The results are comparable but the added term in setting II shows benefits on some datasets.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: While setting I is solely based on the observed modalities, the setting II incorporates the unobserved modalities along with the observed ones.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: By using the complete data, the setting II describes the complete ELBO corresponding to the partially observed multimodal data (in consideration).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: (2) Comparison with VAEAC:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In order to establish fair comparison, we used the same backbone network structures and training criteria for all baseline models and our proposed VSAE.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Therefore, the implementation details differ from the original VAEAC paper.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We did our best to maintain the optimization details described in all baseline papers.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Experiments on VAEAC with partially-observed data are also conducted.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Results show that VAEAC under this setting can achieve comparable performance on categorical datasets: 0.245(0.002) on Phishing, 0.399(0.011) on Mushroom while the errors of VSAE are 0.237(0.001) on Phishing,  0.396(0.008) on Mushroom.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: However, on numerical and bimodal datasets, partially trained VAEAC performs worse than VSAE :
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: *VSAE:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: *VAEAC trained partially:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: (3) Experiments under synthetic non-MCAR masking:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: As mentioned by the reviewer, we conduct experiments on non-MCAR masking following state-of-the-art non-MCAR model MIWAE [2].
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Same as MIWAE, we synthesize masks by defining some rules to specify the probability of a Bernoulli distribution.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Please refer to Table 3 and Appendix C.4 for updated comparison results.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: VSAE outperforms MIWAE under all MCAR, MAR and NMAR masking mechanisms.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (4) Baselines:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: All baselines considered in the paper are designed to have comparable number of parameters (same or larger than our model) to make the comparison fair.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We have updated the baseline details in the Appendix B.3.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Although GAN-based models show promising imputation results, they usually fail to model data distribution properly.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Therefore, we do not consider them as our baseline models.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: It is also important to note that VSAE is not a model designed only for imputation, but a generic framework to learn from partially-observed data for both imputation and generation.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: (5) Conditional imputation:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: When performing imputation, we assume that the generation is not conditioned on the observed image, but only conditioned on the factorized latent variables.

sentence: Input an observed image to the model, we observe a "conditional" distribution if we independently sample from the latent variables.

sentence: In summary, there are multiple reasons why the performance is not identical with the original VAEAC: (I) the back-bone structures are not the same; (II) training criteria (including batch size, learning rate, etc.) are not the same; and (III)  training/validation/test split is different.

sentence: We address the main concerns individually below:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Adversarially filtering using BERT and GPT gives deep learning models a disadvantage:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: While BERT originally achieved high performance on the originally collected dataset, several recent studies [1][2][3][4] have found the presence of annotation artifacts in crowdsourced data that inadvertently leak information about the target label.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: This subsequently leads to overestimation of the performance of AI systems on end tasks.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Our adversarial filtering (AF) algorithm aims to address the problem of overestimation of performance.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In spite of targeting GPT/BERT during AF, human performance on the AF resulting dataset is still high.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The significant gap between human and BERT performance leaves scope for inventing new methods for abductive reasoning.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Ensemble of BERT models:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: An ensemble of three BERT models achieves an accuracy of 68.9%, very close to a single model 68.6%.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Average score of human:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The average score of human annotations is 89.4%.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This is directly comparable with BERT-Ft [Fully Connected] model’s performance of 68.6% in Table 1.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Re. Ground Truth:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The ground truth is assigned based on whether a hypothesis was collected during the plausible (Appendix A1 Task1) or implausible (Appendix A1 Task2) phase of the data collection procedure.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: To measure human performance, we had three annotators select the correct hypothesis and measured human performance as the accuracy of their majority-vote.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Please let us know if this answers your question. If not, could you please clarify your question?
label: rebuttal_followup

sentence: Generative task vs classification:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We completely agree.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: While the generative task is more general and much more interesting, the challenge of evaluating generations is significant, particularly for this task.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: This is due to the fact that there could be multiple distinct plausible explanations for a given pair of hypothesis.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Consider the following example:
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: O1: Kelly and her friend wanted to take a train to the city.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: O2: They had to wait for another one.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Plausible explanations:
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: 1. They read the timetable incorrectly and arrived at the station just after a train had left.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: 2. The train was full.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Both explanations are plausible, and explain the observations, but automated evaluation metrics are not reliable enough to capture this phenomenon based on their reliance on surface level similarities.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: To simultaneously make progress on the novel abductive reasoning task and due to the ease of evaluation, we additionally introduce a discriminative version of the task.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: Nonetheless, we agree that in its most general form, there could be any number of observations and models should be required to generate explanatory hypotheses in natural language (alpha-NLG task).
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: - Another note: to perform a full wall-clock comparison with algorithms that have different per-iteration costs, one must disentangle and retune various hyperparameter choices, most notably the learning rate schedule.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thus we decided to feature the per-iteration comparison in the main paper, as it is the cleanest one.

sentence: @L-BFGS: On a high level, we agree that GGT develops a similar window-based approximation to the gradient Gram matrix as L-BFGS does to the approximated Hessian.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: While adaptive methods have proven effective in practice, quasi-Newton algorithms are not in general regarded as competitive for deep learning (despite recent efforts [1,2]), and that’s why it is not compared to in the vast majority of deep learning papers.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - Quasi-Newton methods are suited for deterministic problems, while stochasticity is crucial in deep learning.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This is because they try to approximate the Hessian by finite differences, which seems unstable with stochastic gradients in practice.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - Direct second-order methods require significant modifications to converge in the non-convex setting (see [3,4]).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Even these have not been observed to work well in deep learning.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - One reason for the practical success of AdaGrad-like algorithms we believe is the difference of  -1/2 vs. -1 power on the Gram matrix, which seems to change the training dynamics dramatically.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: With the gradient Gram matrix and a -1 power, meaningful end-to-end advances have only been claimed for niche tasks other than classification.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Before delving in and providing more details, we have some initial thoughts about the theoretical issues you brought up.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Regarding theorem 1 and the sample complexity of MINE, we also had discussions on why we think they are comparable or not and discussed that on page 5 in our submission.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The tldr is that the MINE sample complexity can not only be seen as 1) bounding best achievable MI estimation but also as 2) bounding distance from estimation to a proven MI lower bound.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The former is a quite vacuous bound on generalization and would require advances in learning theory to improve, not MI estimation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our theorem 1 is trying to improve the latter to enable practical applications.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Improving the former to the level of practical use is a noble goal, let us know when you have an answer.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Regarding "false detection" experiments.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We really appreciate that you brought up this point.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Our synthetic experiments on Gaussians rho=0.0 in Figure 1 do exactly this.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Results show that MINE-f and MINE-f-ES estimates very much non-zero MI when there should have been 0 MI.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: MINE-f bar is not visible due to overshooting out of the chart.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: DEMINE approaches give estimations closer to 0.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We often get questions about why our estimators give MI numbers lower than MINE and why are we claiming that our estimator is better.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: But in fact that's exactly because MINE gives false detection but our estimators provably don't.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Hyper-parameter search example.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Say we are given 3000 paired (x,y) observations.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: First divide into 1500 train, 1500 test.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Take 1500 train and run Algorithm 1 using 3-fold crossval: use 1000 for (x,y)train and 500 for (x,y)val in each run (3 runs total).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Get MI estimation m1,m2,m3 over 3 folds.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Compute confidence interval v using Eq.8 using the hyperparameters and 1500 as test set size.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Hyperparameter search DEMINE-vr maximizes mean([m1,m2,m3])-2std([m1,m2,m3]).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: DEMINE-sig maximizes mean([m1,m2,m3])-v.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Will try to make it more clear.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Regarding fMRI experiments, our focus is on demonstrating neural MI estimation and dependency test on fMRI data.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We compare with pearson's correlation because it's another widely used technique that can perform both correlation analysis as well as significance test.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We used a simple 1D CNN where convolution happens over the time dimension, not the spatial dimensions.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Better architectures, e.g. transformers over time + graph networks over space could improve performance, but not our focus and we leave that to future work.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Higher-order and nonlinear covariance tests may make very appealing comparisons and we are looking into it.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: A first impression is that our technique is more general and will probably give looser bounds, but may be applicable to a wider range of problems not only ones that have specifically that type of covariance, just like DEMINE vs Pearson's correlation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: But at the same time we also have questions on how much additional insight it brings, as it's not an apples to apples comparison, so neither tight or loose estimations diminish the value of both types of approaches.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Please refer to our main response in an above comment that addresses the primary and common questions amongst all reviewers.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Here we respond to your specific comments.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: "What can be said about how computationally demanding the procedure is? running label propagation within meta learning might be too costly. "
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: >>> In few-shot learning, episodic paradigm proposed by Matching Networks [1] is widely adopted by current researchers (we follow the same setting to make a fair comparison).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In each episode, a small subset of N-way K-shot Q-query examples is sampled from the training set.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Typically, for 1-shot experiments, N=5, K=1, Q=15 and for 5-shot experiments, N=5, K=5, Q=15
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thus, the number of training examples are Nx(K+Q) (80 for 1-shot and 100 for 5-shot)
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Constructing label propagation matrix W involves both support and query examples (80 or 100).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: So the dimension of W is either 80x80 or 100x100.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Running label propagation on such small matrix is quite efficient.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: "It is not clear how the  per-example scalar sigma-i is learned. (for Eq 2)"
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: >>> In Figure 4 of appendix A, we describe the detailed structure of the graph construction module.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: After we get the per-example feature representation f_{\varphi}(x_i) for x_i, we feed it into the graph construction module g_{\phi}. The output of this module is a one-dimensional scalar.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: f and g are learned in an end-to-end way in our approach.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: "solving Eq 3 by matrix inversion does not scale. Would be best to also show results using iterative optimization "
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: >>> We want to answer this question from two aspects.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: On one hand, few-shot learning assumes that training examples in each class are quite small (only 1 or 5).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In this situation, Eq (3) and the closed-form version can be efficiently solved, since the dimension of S is only 80x80 or 100x100.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: On the other hand, there is plenty of prior work on the scalability and efficiency of label propagation, such as [2], [3], [4], which can extend our work to large-scale data.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: On miniImagenet, we performed iterative optimization and got 53.05/68.75 for 1-shot/5-shot experiments with only 10 steps.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This is slightly worse than closed-form version (53.75/69.43), because of the inaccurate computation and unstable gradients caused by multiple step iterations.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: [1] Vinyals, Oriol, et al. "Matching networks for one shot learning." NIPS. 2016.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [2] Liang, De-Ming, and Yu-Feng Li. "Lightweight Label Propagation for Large-Scale Network Data." IJCAI. 2018.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [3] Fujiwara, Yasuhiro, and Go Irie. "Efficient label propagation." ICML. 2014.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [4] Weston, Jason. "Large-Scale Semi-Supervised Learning."
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: Thanks for pointing out the pros and cons of our method.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We address your concerns as follows:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Q1. “The search space of the proposed method, such as the number of operations in the convolution block, is limited.”
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A1: First, the size of search space is not determined by the number of operations but the number of connections.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The search space of our method is different from exiting NAS methods in that the number of input of certain operation is not limited.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Second, the search space without block share is even much larger than existing NAS methods.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Third, we can trivially extend our DSO-NAS to accommodate more operations such as dilated conv like our ongoing experiments on PASCAL VOC semantic segmentation task, we extend our search space to accommodate 3x3 and 5x5 separable convolution with dilated = 2.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The following table shows the performance of our model on the PASCAL VOC 2012 semantic segmentation task, where DSO-NAS-cls represents the architecture searched on ImageNet with block structure sharing and DSO-NAS-seg represents the architecture searched on PASCAL VOC segmentation task.

sentence: Q2: “The technical contribution of the proposed method is not high, because the architecture space of neural network is similar to the prior works.”

sentence: A2: Please refer to Q1.

label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: And in fact, most existing NAS papers share the same architecture search space, the main differences between them is the search strategy.
