sentence: Thank you for your constructive comments!
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: 1. We fully understand your concern and we have added detailed description in the supplemental materials to show the hyperparameters we use for baseline methods in the revision.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 2. We would like to argue that constrained optimization based formulation itself is not designed to achieve better distortion compared with regularized optimization based formulation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: So there is no surprise that our algorithm’s distortion is not the best.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: On the other hand, as mentioned by the other reviewer, distortion is usually not that essential in adversarial attacks as long as it is maintained in a reasonable range.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We could actually remove the distortion column, instead, we chose to include it just to show that we did not trade a lot of distortions (to make problem much easier) and thus gains speedup.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: From our experimental results, you can see that our proposed method achieves significant speedup while keeping the distortion around the same level as the best baselines.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3. Thank you for your suggestion.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We have further added success rate vs queries plot (for black-box case) and loss vs iterations plot (for white-box case) in the revision.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: As you can see, in terms of number of iterations / queries, our method still outperforms the other baselines by a large margin.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 4. Thank you for your suggestion.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We have further added experiments on ResNet V2 model and averaging over 500 correctly classified pictures to strengthen our result.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Again, this additional experiments show that our method outperforms the other baselines for both white-box attack and black-box attack.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 5. Regarding poor time complexity in practice, first, as you mentioned, adversarial training currently is quite slow due to the slow adversarial attack steps.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Better time complexity of adversarial attack could significantly speed up adversarial training algorithms.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Second, it is worth noting that the running time complexity of adversarial attack also highly depends on the input size.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For example, if you attack a CIFAR-10 classifier or an MNIST classifier, it could take only seconds per attack even for the slowest algorithm since the input size is only 32 by 32 (or 28 by 28).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, if you attack a ImageNet classifier or even higher dimensional data classifier, it could take significantly longer time (minutes).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: That is why reducing the runtime of adversarial attack is very important.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 6. We apologize for this confusion.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Regarding “gradient-based” / “optimization based” methods and coordinate-wise black-box attacks, we have changed our description to avoid confusion.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Thank you for pointing it out.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We thank reviewer 2 for the detailed feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We are glad that the reviewer found the VAE-GAN model to be a natural extension for the problem and that our work provides a good baseline for future work.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We address the individual questions below.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We changed Section 3.1 to explain that the posterior dependence on pairs of adjacent frames is to have temporally local latent variables that capture the ambiguity for only that transition, a sensible choice when using i.i.d. Gaussian priors.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Another choice is to use temporally correlated latent variables, which would require a stronger prior (e.g. as in Denton & Fergus (2018)).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For simplicity, we opted for the former.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The blurriness in a VAE can indeed be attributable to a weak inference model.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Note that our VAE variant and both SVG variants are able to predict sharp robot arms in the BAIR dataset, but often blur out the small objects being pushed.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We tried recurrent posteriors and learned priors with our models, and the results were similar.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We are now running additional experiments with a deeper encoder and with more filters.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Although in principle a strong inference model could produce sharper images, an alternative approach is to use better losses, which is the approach we chose in this work.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: It is an interesting suggestion to experiment with the effect of the hyperparameters on the trade-off between realism and diversity.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We are currently running experiments for various weightings of the KL loss and the adversarial loss, and we plan to include results that illustrate the trade-offs based on these hyperparameters.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We also plan to include results on the trade-offs between accuracy and realism.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: In fact, a recent result [1] proves that this is a fundamental trade-off for all problems with inherent ambiguity.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The statement that “GANs prioritize matching joint distributions of pixels over per-pixel reconstruction" is a criticism of per-pixel losses, and not of VAEs in general. We clarified in the introduction that VAEs can indeed model joint distributions of pixels.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: [1] Yochai Blau and Tomer Michaeli. The perception-distortion tradeoff. In Conference on Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR), 2018. https://arxiv.org/abs/1711.06077
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: Thanks for your review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: The ION theorem is an important part of explaining sparsity, dead units, and rank as well, but perhaps our writing was not clear enough.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We will work on the writing in the future version of this work.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: As for the mutual information related comment (#2), the results that you have mentioned are well known from information bottleneck paper or from the following information invariance paper.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Alessandro Achille and Stefano Soatto.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Emergence of invariance and disentangling in deep representations.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Journal of Machine Learning Research. 2018
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for your helpful comments!
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: 1. You are right that Frank-Wolfe would be advantageous over PGD when the constraints are more complicated and adversarial attack may not be such a case.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Yet it is also well-known that Frank-Wolfe has quite different optimization behavior compared with PGD even though they have the same order of convergence rate.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Therefore, it is interesting and important to examine the performance of Frank-Wolfe algorithm for adversarial attack, given the fact that PGD has been shown to be a very effective for adversarial attack.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In fact, from our work, we found that Frank-Wolfe based methods are generally more efficient than PGD method.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: From another perspective, Frank-Wolfe solves the problem by calling Linear Minimization Oracle (LMO) over the constraint set at each iteration.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This LMO shares the same intuition as FGSM, which also tries to linearize the neural network loss function to find the adversarial examples.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In this sense, it is a quite natural attempt to revisit FGSM under the Frank-Wolfe framework.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2. We are sorry maybe we didn’t explain it very well in the paper, but this is a misunderstanding.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We indeed compared our method with generalized I-FGSM/BIM, which is exactly the same as PGD (In [Madry et al.] they also mentioned this in Section 2.1 and they refer it as FGSM^k).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We decide to just call it PGD in the revision to avoid confusion.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We hope this remove your concern.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Indeed, theoretically we can only prove for $\lambda$ = 1 case.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Yet we found that larger \lambda brings us more speedup.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have added further empirical evidence (performance comparison of our method with different \lambda in Figure 1 in the revised paper) to justify it.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Intuitively speaking, using lambda>1 is essentially a “relax and tighten” step by first relax the constraint to make the problem easier, and then tighten it back to the real constraint.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The “relax and tighten” idea has been widely used in constrained optimization, and in this paper we adapted this idea into Frank-Wolfe algorithm to make it even faster.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 4. [Lacoste-Julien 2016] considered the general first-order Frank-Wolfe algorithm for nonconvex smooth optimization.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The result of Theorem 4.3 in our paper is almost the same as the result in (Lacoste-Julien 2016), except that the choices the learning rate in these two papers are different though.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have made it clear in the revision.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 5. We have added detailed hyperparameter settings for CW and EAD in the revision in the supplemental materials.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 6. While Theorem 4.7 is new and may be of independent interest in the optimization community,  it is not the main contribution in this paper.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We would like to emphasize that our major contribution in this paper is a Frank-Wolfe based algorithm for adversarial attack, which is more efficient than PGD based adversarial attack algorithm and other baselines.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 7. Sorry about the confusion.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: $y$ should be replace by $y_{tar}$. It is a simplified notation we mentioned in the proof in the appendix.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for your suggestion and we have revised the notation $f(x,y_{tar})$ to $f(x)$.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 8. Thank you for pointing out several typos. We have fixed all of them in the revision.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We would like to thank the reviewer for the time and useful feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Our response is given below.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - Relationship to z-conditioning strategy in BigGAN.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thanks for pointing out the connection to this concurrent submission.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We will discuss the connections in the related work section.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: The main differences are as follows:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: 1. BigGAN performs conditional generation, whilst we primarily focus on unconditional generation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: BigGAN splits the latent vector z and concatenates it with the label embedding, whereas we transform z using a small MLP per layer, which is arguably more powerful.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In the conditional case, we apply both additive and multiplicative interaction between the label and z, instead of concatenation as in BigGAN.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2. Overall BigGAN focusses on scalability to demonstrate that one can train an impressive model for conditional generation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Instead, we focus on a single idea, and show that it can be applied very broadly.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We provide a thorough empirical evaluation across critical design decisions in GANs and demonstrate that it is a robust and practically useful contribution.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - Propagation of signal and ResNets.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Indeed, ResNets provide a skip connection which helps signal propagation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Arguably, self-modulation has a similar effect.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, there are critical differences in these mechanisms which may explain the benefits of self-modulation in a resnet architecture:
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 1. Self-modulation applies a channel-wise additive and multiplicative operation to each layer.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In contrast, residual connections perform only an element-wise addition in the same spatial locality.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: As a result, channel-wise modulation allows trainable re-weighting of all feature maps, which is not the case for classic residual connections.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2. The ResNet skip-connection is either an identity function or a learnable 1x1 convolution, both of which are linear.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In self-modulation, the connection from z to each layer is a learnable non-linear function (MLP).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - Reading Figure 2b, one could be tempted to draw a correlation between the complexity of the dataset and the gains achieved by self-modulation over the baseline (e.g., Bedroom shows less difference between the two approaches than ImageNet). Do the authors agree with that?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Yes, we notice more improvements on the harder, more diverse datasets.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: These datasets also have more headroom for improvement.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 1. I feel the approach to implicitly assume that the classifiers to be compared are already "reasonably accurate"; since if not, both classifiers might be easily falsified by certain trivial examples, making the "disagreed examples" not as meaningful. If that is true, I would suggest the authors to make this hidden assumption clearer in the paper
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Response: Thanks for the constructive suggestion. We agree with the reviewer and will make this assumption explicit in the revised manuscript.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: 2. The idea shows clear liaison to the "differential testing" concept in software engineering besides the cited work of perceptual quality assessment.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The idea has a cross-disciplinary nature and is fairly interesting to me.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: I can see the paper to be of interest to a quite broad audience and can motivate many subsequent works.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Response: Thanks for recognizing the strengths of the paper. We will add the appropriate references regarding the "differential testing" concept in software engineering.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: 3. One minor comment: for images in "Case III", the authors considered them "contribute little to performance comparison between the two classifiers" and therefore did not source labels for them.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: However, since the authors adopted an affinity-aware distance, two incorrect predictions can still be compared based on their semantic tree distances to the true class.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Response: Thanks for pointing it out.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We agree with the reviewer that images falling into Case III can be used to distinguish the associated two classifiers using the proposed semantic tree distance.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We will revise the writing to make it more rigorous.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: In our current subjective assessment environment, we choose to stop labeling images in Case III because it is difficult for humans to select one among 200 classes, especially when they are unfamiliar with the class ontology.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for your comments. Please find below our response to your questions and concerns.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: 1) Pseudocode
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We apologise that the optimization procedure was unclear.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We have added pseudocode of the general optimization procedure in Appendix A.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 2) Hyperparameter selection
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The reviewer is completely right that we are removing one hyperparameter by introducing another.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, there are two reasons why this might still be beneficial: one is that the penalty coefficient is now effectively dynamic and can change during training, ensuring higher chances of finding a good solution.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Second, by elevating the hyperparameter one level up, we hope that the learning is indeed less sensitive to its specific setting.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Indeed, we found in practice that we get similar results for \beta within some orders of magnitude, which requires significantly less tuning compared to a fixed \alpha.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3) Relation to safe reinforcement learning
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: It is indeed the case that constrained MDPs are often considered in safe RL.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In those cases there is generally an upper bound on a penalty function that should never be exceeded, including during training itself.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: These algorithms generally restrict policy updates to remain within the constraint-satisfying regime.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: While our approach can similarly be applied to upper bounds on penalties, there’s unfortunately no guarantee that the constraints will be satisfied at every moment during training, but only at convergence.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: As such it is not clear how these methods would apply to our specific experimental setups.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q1: In Theorem 4.3, the result holds for any $k$ and $M$. The authors claim that if we take a limit of $M \to \infty$ with fixed $k$, the practical dynamics converges to the discrete-time mean-field limit, in Section 4.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: However, to state the result of Theorem 4.3, $k$ should be bigger than $M c_\eta$ from the dentition of $\tilde{\rho}_k^M$, as shown under the equation (4).
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: How do we take a limit of $M \to\infty$ ? Does k also go $\infty$?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A1: Thanks for pointing this out.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: The result of this theorem holds uniformly for any $k$ (not a fixed $k$).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Besides, we do not require $k$ bigger than $M c_\eta$ in the definition of $\tilde{\rho}_k^M$. When $k$ is no more than $M c_\eta$, $\tilde{\rho}_k^M$ and $\rho_k^M$ are stochastic processes with same distribution and thus the Wasserstein distance between them is 0.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: And for any $k$ is greater than $M c_\eta$, we have the uniform bound (w.r.t. $k$) as stated in the theorem 4.3.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We are sorry for not stating this clearly in the theorem and we have revisited the present of the theorem. We will fix this issue in the next revision.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We also point out that, as our system is complicated, in taking the limit of $M\to\infty$, we need to ensure that the number of iteration we run is larger than $Mc_\eta$. To be specific, the asymptotic convergence would be
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: $$\lim_{k,M \to\infty, \eta \to 0^+} \mathbb{D}_{\text{BL}} (\rho_k, \rho^*)=0$$
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: where the joint limit of k and M requires that $k\eta\to\infty$; $\exp(C\alpha^{2}k\eta)\eta^{2}=o(1)$; $(k\eta)/(Mc)=q(1+o(1))$ with $q>1$. Here if $q \leq 1$, we degenerate to Langevin. But when $q>1$ (intuitively that means, when $M$ is large, the number of iterations we run is larger), our dynamics is different from Langevin, which is what we do in the practice.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Also, we would like to remark that this seemingly strange things is in fact the ‘artifact’ caused by the using of Langevin dynamics at beginning to obtain the $M$ initial samples when we designed the practical implementation of the proposed methods.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, it is not really necessary to use Langevin dynamics to get $M$ initial samples, as we can simply using some other initialization distribution and get the $M$ initial samples from that distribution (and by this setting, our dynamics is simply the second phases in Eq (3)).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: All our theory can be easily generalized to this setting using almost identical argument, which can also address your concerns on this issue.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q2: Regarding other minor comments
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A2: Thanks for your notification! We will polish our paper and rewrite the corresponding part in the next revision.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Thank you very much for the highly constructive review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: > I think this is a very interesting direction, but the present paper is somewhat unclear. In particular, the example in section 3.1 says that a noisy information bottleneck is introduced, but then says that the modified and unmodified models have "training algorithms that are exactly equivalent." I think this example needs to be clarified.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We realized that the naming was very confusing and consequently, we renamed \tilde\theta to \tilde\mu in the noise-injected model.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Now,
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - the original, noise-free model p has the structure \theta -> D (no bottleneck) while
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - the adapted, noise-injected model p’ has the structure \mu -> \tilde\mu -> D (containing a bottleneck).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Hereby, \tilde\mu is a noise-corrupted version of the new parameters \mu, and we obtain a limit on the mutual information between \mu and D. We simplified Figure 2 and 8 to make this more clear.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: To better characterize Gaussian mean field inference on the original model, we aim to find an inference procedure on p’ so that both algorithms result in exactly the same outcome, e. g. the same calculations are executed when running the corresponding program.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We show that there is such an inference procedure on the noisy model, and it has the character of MAP.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Note that only if generative and inference model are adapted simultaneously we end up with equivalence.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Hereby, \mu (the mean of the Gaussian q) and \theta (the original parameter in p) correspond to \mu (the MAP point-mass of q’) and \tilde\mu (the noise-injected version of \mu in p’).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: > Many of the parameters here are also unclear and not properly defined/introduced.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: What is the relationship between \theta and \tilde\theta exactly?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In this example, \theta and \tilde\theta never appear in the same model (they are part of p and p’, respectively).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We realized that this is confusing and have therefore renamed \tilde\theta to \tilde\mu.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: > In this simple model, can we not calculate the mutual information directly (i.e., without the bottleneck)?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: This is an excellent question.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In fact, we believe that trying to construct noise-free deep models with a specific mutual information of data and parameters for the purpose of generalization would be an interesting research direction.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Due to nonlinearities in typical deep models, it is at least not obvious how to calculate the mutual information between data and parameters.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The main challenge here would certainly be to come up with an effective estimator.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Relatedly, one would have to design priors and architecture to achieve a specific mutual information.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: > The connection between mutual information and generalization has been studied in several contexts [see, e.g., the references in this paper [...]] and further exploration is desirable.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: This paper is giving an information-theoretic perspective on existing variational inference methods.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Such a perspective is interesting, but needs to be further developed and explained.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Specifically, how can mutual information in this context be formally linked to generalization/overfitting?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We updated section 2.2 to relate to the references you mentioned.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: They explore the link of limiting mutual information and generalization error mostly in theory (and in particular for adaptive analysis).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In contrast, we deploy this principle in a practical model structure that is easily applicable to many existing deep and variational learning approaches and provide empirical evidence of the validity of our framework.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Also, the definition of mutual information used in this paper uses the inferred distribution q (e.g., in eq. 2), which is somewhat unusual.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: As a result, constraining the model will alter the mutual information and I think the effect of this should be remarked on.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We want to emphasize that we do use the standard definition of mutual information.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Therefore, the bottleneck implied by Eq. 5 is purely a property of the generative model and not influenced by the approximate inference distribution q.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Eq. 2 is only introduced to provide additional motivation for our approach as it allows to characterize overfitting in variational inference.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The guarantee derived in section 2.2 ties this quantity back to the mutual information from Eq. 5.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Thank you to Reviewer 1 for noting the clarity of our presentation and reproducibility.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We also appreciate the constructive criticism and thought that went into your review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We spent a considerable amount of time trying to fulfill the reviewer’s request to match state of the art (SOTA) on PTB.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: To get SOTA on PTB, we need massive architectures, which considerable computing power and experimentation at the extreme limit of what is achievable for our team.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Still, we pursued two directions.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: First, we tried to reimplement an architecture similar to  Melis et al. 2017.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, they did not publish their code, hyperparameters, or weights, requiring re-implementing and re-training from scratch.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We tried this path, but soon realized we would not be done in time (especially with a hyperparameter search).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We then tried to weave neuromodulation and differentiable plasticity into the architecture and code base of Merity et al., ICLR 2018 (also tied for SOTA).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, while they could simply leverage existing PyTorch implementations of LSTMs (written in extremely fast C++), we had to re-implement LSTMs “by hand” (i.e. as a series of connected layers) in PyTorch to introduce plasticity and neuromodulation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: As a result, our networks thus ran considerably slower, by more than 10x (not because our method is intrinsically slower, but just for lack of engineering optimizations on our bespoke Python implementations; we confirmed this by observing that a similar “hand-built” reimplementation of simple, non-plastic LSTMs ran similarly slower, while producing results identical to Merity et al.).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: These experiments are thus unfortunately still running.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For these reasons (and more provided below), we thus think it more fair (and necessary) to make such experiments the subject of a future paper.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: That said, we still believe the results in the current paper demonstrate the benefits of our techniques on a sizable model, and thus it would benefit the community to allow people to know about, and build upon, these new methods and results.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: The purpose of the present paper is to introduce a novel technique and show that it can produce an advantage in realistic settings, which we believe our PTB task confirms.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Our claim is that, all other things being equal (especially the number of parameters), a neuromodulated plastic LSTM outperformed a standard LSTM on this particular benchmark task.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We do **not** want to claim that our results are anywhere near SOTA.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We have modified our text to avoid possible misunderstandings (see end of next-to-last paragraph in Section 4).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Additionally, philosophically, If SOTA results are the bar for all papers to be accepted into conferences like ICLR, then those venues will be the exclusive domain of those with either the computation or time (i.e. large-scale resources) to dedicate to such results.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In that case, many cutting edge ideas will by necessity be excluded from the discussion, as will many research groups.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Moreover, insisting on papers to be SOTA to be accepted also likely encourages p-hacking and shoddy science to game the results (even if unintentionally), reducing the quality of science our community tries to build on.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Re: "Parameters of the model": All trainable parameters of the Hebbian synapses (alpha and w in Equation 1, plus the neuromodulation parameters) are included in this parameter count.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: To equalize the number of parameters across architectures, we reduce the number of hidden units in the plastic models in comparison to the non-plastic baseline.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have clarified this in the text.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Re: "Attention": Non-trainable, homogenous plasticity can indeed be compared to a form of attention, i.e. “attending to the recent past” in the words of Ba et al. 2016.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, differentiable plasticity allows for the plasticity of each connection to be trained; as a result, different connections play different roles and it is not at all clear that the analogy with attention remains relevant (see e.g. the clever mechanisms automatically implemented by the trained plasticity connections in the image completion experiment of the Differentiable Plasticity paper, Miconi et al. 2018, sections 4.3 and S.3, which can hardly be described as simply “attention”)
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: Re: "Style (font)": We used the template and do not see the discrepancy. Can you clarify? We are happy to fix it.
label: rebuttal_followup

sentence: We thank the reviewer for their encouraging words and will correct the errors of expression.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Thank you very much for the comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We believe that this response can help the Reviewer to be more convinced about the validness of our experiments; in particular, the validness of our retraining methodology.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Q1. The paper is not very self-contained, and I have to constantly go back to [1] and [2] in order to read through the paper.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In the original manuscript, we had to limit the detailed information of the previous work due to the page limit.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: Based on the Reviewer’s comments, we added more description about the schemes we adopted from [1] and [2] in Appendix A.1 and A.2 of the revised manuscript.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: For the Figure 4, we added the description of the underlined numbers.

sentence: Optimizing compression rates should be done on the training set with a separate development set.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The test set should not used before the best compression scheme is selected.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Both the results on the development set and on the test set should be reported for the validity of the experiments.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thanks for pointing this out.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We believe that this is the Reviewer 1's core question so would like to justify our results more in detail in this response and try to convince the Reviewer.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We agree that optimizing compression rates should not use the test set before the best compression scheme is selected.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: In fact, in case of PTB and Wikitext-2 corpus, we already used the provided validation set and measured the test PPW only once after training (Table 2) in the original manuscript.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: From the Table 2, we can see that our proposed scheme maintains the accuracy of the uncompressed baseline network.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: On the other hand, the CIFAR-10 dataset does not include a separate validation set, so we had to use the test set in the retraining process.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: To avoid using the test set in the retraining process as the Reviewer pointed out, we randomly selected 5K validation images among the original 50K training images in CIFAR-10 dataset, and applied our scheme.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Then, we observed the training and validation accuracy at each training epoch, and measured the test accuracy once after training.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The accuracy results are as shown in the following table.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Note the compression rates are the same as the data in Table 3 in the original manuscript.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Compression scheme   Validation Error (%)    Test Error (%)
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Baseline
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: VWM (Ours)
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The test accuracy in the above table is about 1 % less than the accuracy which we reported in the originally submitted manuscript because the number of training data was decreased as part of the data set is used as a validation set.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: However, the results show that our proposed method does not make the network be overfitted to test data as the Reviewer doubted because the difference between the accuracy for validation set and test set are consistent with the values from the previous works.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Note that even the uncompressed baseline network exhibits similar accuracy difference between the validation error and the test error compared with the compressed networks.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Therefore, we believe that our proposed compression method does not suffer from the concerned overfitting problem regardless of the types of neural networks or dataset.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Reference
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: [1] Dongsoo Lee, Daehyun Ahn, Taesu Kim, Pierce I. Chuang, and Jae-Joon Kim. Viterbi-based pruning for sparse matrix with fixed and high index compression ratio. International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR), 2018.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [2] Chen Xu, Jianqiang Yao, Zouchen Lin, Wenwu Qu, Yuanbin Cao, Zhirong Wang, and Hongbin Zha. Alternating multi-bit quantization for recurrent neural networks. International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR), 2018.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: Dear Reviewer,
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Thank you for your valuable comments.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We have revised our writing in the revision, and will further improve its clarity.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Please find our response as follows.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - Algorithm 1 does not include mitosis, which may have an effect on the resulting approximation.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Mitosis training can be considered as executing Algorithm 1 for multiple times with an increasing number of experts and inherited initialization from last round by changing W^e and W^g.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Also, training with mitosis achieves similar performance as training without it shown in Appendix B, Figure (a).
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: - How are the lambda and threshold parameters tuned? The authors mention a validation set, are they just exhaustively explored on a 3D grid on the validation set?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The hyper-parameters related to DS-softmax (such as lambda) are tuned according to the performance on a validation dataset.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Also, as we mentioned in the paper, only one hyper-parameter (group lasso lambda) needs to be tuned.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The heuristic we use to tune group lasso lambda is to increase lambda, starting from a small value, until it hurts the performance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Also threshold and balancing lambda variables are kept fixed as (0.01 and 10).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: - Why would it be expected to be faster than all the other alternatives? Wouldn't similar alternatives like the sparsely gated MoE, D-softmax and adaptive-softmax have chances of being faster?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In terms of baselines, SVD-softmax (NIPS’17) was chosen since it is a recent method that provides a significant inference speedup for softmax.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Other alternatives, such as D-softmax and adaptive-softmax, focus on training instead of inference speedup.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Furthermore, as claimed in their papers, they achieve limited speedup (around 5x) in language modeling, which is much worse than ours.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: With regards to Sparsely Gated MoE, it cannot speed up inference, since they select expert with full softmax.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We would like to emphasize that most existing methods for inference speedup focus on approximating trained softmax layer, which usually suffers a loss on performance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our model allows the adaptive adjustment of the softmax layer, achieves speedup through capturing the two-level overlapped hierarchy during training, which is novel and does not suffer from the performance loss.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We thank for the reviewer for their positive comments on our work, and we share our responses below.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: The purpose of our work is not to achieve state-of-the-art performance simply by incorporating the latest network architectures and optimisers.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Instead, we provide a novel general framework for automating generalisation, and show that when used with standard classification networks across all baselines, our method performs the best.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Furthermore, as we also explained in Reviewer #3, the hyper-parameters for defining a hierarchy is not critical, and we can choose an arbitrary hierarchy whilst still achieving better performance than baselines.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: In the future work, we would like to explore how to find the optimal hierarchy in an automatic manner, or provide an alternative solution on building a general type of auxiliary tasks (such as regression).
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: However, this is the first work to present a double-gradient method for auxiliary task generation, and we believe that it is important to present the success of this initial method now given how simple and general it is, and then fine-tune other aspects in future work.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: Thanks for your positive feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Lemma 2.4, Point 1: The gradient in your example is indeed perpendicular to w which can be seen as follows.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In case of one variable vector, our proof is to take the derivative of c on both sides of F(w) = F(cw), which is the definition of scale-invariance.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: Then the left-hand side becomes 0 and the right-hand side becomes w’ * \nabla F(cw)
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: by chain rule.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: Taking c = 1, we can conclude
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: that w’ * \nabla F(w)  = 0.
label: rebuttal_refute-question

sentence: Theorem 2.5: Sorry G_t should be G_t^{(i)}. We will correct this typo in the next revision of this paper.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: For t = 0, G_t^{(i)} are all initialized to some value.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: The recursion formula for G_t^{(i)} is shown in equation (9).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We thank AnonReviewer1 for their positive comments about the interesting-ness of our proposed abductive reasoning tasks (inference and generation) and the associated benchmark dataset.
label: rebuttal_accept-praise

sentence: We address specific concerns individually below:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Discussion about e-SNLI:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: A key distinction between e-SNLI and Abductive-NLI is that the explanations in e-SNLI serve the purpose of justifying model decisions.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In contrast, the goal of Abductive-NLI and Abductive-NLG is to select or generate explanatory hypotheses for given observations.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Indeed, analogous to e-SNLI for SNLI, Abductive-NLI can be extended to “e-Abductive-NLI” by providing explanations that justify the selected hypothesis.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Consider the following example that BERT fails to predict correctly:
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: O1: Chad loves Barry Bonds.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: H1: Chad got to meet Barry Bonds online, chatting.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: H2: Chad waited after a game and met Barry.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: O2: Chad ensured that he took a picture to remember the event.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The e-Abductive-NLI task would require models to generate an explanation for selecting H2.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For the above example, a possible explanation for selecting H2 could be: “People need to be physically co-located to take a picture with someone. Meeting online does not mean two people are physically co-located”.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We think generating such justifications is a great next step and hope that our work will foster such interesting future research.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Re. somewhat limited contribution:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We appreciate the opportunity to briefly restate our contributions and to discuss its significance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Abductive Commonsense Reasoning, a critical capability in human reasoning, is relatively less studied in NLP research.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: To support this line of research, our work introduces a dataset that focuses explicitly on this important reasoning capability.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Furthermore, several recent works [1,2,3,4] have shown the presence of annotation artifacts in crowdsourced datasets -- which poses a significant challenge for dataset curation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our work makes the following contributions:
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: i) proposes and formalizes two novel tasks of Abductive Inference and Abductive Generation,
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: ii) presents a new dataset in support of these tasks collected through careful crowdsourcing design and an adversarial filtering algorithm,
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: iii) establishes strong baselines on the task proving the difficulty of the tasks and
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: iv) analyses the types of commonsense reasoning that current state of the art models fall short on.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Re. limited form of Abductive Reasoning:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The simplifying assumptions, mentioned in the paper, allow us to i) formulate the tasks concretely and ii) curate the dataset and evaluate models viably.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We show that in spite of the assumptions, our dataset presents significant challenges for current models.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We totally agree that in its most general form, there should be any number of observations and models should be required to generate explanatory hypotheses in natural language (as in the alpha-NLG task).
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: We hope our work will lead to this future line of research.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Re. the title:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thanks for the suggestion. We will update the title to reflect that this work is aimed at language-based abductive reasoning.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Table 7 vs Table2:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thanks for catching that. We’ve updated the paper with the fix.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: [1] Gururangan et al. Annotation artifacts in natural language inference data.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [2] Poliak et al. Hypothesis only baselines in natural language inference.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [3] Tsuchiya e. al. Performance impact caused by hidden bias of training data for recognizing textual entailment.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [4] Sakaguchi et al. WINOGRANDE: An Adversarial Winograd Schema Challenge at Scale
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: Thank you for the detailed review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We appreciate your comments on the contributions of our work and invaluable suggestions to improving our paper.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Before delving into the details and providing a more detailed rebuttal, here are some of our initial thoughts.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Regarding comparison with MINE on fMRI dataset, MINE could be applied to fMRI data for MI analysis.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: After all, our DEMINE-vr is simply MINE under cross-validation.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our first guess is that MINE will not be able to identify significant dependency in Table.1 due to large confidence intervals, i.e, the rows and cols for MINE will be all 0s.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For segment classification, MINE-f-ES uses the same model architecture and training process as DEMINE-vr and uses hyper parameters from DEMINE-vr hyperparameter search, and will provide identical segment classification accuracy as DEMINE-vr.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thanks again for pointing out the typos, we'll post an updated version shortly.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We thank the reviewer for insightful feedback and for noting that our​ experiments ​are​ ​solid​ and our setup and analyses are sound.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: The reviewer asks great questions, and we provide the answers below.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: RE: Total running time
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The reviewer raises an interesting point about total training time, which includes the time to pre-train a GNN and the time to fine-tune it on a downstream task.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: To address this point, below, we give the results of the total training time as well as the amortized total time over different downstream tasks.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We will include detailed results and a discussion in the final version of the paper.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: We note that although pre-training does take some time, it is a one-time-effort only.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: That is, we pre-train a GNN model only once and then reuse it many times by fine-tuning the model on any number of downstream prediction tasks.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Overall, we find that GNNs, once pre-trained, tend to converge much faster on downstream tasks.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Most importantly, we find (details below) that validation set performance converges 5-12 times more quickly when GNNs are pre-trained.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We emphasize that this cannot be achieved by mere training of (non-pre-trained) GNNs longer.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: The following summarizes training time for chemistry and biology datasets.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 1) Chemistry dataset (single GPU implementation)
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Pre-training**
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: — Self-supervised pre-training: 24 hours
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: — Supervised pre-training: 11 hours
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: **Fine-tuning on MUV dataset** [Time to achieve the best validation set AUC]
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: — From random initialization (i.e., no pre-training):
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 1 hour; 74.9% AUC
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: — From a pre-trained GNN:
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 5 minutes; 85.3% AUC
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 2) Biology dataset
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Pre-training**
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: — Self-supervised pre-training:  3.8 hours
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: — Supervised pre-training: 2.5 hours
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: **Fine-tuning** [Time to achieve the best validation set AUC]
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: — From random initialization (i.e., no pre-training):
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 50 minutes; 84.8% AUC
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: — From a pre-trained GNN:
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 10 minutes; 88.8% AUC
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: On chemistry dataset, we see that fine-tuning a pre-trained GNN on the MUV required only 5 min.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: This is in sharp contrast with training a GNN from scratch, which required 12x more time, yet it gave a worse performance.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We can reach similar conclusions on the biology dataset.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We thus recommend using pre-trained models whenever possible as they can give better performance and can be reused for any number of downstream tasks.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We shall add these results and explanations to the final version of the paper.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: RE: Analysis of different pre-training strategies
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Thank you for bringing up this valuable point.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We agree that it is important to understand why some pre-training strategies work better over others.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Our key insight backed up with extensive empirical evidence is that a combination of graph-level and node-level methods (Figure 1) is important because it allows the model to capture both local and global semantics of graphs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Further, we find that our structure-based node-level methods (Context Prediction and Attribute Masking) are preferred over position-based node-level methods (Edge Prediction, Deep Graph Infomax). As future work, we plan to further investigate what graph-level and node-level methods are most useful in different domains, and understand what domain-specific knowledge has been learned by the pre-trained models.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Dear reviewer,
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Thank you for your comment. Before we reply to the points you have made, we would kindly ask you to please add the references that are missing from your review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Thank you for your review of our work.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: The following are your concerns of our work:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: a. Prior distributions of hyperparameters
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: b. Loss landscape plots and relation to tunability
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: c. Importance of search order
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: d. Details of the calibration procedure
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We address them as follows (in two parts):
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: a. Prior distributions of hyperparameters:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We envisage an optimizer not merely as update equations, but as the conjunction of the update equations, the hyperparameters, and distributions of those hyperparameters.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Those distributions should be prescribed by the designers of the optimizer.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This is crucial: For example, if we take Adam with LR between $10^1$ and $10^5$ and claim that Adam is less tunable than others, the evaluation is inherently faulty, as it doesn't capture where the mode of the distribution of LRs for which Adam is expected to work.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: These prescriptions are absent for the optimizers considered in the paper.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Therefore, we define them from either mathematical reasoning (say learning rate is non-negative, $\beta_1, \beta_2$ in Adam are between (0, 1) and close to 1) or using the calibration step, where we determine those distributions by fitting on the configurations that yielded reasonably good results.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We choose simple priors for their ease of estimation, though given enough computation, arbitrarily complex priors can be computed and used.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We fail to see the explicit relationship between our work and the papers you have referenced.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Specifically [1] only proposes that there is an optimal batch size that is dependent on the momentum parameter.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We do not consider tuning the batch size, as we do not consider it a hyperparameter of the optimizer itself.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: [2] shows that instead of using LR decay schedule, increasing batch size has a similar effects on training, but results in faster training.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: [3] talks about the existence of an effective learning rate as a function of learning rate and the norm of the weights, and proposes that the optimal learning rate is inversely proportional to the weight decay parameter.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This doesn’t, however, trivially lend itself to modeling priors.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: In summary, these papers show a complex interplay between the parameters giving rise to other notions, but not provide any methods to jointly model these hyperparameters.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: In the absence of such knowledge, we use our calibration procedure.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The distributions we use are justified in section 3.2 in the paper.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However, we accept the fact that a more complex distribution that might model the interaction between these hyperparameters might exist, and using that to sample for an HPO would be better.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: b. Loss landscape plots and relation to tunability:
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We show in figures 1.a, 1.b, as you rightly pointed out, the landscapes of loss function of the HPO objective as a function of the hypothetical hyperparameter $\theta$. There seems to be a misunderstanding of the purpose of figures 1.a, and 1.b.: These figures do not show what we try to measure, but they merely illustrate by example what properties we would like a tunability metric to have.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We describe this in the beginning of Section 2.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In Section 5, we explain why existing measures of tunability are unable to make the distinction between the cases in Figure 1a.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We would like to emphasize that the point of Figures 1a, 1b is to illustrate the necessary properties that a proposed metric for tunability - it is not our intention to create such plots for our actual experiments.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: If you are interested in these nonetheless, a very recent publication by Asi & Duchi (2019) shows the plot of lr vs performance.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In summary, they show that the sensitivity of SGD to stepsize choices, which converges only for a small range of stepsizes.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: AdamLR exhibits better robustness when tested on CIFAR10.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for the comments!
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: To reviewer’s concerns:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - First of all, the state of interest does not have to be the object state.
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: It can be the state of the robot, for example, the state of actuators.
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: Maximizing the mutual information between two sets of actuator states can help the agent to learn to control itself.
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: We did a new experiment in navigation environments, where train the agent to maximize the mutual information between its left wheel states and its right wheel states.
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: The agent learns to run in a straight line instead of in random directions.
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: The video showing experiment results is available at https://youtu.be/l5KaYJWWu70?t=134
label: rebuttal_contradict-assertion

sentence: - Although we evaluated our method in robotic manipulation tasks, it does not mean it won’t work for other tasks.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We added additional experiments in a new navigation task, see the video at https://youtu.be/l5KaYJWWu70?t=104
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We consider our algorithm as a general-purpose skill learning algorithm in the sense that it guides the agent to learn any skills to control the states of interests.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: The states of interest could be any states, such as the robot states, the object states, or the states of the environment.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: - The state of interest is specified by the user with little domain knowledge.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: However, when there is no clear divide from the user, the agent can learn from different combinations of the states of interest and the context states.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: In the end, the user can choose skills from the learned skill sets that are useful for the task at hand.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: - The combination of our method and DIAYN enables DIAYN to learn manipulation skills efficiently, while DIAYN alone did not learn.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Furthermore, compared to MISC, the combined method enjoys the benefits brought by DIAYN, such as learning combinable motion primitive with skill-conditioned policy for hierarchical reinforcement learning [1].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Reference:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: [1] Benjamin Eysenbach, Abhishek Gupta, Julian Ibarz, and Sergey Levine. Diversity is all you need: Learning skills without a reward function. In International Conference on Learning Representations, 2019. URL https://openreview.net/forum?id=SJx63jRqFm.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We thank the reviewer for the comments and feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We will also include the suggested experiment that shows the plug-and-play nature of PMN.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: 1. Residual modules
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - Residual modules are small neural networks (e.g., an MLP for Mvqa, Sec. 3.4, (4)) that a task module may use when other lower level modules are incapable of providing a solution to a given query.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For example, consider the question “is this person going to be happy?” on an image of a person opening a present.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Lower level modules of Mvqa may not be sufficient to solve the question.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Therefore, Mvqa would make use of its residual module, which would essentially learn to “pick up” all queries that lower level modules cannot answer.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2. Effect of fine-tuning
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - While it might be beneficial to fine-tune the modules for a specific parent task we want each module to be an expert for their own task as it facilitates a plug-and-play architecture.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Fine-tuning may push the modules towards blindly improving parent module’s performance but (i) badly affect interpretability of inputs and outputs; and (ii) may also reduce the lower module’s performance on its own task.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Most importantly, it would not scale with the number of tasks, as for each task the agent would need to keep several fine-tuned modules of the lower tasks in memory.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 3. Feeding in the ground-truth
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: - Thanks for this great suggestion.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We performed an experiment where we evaluate the benefits that the VQA model may achieve by using ground-truth captions instead of captions generated by the caption module.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Our preliminary experiments show a gain of about 2.0% which is a relatively high gain for VQA.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: This points to important properties of the PMN allowing human-in-the-loop type of continual learning, where a human teacher can pinpoint flaws in the reasoning process and potentially help the model to fix them.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for the useful feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We’ve updated our paper to take it into account -- we’ve updated the model description and the notation in Section 4 to clarify our method.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Two important additions are a high-level summary of the model, which we give at the beginning of Section 4, and a table (Table 2) that lists what each symbol represents along with its dimensions.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We also made several updates that address your specific questions.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 1. Are e_{i,t} and lambda_{i,t} vectors?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Scalars?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Abstract node notations? It is not clear in the model section.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Also, it took me a long time to figure out that ‘i’ is used to index each entity (it is mentioned later).
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: The entity and location embeddings  e_{i,t} and lambda_{i,t} are d-dimensional vectors, although we also overload the symbols to refer to abstract nodes in the model’s knowledge graphs.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In the updated manuscript we state both these facts explicitly and state much earlier that ‘i’ is the index for entities.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 2. The paper says v_i (initial representation of each entity) is obtained by looking at the contextualized representations (LSTM outputs) of entity mention in the context.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: What happens if there are multiple mentions in the text? Which one does it look at?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: When there are multiple mentions of entity i, the initial representation v_i is formed by summing the representations of each mention.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have updated the paper to clarify this (Sec 4.1).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: 3. For the LSTM in the graph update, why does it have only one input? Shouldn’t it have two inputs, one for previous hidden state and the other for input?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Good point! We’ve improved the notation used to describe the model in Section 4.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: The update equation now shows clearly that the LSTM takes in the concatenation of two node inputs (entity and location embeddings) along with the previous hidden state.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 4. Regarding Recipe experiments, the paper says it reaches a better performance than the baseline using just 10k examples out of 60k.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: This is great, but could you also report the number when the full dataset is used?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We’ve completed an experiment on the full Recipes dataset and updated the paper to describe the result (this experiment did not finish in time for the initial submission).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: The model’s F1 score improves from 51.64 on the partial data to 54.27 on the full data, surpassing the previous state of the art by a more significant margin.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: 5. What does it mean that in training time the model “updates” the location node representation with the encoding of the correct span. Do you mean you use the encoding instead?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We meant that we perform teacher-forcing to train the model.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: During training, we extract the context encodings for the groundtruth span and use these in downstream operations  to obtain the node representations.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: At test time, we use the MRC module’s predicted span rather than the groundtruth.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: 6. For ProPara task 2, what threshold did you choose to obtain the P/R/F1 score?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Is it the threshold that maximizes F1?
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: For ProPara task 2, our model was optimized for micro averaged F1 on the development set.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Tandon et al. (2018) were kind enough to provide us with their evaluation script.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for your thoughtful review.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We have been hard at work to perform additional experiments to compare with other state of the art methods on a broader dataset.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: We summarize the changes here and will upload a revised the manuscript with complete quantitative evaluations before the revision deadline.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: Q1: More extensive evaluations
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In response to your comments, we have trained and tested our method on the dataset provided in [1], using the F1 score rather than Chamfer Distance in accordance with the recommendations in that work.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: This dataset contains more than 4 times as many classes as our original dataset.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We find that HOF is competitive with the performance of various state of the art methods reported in [1], showing the highest average F1 score out of all methods compared in [1].
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: See Section 4.1.2 for added discussion, and the Appendix Sections A7 and A8 for complete class performance breakdowns for both our original experiments as well as the new comparison with [1].
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We hope this extended comparison provides a more convincing experimental evaluation of HOF.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Q2: Technical description and justification
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In the paper, we make the observation that codeword based approaches are equivalent to learning the biases of a fixed network, whereas the fast-weights-based HOF approach learns all of the weights.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Therefore, we conclude that HOF is mathematically at least as general as codeword based architectures.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We further show, with experiments, that the coding provided by HOF is more efficient than codeword-based approaches in terms of number of parameters in the decoder.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: There is similar evidence in the literature which suggests that fast-weights based approaches can be more efficient than static networks.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: However at this point, similar to our paper, the evidence is empirical and a theoretical justification of this phenomenon is missing.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: In response to your comments, in our concluding remarks, we mention this lack of theoretical analysis and note it as an important direction for future research
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: Q3: Architecture of encoder/mapping network
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In addition to experiments on a new dataset, we have performed new evaluations of variants of HOF on our original dataset to demonstrate that HOF performs competitively even when we change the encoder architecture, decoder depth, decoder activation function, or input sampling for the decoder network.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For example, using Resnet18 as the encoder network gives almost identical performance in terms of average chamfer distance on our original test set.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: The complete quantitative results of these comparisons will be included in an updated PDF before the end of the discussion period.
label: rebuttal_by-cr

sentence: Q4: Number of mapping layers
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Our original results reported in Table 1 compare two different mapping function architectures.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: HOF-1 has one hidden layer with 1024 units, HOF-3 has 3 hidden layers with 128 units each.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We have updated the text to clarify this distinction.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: In response to your comments, we have also conducted an additional experiment with a mapping network with 6 hidden layers with 128 units each; the test performance of this architecture is almost identical to that of HOF-3 (1.2485 average Chamfer distance with 6 layers compared with 1.247 average CD for 3 layers).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Q5: Vanishing/exploding gradients
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In all of our experiments, we address the problem of vanishing/exploding gradients by dividing by the square root of the in-degree of each neuron (as in [2]).
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Using the same initialization in the encoder network, we find that training a mapping function with 6 hidden layers ("HOF-6") trained easily with no modifications to our training code.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Another advantage of HOF over deeper, fixed decoder architectures is that it admits extremely shallow decoders, which require less careful tuning of hyperparameters such as initialization scaling and normalization compared with deeper networks.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: For this work, our goal was not necessarily to find the optimal architecture for the decoder, but rather to demonstrate that the usage of the higher-order function paradigm allows for a much smaller decoder architecture than LVC methods.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: Thank you for bringing the additional literature to our attention.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: We have included it in our discussion of related work in a revised manuscript.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We have also updated the text to more clearly explain the path-based evaluation and its motivation.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We hope that these additional experiments better demonstrate the effectiveness of HOF as a competitive, parameter-efficient 3d reconstruction paradigm.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: Thank you again for your feedback.
label: rebuttal_social

sentence: [1] M. Tatarchenko, S. R. Richter, R. Ranftl, Z. Li, V. Koltun, and T. Brox, “What do single-view 3d reconstruction networks learn?,” in Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition, pp. 3405– 3414, 2019.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: [2] K. He, X. Zhang, S. Ren, and J. Sun. Delving deep into rectifiers: Surpassing human-level performance on imagenet classification. In ICCV, 2015.
label: rebuttal_other

sentence: Thank you for your thoughtful and helpful comments.
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: Following the suggestions, we added additional results for the associative recall task for many network variants.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: We also report mean and variance of losses for different seeds.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: This shows that masking improves performance on this task especially when combined with improved de-allocation, while sharpness enhancements negatively affect performance in this case.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: From the variance plots it can be seen that some seeds of DNC-M and DNC-MD converge significantly faster than plain DNC.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: In our experimental section, we added requested references to methods performing better on bAbI, and point out that our goal is not to beat SOTA on bAbI, but to exhibit and overcome drawbacks of DNC.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Comparison to Sparse DNC is an interesting idea, and we are currently running experiments in this direction. We intend to make the results available in the near future.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: We are unable to provide a fair comparison for the lowest bAbi scores, having reported 8 seeds compared to the 20 seeds reported by Graves et al. Indeed, the high variance of DNC (Table 1) suggests that it may benefit a lot from exploring additional seeds.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: We incorporated all of the smaller notes, including a comparison to the original DNC equations in Appendix A.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (1) Multimodal setting:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We apologize for not describing experimental settings clearly.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: In general, we believe multi-modal data is more general than simply image-text or video-text pair.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: By unifying tabular data also as multi-modal data (with each attribute as one modality), we show that VASE provides us a principled way for imputation and is capable of generalizing to more data families.
label: rebuttal_answer

sentence: We update additional multimodal dataset experiments in the point (3) below.
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: (2) Prediction and Representation learning:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We consider conducting these experiments during the rebuttal but none of the paper's code has been released by the authors.
label: rebuttal_reject-request

sentence: We agree deep latent variable models explicitly model the data distribution and provide a natural way for representation learning, but in our paper we evaluate the model from the perspective of imputation and generation.
label: rebuttal_mitigate-criticism

sentence: (3) Additional experiments:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: We updated additional imputation experiments on multimodal datasets (see in Appendix C.5) : CMU-MOSI/ICT-MMMO (Tsai et al. 2019), FashionMNIST/MNIST (Wu et al. 2018).
label: rebuttal_done

sentence: Each dataset contains two or three modalities.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: VSAE outperforms other baselines on multimodal datasets under partially-observed setting.
label: rebuttal_summary

sentence: (4) Require mask during training:
label: rebuttal_structuring

sentence: In our experiments, the binary mask is always fully-observed as is the nature of partially-observed data.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: A mask simply indicates which  modalities are observed and which are not.
label: rebuttal_reject-criticism

sentence: We agree that it is very interesting to design a model with partially-observed or even unobserved mask.
label: rebuttal_concede-criticism

sentence: However, it is beyond the scope of this work and we will consider it in future work.
label: rebuttal_future

sentence: [1] Wu et al. Multimodal Generative Models for Scalable Weakly-Supervised Learning, NeurIPS 2018.

sentence: [2] Tsai et al. Learning Factorized Multimodal Representation, ICLR 2019.
